content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												I must say this is the most unique and engrossing games I have played in quite some time. The game forces you to slow down and look for clues in order to solve the array of mysteries that you undertake. Having a keen eye and a good memory is imperative to cracking the case. The interrogations are truly the most gripping part of the game; nothing is more exciting than getting a confession after spending hours unearthing clues, following leads, interviewing witnesses and chasing suspects.Team Bondi has changed the face of video games with L.A. Noire. The facial expressions in this game are unrivaled by anything currently out there, and they're not just used during cut-scenes, it's in effect at all time during the game; a level of dedication most becoming of a Rockstar Game. They're so good in fact that you're left wanting the rest of the world to be on par. I'm not saying that it looks bad but it is missing minor polish seen in other Rockstar games (I understand it's a Bondi game...) like limited damage on the cars, bullet holes are missing when a car or person is shot... and that's it. That's all the nitpicking I can pull off.Gunplay isn't as sharp as Grand Theft Auto and takes a little getting used to but it feels right for this type of game and works just fine. The focus isn't wholesale gunfights, rather poignant, key engagements that mean something; you are an officer of the law after all.Give this game a shot if you like cop dramas, film noires, GTA, tacos, fresh and unique gaming experiences.

number of helpful: 222 of 240 people (93%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
TL;DR? See ConclusionINTRODUCTION:L.A. Noire is an open world neo-noire police / detective game made by Team Bondi and published by Rockstar Games. It features crime scene investigation, interrogations, arrests, and possibly, for the first time in the Rockstar games portfolio, police chases where the player is the police.If you like movies such as L.A. Confidential (specially this one), Chinatown and The Untouchables, you'll definitely might want to give this game a try.PROS:+ Facial Animation: -The selling point of L.A. Noire is possibly the facial motion capture technology that was employed. It is this technique that makes the game's interrogations as close to realism as possible for the 'truth / doubt / lie' mechanic to work.+ Atmosphere: -The devs have done remarkable work recreating the wonderful city of 1947 Los Angeles. Although it may not be exactly how it was back then, it's still a large and magnificent city to explore. From the cars, the clothing, the buildings and the radio, Team Bondi certainly nailed the 1947 atmosphere.+ Investigation: -From examining clues to following leads, LA Noire delivers a great police / detective mechanic that provides fun and exciting experience.+ Sound: -Great voice acting, great selection of 1940s classic hits, a bit of radio news from that time, good sound effects and some very classical OST vibe. The voice acting makes for some very memorable characters with unique personalities.+ Playtime: -The game is extensive and will require some time to finish. From the main story, DLC cases, Street Crimes and Collectibles, there are a lot of things to do which is more than enough to make you feel that your money was well spent.CONS:- 30 FPS: -According to the devs, the reason for this was that the motion-capture technology would not function properly if it was not locked at 30 FPS. Be that as it may, most PC gamers would still expect certain games to run at 60fps minimum.- Awkward Body Movements: -I kinda feel they focused a bit too much on the facial animation and severely under developed the body animation. Most character movements are awkward and the bodies seem to move like they were made from cardboard or cement.-  No reward for Non-Lethal Arrest: -The game has optional 'Street Crimes' which can be solved by lethal or non-lethal methods (depending on the Crime). Unfortunately, there is no reward in trying to chase down a fleeing suspect and it would be much easier just to shoot them in the back. This disappointed me a lot.CONCLUSION:GOOD GAME for a GOOD PRICE. L.A. Noire captures the classical 1940-70 police / detective movies that once graced the silver screens but with a bit of modern sprinkles to it. WORTH IT?:Sale or full price, this game is worth every penny.I suggest that potential buyers of this game purchase the 'Complete' Edition which includes the DLCs because they extend the gameplay by providing additional 'Cases' for each of the game's chapters.--------------------------------------------------------- Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:Miyumi's Review Corner (MIRECO)

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												L.A. Noire is a detective game, simple as that. If you're looking for another shoot everything rampage game like GTA just because this game is made by Rockstar then this is not the game for you. Sure there is shooting, but you won't be allowed to kill everyone in sight, running people over will affect your case rating etc. The Atmosphere	  Personally, I love the setting of the game, the late 40s jazz theme mixed with golden age Hollywood as well as a classic noir feel makes for a great mix, but while the storytelling is good, it's not all there. The story feels a bit like it's jumping around without finishing everything off, Rockstar gathered enough story for a movie, but not a 20 hour game. Because of this you will be left with extra things that feel like they are just there to fill up an hour of your time and parts of the story that are never properly concluded. This being said, the story has some great parts towards the second half of the game and does a great job 80% of the time, however the ending will feel incomplete.  Gameplay and Fun	 It's fun to drive around and using your siren to move people out of the way is great. The car chases are exciting at first but end up being repetitive, as with all the chases. Shootouts feel this way too and there are one or two that will feel boring. The combat tends to feel stiff from time to time. For an open world game it is very linear and the free roam mode itself actually takes some working out to access. Street crimes are fun to attend to and interrogations are challeging. The clue finding in the game is brilliant and walking around the crime scenes never gets old although you will quickly work out the set structure to finding all the clues. Sound	 The sound in the game makes for great immersion, no complaints here really. The hint sounds at crime sounds can be turned off if they make the game too easy and the whole feel of the sirens and the radio really sells the 40s atmosphere. Graphics	 The facial expressions are the best part about the graphics, I didn't notice too many hiccups in the graphics and if I did they didn't distract from the game. The faces of people look incredibly lifelike and all the other graphics are good too. The sunny setting of Los Angeles adds a bright feeling to the game. Replayability	 While you do have the option to replay your cases to get all clues and perfect your interrogation this game is likely to be one you will only play the story of once, it's still fun to drive around and do street crimes but the cases tend to be something that's best as a one time thing. Verdict	 Overall this game is great fun and a nice step away from GTA while still keeping to the Rockstart format. It feels fresh but also familiar. The graphics look very good for a game that came out in 2011. You will feel very immersed in the time period through use of sound and surroundings. The open world side has something to be desired and Los Angeles doesn't exactly feel as alive as GTA 4's Liberty City or Watch Dog's Chicago, it doesn't have much of a personality, the characters do. If you're looking for a good open world game, this isn't it, if you're looking for a good story with a mix of puzzle and regular shoot/drive gameplay and well designed characters then this is it. Get this if: You like a good story You want diverse gameplay that makes you think You like the Noir settingDon't get this if: You want full freedom in an open world You want to go on a killing spree You don't care about story  8.5/10

Posted: November 25, 2013
												I have enjoyed this tremendously. This is probably the most expensive adventure game ever created, only without the point-and-click, of course. But you will be going from location to another location and looking for clues.You will scoff at the locked 30 fps and you'll be baffled at the confusing interrogations, however the atmosphere and the authenticity of this game is a marvellous feat. Los Angeles depicted in the late 40s is only a backdrop, but it plays its role well.Playing L.A. Noire was like watching a really great TV series – each case is around an hour and a half long, and they all tell a different story. If this were a film, it would be quite bland probably, but this is game, and with interactivity it comes to life. Also I have to say the face capture technology is not a gimmick but an integral part of gameplay, and I cannot wait for the next game by Team Bondi and Mr. McNamara.

												L.A. Noire is not for everyone, it's linear, you gotta make the right decisions or most of the time you'll see a game over screen.But for those who, like me, are into detective whodunit type of stories this game is for you.There's content here for all tastes in crime: traffic, vice, arson and the Homicide desk, which is the best IMO.The driving feels a bit stiff, but nothing that will bother you too much, since you can have your partner drive you places if you don't feel like spending time behind the wheel and want to get straight to business.There is quite some replay value if you want to discover all clues, get all the film reels, cars etc..*The producers really put some hard work in bringing 1947 Los Angeles back, the city is beautiful and feels alive, like every person walking the streets has a story to tell, the attention to detail in this game is amazing, its a pity that so many areas of the city are left out of the main story.Needless to say I recommend this game for those who are interested in deep narrative and focus on story rather than just mindless action.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												This is one of the best detective games I've ever played. L.A Noire is also very underrated compared to other games from Rockstar Games. Only problem with this game is the PC-port. The resolution was a little strange on my computer and unfortunately the game is locked at 30 fps. That basically means that it runs and looks  like the console version. I would actually recommend an xbox 360 controller to get the best experience.You play as Cole Phelps, a police officer. As the story goes you get higher and higher rank. You move up from a police officer to Arson Desk, Vice Desk and so on. You solve big murder cases by finding clues and interview witnesses. The story is good and comes with a plot twist and a surprising ending. The notable thing about L.A Noire is the Motion Scan though. It is a really cool technique where you use multiple cameras to capture facial expressions from every angle. It looks so real, and I wish more games would use this. In L.A Noire they used 32 cameras just for the face.The biggest problem with the FPS-cap is when you're driving. The driving feels slow and laggy. However, the framerate wasn't a problem when I investigated things, and that's what you will do the most. You can have your partner drive to almost all locations (like a fast travel) which is great and prevents the problem. So if you're thinking about buying this game for the driving then I would say no, buy GTA instead. If you want a good action adventure crime game, then this is for you.It's tough to decide whether I should recommend this game or not. It's such a great concept with good gameplay, superb voice acting and Motion Scan, but the PC-port is far from good. I think LA Noire is too good to miss out on just based on the port though, so I would say i recommend it. Pick it up on sale and you shouldn't regret it. I got 45 hours of enjoyment just from the story, and I still have many side activites to do.

number of helpful: 76 of 83 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												There are games you know when you play that there hasn't been any real work put into it and most of the budget went into marketing. But there are some games that when you play, you KNOW that the sheer amount of creativity put into it and the expenses made to craft the experience and make a world has paid off.And then there's LA Noire.This game sets a new standard for the storytelling experience in games, not only with it's technology, but with it's excellent integration of good gameplay mechanics and using that as a way to unravel for yourself the world and it's mysteries.The gameplay involved in solving the cases is pretty solid, with you scouting for clues that will later be used in interrogations. Though the clue-hunting is little more than a game of click-everywhere-until-something-happens, the meat is in the driving sequences and the interrogations. The driving sequences make full use of the fact that there's a big open world out there and anything could happen. Simply driving from one place to another is a nice experience as you see in full glory the love and patience with which Team Bondi recreated 1940s LA. Of course these can be skipped but you'll be missing out on the side missions which dot the city from time to time and can only be discovered if you take over the wheels.But the true flavor comes from the interrogations. They used this technology masterfully in order to not only make the interrogations engaging, but also accessible with some exaggerations on the part of the actors which was done on purpose knowing full well the limitations this technology could have. Simply reading the expressions isn't enough since you also have to back up your accusations with evidence. This requires some thought and patience on your part and you need to read the descriptions of each clue carefully before using them. Suffice it to say that the game is worth it for these sequences and there are a LOT of them.The story too is quite excellent with many noire elements, plot twists and an overarching conspiracy. LA Confidential, the 1997 movie set in around the same time, was a considerable influence for the game.There are a few negatives though. Some cases felt like I wasn't really solving them. Even though ALL the cases have definitive culprits, there were a couple of cases where I felt I was simply going through the motions. The shooting isn't very good. The chase sequences on foot aren't really great as there are some navigation issues. Though the game is HUGE with MANY cases and the DLC also contributing to the list, there's not much to do outside the story missions which somewhat ruins the fact that these guys toiled so much to recreate this beautiful city. The PC port, though it has many of the features other PC ports lack like a good options menu and reasonable mouse support, it still is quite wonky though I wasn't too distracted by it.Minor faults don't bring down this excellent game though. It is something I would definitely recommend to any gamer who wants to play a linear story-driven non-action intensive game. Suffice it to say that after I was done, I missed the game and felt just a little hollow inside.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
A criminally underrated game, a flawed masterpiece and one of my absolute favourites. If you love point and click games, games where you play as the detective or are just a fan of the noir genre: this one's a must-buy for you folks!I played this on the PC back in 2012 and I don't understand why it's taken me this long to make a review for this game... but here it is. I've got 120 hours on L.A. Noire and that doesn't even include the 100 hours or so I've racked up on the Xbox 360. Before I praise the hell out of this game, I'd like to go over some issues with this game in general:1. The main campaign's quite long (~20 hours) and at-times repetitive. This might not be a con for some people but it's worth mentioning regardless. Although there's a lot of variety, you won't shake off the feeling you've already done this x amount of times.2. The city hasn't got much to do in it. Another game, Mafia II, similarly shared this issue but there are street crimes or sidequests to participate in, vehicles to find and collectibles to attain. The stunning recreation of a 1940's Los Angeles is worth exploring but unfortunately there's not a lot of reasons to do so.3. The port is locked to 30 FPS. This is not a dealbreaker for people like me but again, I thought it was worth mentioning. There also exists several unofficial ways of unlocking this (and there's not a lot of negative side-effects which is neat).4. Performance can be hit and miss for a few individuals. I recommend swapping from Direct X 9 to Direct X 11 and vice versa for those people, as well as changing the Threading mode from "single" to "multi" and vice versa.With that out of the way, here's why you should get this game:1. The atmosphere. This game oozes it and you'll be immersed right away. Set in the 1940s you are placed in the shoes of a bright star who is rising through the ranks of the Los Angeles Police Department. As you play as Cole Phelps and go from case to case: the voice acting and dialogue, the clothing, the cars... every little detail wants to convince you that you are in this setting. And to think an Australian team (Team Bondi) pulled this off. It's incredible and simply deserves to be mentioned.2. The story. The story doesn't reveal itself until later in the game and until then, you're working your way from one case to the next with the occasional collectible newspaper acting as a "here's what's also going on" feature. What I liked most about the story is that it's subtle early on and then it all starts making sense. It's nothing super-amazing but I would be lying if I said I didn't think it was good. Bits and pieces of the game world also serve the story well in reinforcing issues and ideas that were present in the 1940s.3. The characters. You've got a large roster with people of all different beliefs and personalities. Everyone feels unique, multi-layered and realistic. The characters further aid in immersing you in this wonderful game.


That's what she said. 
A Screenshot of L.A. Noire
By: -3xA'Lu©κy




4. The gameplay. Most of the time the game's rather slow-paced. You'll be walking or driving to a crime scene while picking up clues, but at points in the game, all hell breaks loose. A man starts a brawl with you! A criminal starts making a run for it! A shootout occurs! Moments like these help break up the monotony, and while most of them are scripted, they really are exciting. Don't go in expecting an action game though. When you're not searching for clues or being a badass: you're doing interrogations. I'll talk about this in the next point.5. The motion capture/interrogations. Never has a game utilized motion capture like this I reckon. When you're interrogating a suspect: you're not interrogating a NPC, you're interrogating someone that looks and acts like a real human being. It's something you'll simply have to witness for yourself. And this doesn't just apply to interrogations - the whole game uses motion capture for every character's face and I couldn't be more pleased with the result. Back to interrogations though... I love them. Some find difficulty with these but it's probably because the choices you have to make - Truth, Doubt or Lie - were originally called: Truth, Coax or Force. I have no idea why they were changed for the final product, as they make less sense. Still, interrogating is where you rely on this motion capture the most to see if the suspect is lying. Just like real life though: don't judge a person soley by their looks or behaviour though!6. The soundtrack. I could go on and on in this section but let me just say this: Team Bondi killed it here. You might not be a fan of 1940s music but you'll be able to appreciate just how accurate the setting feels.7. Everything else. The huge open city to explore. Being able to slap on a black and white filter in the options menu is just another thing that makes me love this game. Swapping between costumes for Cole Phelps is really nice too. Making different choices and the somewhat linear missions changing up a little to reflect this. The little conversations between Cole and his partners as you're driving in a car throughout the city. And if you don't want to drive? Being able to make your partner transport you to the destination in a few seconds or so. It's all small stuff in the end but it's the icing on the cake for me.Hopefully you can see why this game is so special to me. I believe this game still doesn't get the recognition it deserves but it's great to see more and more people are experiencing this gem. It's definetly not perfect but I believe this is a game that needs to be placed in a "try this game before you die" list. Writing this review... I suddenly have the urge to revisit Los Angeles. Rating 9/10.If you do plan on buying this game, I have to insist on getting the DLC for this game. It adds 5 great cases that slot seamlessly into the main story, as well as some new outfits and collectibles. I promise it's worth it.P.S. If you like these reviews and want to see more of the same, you're more than welcome to follow my curator page. If you don't like curators or groups, I completely understand (I'm not a big fan either). It's just a much easier way to find old and new reviews I've made: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/rblc#curation

												Review for L.A. NoirePros :- Awesome Playable Character- Strong Story- Amazing Face Animationscons :- 30FPS Lock on PC- Games looks outdated.Review : In L.A. Noire you play as Cole Phelps, War Veteran Who fought in the Second world war in The American army in Japan.After the war returned to Los Angeles he starts to work as a Cop, but after proving himself, he becomes a Detective...In the game your main goal is to solve cases as good and as truly as possible...in a City filled iwth Corruption and shady Characters...One of the things you will be doing alot in this game is Looking around, looking for clues.Interrogating people is also a big part of the game, Here is where the Face Animations play a big role...it can be really hard to see if someone is lying or telling the truth.Knowing this is a Rockstar game doesn’t mean its a shooting game or something like GTAyou're not allowed to just randomly kill people on the street or to carry a gun when you want.As a LAPD Detective your job is to protect the people of Los Angeles.There also isn't a Open world to this game, While doing mission you can have little sub mission in them,i noticed when i was driving to my next location some random event could happen on the streets, and its my choice to do something or just keep driving.this give it alot of replay value and just changed the passing abit.Overall I really enjoyed this game, and i clocked 21 hours in my first Play I also felt pretty sad and empty when the game ended.Hope L.A. Noire 2 is on its way.Release date : 20th of may 2011Developer : Team Bondi,  Rockstar North,  Rockstar San Diego,  Rockstar Leeds,  Rockstar New England,  Rockstar Lincoln.Publisher : Rockstar Games.Category : SingleplayerWebsite : http://www.rockstargames.com/lanoire/Platforms : Xbox360, Playstation 3, and Microsoft Windows.(Always do more research than just reading a review, to ensure that you get the right product.)[sorry for any grammatical errors]Follow my Curator page : http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6858371/

												This was revolutionary in gaming technology. Key word being WAS.I find myself having difficulty reviewing this game. It's such a mixed bag. In a nutshell, This game is fine. Just fine.The story follows you, a police officer played by aaron staton (More famously Ken Cosgrove from "Mad Men") as you solve cases in 40's Post war Los Angeles. Rockstar did well developing the enviroment. It does actually feel like i'm in a different period when I play this game. The story is solid, the characters are well written, and yes, the faces look legit. Thats pretty much the reason that I play the game.The game is on the other hand, a game made for consoles. The port is cancer.Good luck trying to boot it on windows 7. I had to jump through hoops just to get it playable. Oh by the way, there is a 30 fps cap. Read it agian. 30 FPS CAP. Even though you can disable it in the game files, the game really doesnt want you to. The reasoning behind this is that the facial animations were only RECORDED in 30 fps. you have the game running at 60 and the faces running at 30 and you get some weird graphical errors. Not to mention that on top of this the game is horrendously optimized. I mean cmon bondai. The game looks mediocre even for the gen it was made for, and you still can't make it run on older hardware.Anyhoo, Game is still fun enough to play because of the characters and actors. I'd reccomend it, but barely.

number of helpful: 269 of 409 people (66%) found this review helpful10 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												What a frustrating and disappointing game.The most basic flaw with the game is the poor and inconsistent logic that's used to govern interrogations, which is the game's primary mechanic and conceit.Interrogations work like this: you ask a witness or suspect about a topic, and he gives a response, at which point you have to choose between three options to characterize that reply -- Truth, Doubt, or Lie. If you choose Lie, you must select a piece of evidence that contradicts the interviewee's statement. A correct choice nets you experience and possibly a new clue or lead, while a failure may shut down the rest of the interrogation.The problem is that sometimes you will have evidence that suggests a person is lying, but the game expects you to choose Doubt instead. Other times, the game expects you to accuse the interviewee of lying in cases where you're not calling out a specific lie, or where the evidence that the game wants you to use to substantiate the accusation does not clearly contradict the interviewee's lie.Here is an example; I'll be a little vague and change some names and details so it shouldn't be too much of a spoiler:Towards the end of a case, I was in a room with a crook that we'll call Tony. In Tony's office I found some clues, including some forged documents that were noted as having come from a corrupt businessman that I'll call Levy, as well as hard evidence that Tony had leverage over Levy. Also worth noting is that I had interviewed Levy earlier, and Levy's records helped lead me to Tony's location.During my interview with Tony, my character asked for information about co-conspirators -- this is apparently so you can learn about Levy, in case the player has not already encountered him in the course of the investigation. Tony stonewalls, saying he acted alone. To me, the correct response to this would be to call him out on the lie, and cite either the forgeries (which had Levy's name on them), or the evidence that shows that Tony has leverage over Levy (though it's really both of these pieces of evidence COMBINED that make Tony's lie obvious). But no, the "correct" response is to Doubt, which gets Tony to give up Levy as co-conspirator.In the follow-up question to that, my character asked who Levy is and where I can find him. This was completely stupid as my character had already interviewed Levy and knew exactly where he was. The stupidity was then compounded when Tony claimed that Levy is one of the gangsters I shot dead on my way in to Tony's office. However, I couldn't think of any evidence I could cite that contradicts that lie ("the fact that I know Levy's face" is not a selectable piece of evidence in my notebook) so I selected Doubt. Wrong answer. Apparently, THIS is the spot where I was supposed to call him on the lie, by citing either of two pieces of evidence that did absolutely nothing to disprove Tony's claim that one of the dead gangsters is Levy.Those two pieces of evidence were a log in Levy's possession that showed that he sold the forged documents to Tony, and a scrap of paper that another detective gives you that basically just has Levy's address on it. I guess by the game's twisted logic, these two pieces of evidence each serve as a proxy for your own character's knowledge of Levy, because if you have the former evidence, or if you followed up on the latter evidence, you would know what Levy looks like. Instead that nonsense, why couldn't the game be scripted to simply check that I've encountered Levy and bypass the whole co-conspirators line of the interrogation, and just credit me with the rewards for having done the earlier legwork?It's because the game has a system, and even though that system isn't robust enough properly handle the situations that are written into the game, I guess they felt the need to stick to the system for the sake of consistency, even though the logic the system ITSELF uses is anything but consistent.The above situation also demonstrates how the game's writing can be a bit weak. What did Tony have to gain by saying Levy is one of the dead guys? He's making a false statement to a cop when he knows we already have enough evidence on him to convict, which is just going to add time to his sentence. He'd already given me Levy's name, and it would take a truly inept cop to not follow up on that and find Levy. He could be trying to protect Levy, but that doesn't make a lot of sense either -- the game makes it seem like Tony was just using Levy. At that point, Tony should've either stayed completely quiet, or he should've sold Levy out, without playing any more games. The self-incriminating middle ground approach that Tony takes is simply a contrivance to create one more piece of gameplay for the player to work through.This is just one case, but I experienced things similar to the above in basically all of the early cases. Too often you can have a solid understanding of the situation and the characters, but the mystery you face as a player does not lie in the details of the case -- but rather is figuring out what the game itself wants from you.The game also has some other issues. One annoyance is that you can drive from crime scene to crime scene, but as far as I can tell it's fairly pointless and boring. Either you end up driving around recklessly in GTA fashion (which doesn't make sense since you're playing the role of a notoriously straight-laced cop) or you sit at red lights and navigate city traffic with overly sensitive arcade-style controls. Fortunately, you can have your partner drive to your destinations for you.Another problem is that you can't directly review evidence you've collected after you've collected it. You do have access to a LIST of the evidence you've collected and a brief summary of it, but the summaries sometimes lack important info. I encountered one case where I acquired two separate pieces of evidence at different times -- both were documents that had a lot of information on them, but where it wasn't immediately apparent which details were important. You'd have to cross-reference them to draw a useful conclusion, but you CAN'T directly cross-reference them because the summary of each document that you have in your notebook doesn't include the pertinent info.Another thing worth noting is that this is a bad port. The aliasing (jaggies) are absolutely horrible, and the in-game AA feature seems to do absolutely nothing, even cranked up to 3X, which for some reason is the maximum. The frame rate is locked at 30 FPS (apparently due to the technology utilized in the facial animations -- a reasonable compromise would've been to have capped the frame rate during dialogue/cinematics, but uncap it elsewhere). Anistropic filtering is limited to 4X for no apparent reason. Screen tearing is rampant and there is no V-Sync option to address it. The game looks pretty bad, but would look fine if these technical features could be enabled and worked the way they are supposed to. It also seems to be poorly optimized -- I have a i5-2500k, GTX 670 and 8 GB of RAM, and at high/balanced settings, there was still some noticeable stutter.I haven't played deep enough into the game comment on the overarching story, but from what I have heard, it is also not one of the game's strong suits. I have since learned that there is a plot twist that I would've found infuriating if I had put more hours into the game.Overall, the game doesn't have any strong suits, other than the quality of the animation and performances during interrogation scenes, and there are some nice period touches that help capture that Noire feeling. But that alone isn't enough to make a game, in my opinion.I've tried a few times to get into this game. I want to like it, but I just can't. It's a shame. I hope someone takes another crack at this type of game though, and learns from L.A. Noire's mistakes.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
PresentationL.A. Noire has an excellent setting, Los Angeles in the 1940's, and everything the game has to offer feels very true to this setting.The story of the game is very well written, offering insight to life in the 1940's overall as well as focusing even more on the lives of cops, crooks, and war veterans.GraphicsL.A. Noire's graphics are excellent. Even though the game's a few years old by now, it still looks spectacular, and nothing in the game is boring to look at.All the animations look great and it's worth to note that there haven't been better facial animations in video games after this game.SoundFrom the sound effects to the songs and shows on the car radio as well as the music that's been carefully selected to feel right in different situations, everything in this game sounds just right.GameplayThere are gameplay elements that will instantly feel very familiar to those who've played any of Rockstar's games before. But there are also many unique features that this game has to offer.The game is divided into different cases during which the players are also able to focus on different side quests like dealing with street crimes and finding different cars and landmarks.Questioning the suspects and other people of the world is done very well. Although, I have to say that on a few occasions, I felt that the right choices were a bit surprising to say the least.NoteworthyMy playtime of 38 or so hours includes just one playthrough with all the DLC cases included. I also did over half of the street crime missions and unlocked more that a third of the vehicles the game had to offer.I did come across a few bugs during my playthrough, but they were mostly graphical stuff that disappeared fairly quickly. I also experienced some stuttering every now and again, and the game did freeze two or three times during the almost 40-hour long playthrough. However, I feel that these had little impact to how much I enjoyed the game itself.The game does require for the player to log in to a Rockstar Social Club account, but it is possible to choose a "Default" account for which the player doesn't have to provide any personal information and which requires no email verification or the like.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2013
												Essentially LA Confidential: The Video Game. The similarities between the two are remarkable, although I'm guessing most of the inspiration originates from the books the movie was based on. LA Noire is not without its problems, but if you approach it thinking it's more like an interactive movie than a video game, you'll probably enjoy it. It just oozes atmosphere and setting. The acting is really good, and due to the incredible facial animations it's not just voice acting that you're watching.  You'll probably recognize various actors from other roles they've played (mostly on TV). It's really like nothing else I've experienced in a video games. The problem is the gameplay. There's a few parts to it: finding clues, questioning/interrogating witnesses and suspects, and fighting/driving. Finding clues isn't all that bad, although it can get kind of tedious. Questioning people is the fun part, as you have to pay attention to character's facial expressions (that originate from the actual actor that played the part). The combat, however, is pretty bad. It's clunky, shallow, and repetitive. Fortunately, it's not a major part of the game, so it's bearable.Overall, if you want to enjoy gritty, noire detective stuff, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
"I can assure you I'm no war hero, detective."  ~Cole PhelpsL.A Noire is a highly underrated game, emerging from an unusual meeting between open world action game, point-and-click adventure and a 1940' or 50' film Noire.The game places us in the role of Cole Phelps, veteran of the sixth marines, former war-hero from Okinawa who, after coming back to L.A. in 1947, takes up a job in LAPD. Through the course of the game we assist Cole in solving various cases grouped into four desks - traffic, homicide, vice and arson.Each case is diferent, and may require different aproach, but the general tools we use over the course of the game remains the same - we need to gater as much relewant evidence as we can, and later, eventualy use them to prove our point during many witnes questioning parts of the game. To nawigate through this piling mountain of names, locations and objects we get a cool interface feature resembling LAPD detective notebook, that alows us to track case progress anytime we need to.The strongest point of the game is definitely it's plot, settled in an alomost perfectly recreated 40's L.A. Cole's tale, as he rapidly advances through LAPD desk offices and departments perfectly catches specyfic atmosphere of Noire movies from mentioned times, with all it's moral ambiguity and dillemas. Above that every single case tells a story of it's own, often re-telling some well known crime-stories like 'Black Daliah' case, or creating a longer plotline connecting some seemingly unrelated cases.I'd strongly recomment L.A. Noire to any fan of Noire movies, and good thriller or crime stories. The game itself is quite specyfic and to be frank, due to the nature of it, the replayability of this title is very low (what point in solving a case, if You already know the culprit ?), but nevertheless it's still worth playing !Pros:- Amazing storyline based on 40's and 50' film Noires.- Game with one of the most convincing characters in history of VG.- Engine simulating real facial expresions and body language.- Story set in almost perfectly recrated L.A. from around mid 40's.- more than 90 historicaly correct car models to drive !Cons:- Extremely low replayability (due to the nature of the game)- Huge amount of cinematic breaks and introductions slowing the pace of action.- Controls may feel somewhat curde

number of helpful: 25 of 26 people (96%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												DISCLAIMER: IF YOU WISH TO PLAY ON 60FPS, USE WIDESCREENFIXER SINCE THIS GAME IS LOCKED IN 30FPS. FOR FOV, USE FLAWLESS WIDESCREEN AND PRESS EITHER + OR - TO CHANGE THE VIEW. THE PORT FOR THIS GAME ISN'T REALLY THAT GOOD BUT THE GAME ITSELF IS. LA Noire is an open world detective game set in the 1940s after WWII. You play as a Cole Phelps, a marine turned police officer then detective. You solve cases from traffic to homicide to vice and then arson. PORTThis game was ported by Rockstar Seeds who were known for porting other pc games either developed or published by Rockstar such as GTA 4. Team Bondi developed this game for Xbox 360 and Ps3 and a year later, Rockstar Seeds brought it to PC. Like GTA 4, LA Noire isn't really that a good a port, maybe worst if you ask me. There's no mod support so there's nothing anybody can do fix the issues this game has. The PC controls aren't that well so you need a controller. The framerate is capped at 30fps, unless you use the tool I mentioned above, it's easy to use. However some of the physics in the game will be messed up when playing at 60fps, there are videos on Youtube that shows it. But just cap it back to 30fps for a minute and you'll be fine. Also there are plenty of texture pop-ins everywhere you look especially driving. It's obvious how much they truly cared from this console port.GRAPHICSAs stated there are a ton of texture and assets popping up in the screen but you can handle after a little while. The amount of detail in this game is amazing. As a guy who lives in Los Angeles, I actually recognized a lot of buildings in the game, the amount of work put into the interior, and exterior design of the city is beautiful. As you may know, this game utilizes what's called MotionScan, where the developers used 32 high definition cameras to capture actors faces. While it looks great, less attention I believed was put into the bodies since it was done separately. STORYYou start as a cop, then rise to becoming a detective. The story is told by the cases you solve, however the actual story to the game does start later near the end when you're in vice. You can pick up the pieces to the story by picking up newspapers as you're doing the earlier cases. The dialogue in this game is well written but there were some times when I felt that the actors where overdoing it. Above all, the story is really good and dark since that's what you would expect from the noire type of entertainment. GAMEPLAYRockstar may have published this game but it doesn't mean you blast gas stations up with a rocket launcher. To simply put, the gameplay is extremely limiting. You can browse the open world detail of LA Noire but there isn't much to do in this game when not doing the cases. There are mini side quests where help people out but they're really short (Lasts about 1-3 minutes). Interrogation in this game consists of asking a question and wondering if that person's telling a truth or lieing and expose them with evidence, or doubt them if you don't believe them. Like other Rockstar games, there are gunplay but in my honest opinion the gunplay in this game feels like an arcade game. It's not the same as GTA or Red Dead Redemption's gunplay which I think is amazing (Rockstar please bring to PC).CONCLUSIONI believe you will enjoy this game especially when getting the Complete Edition which has every case the game has to offer. I know I haven't said much about your character Cole Phelps but to honest he has no personality at all. You don't know much about him in a personal level. 1.) Port isn't that good (30fps lock)2.) Environment is really well detailed and amazing3,) Don't know much about the character you play as.If on sale, get this game and have fun, it's a long game.

 L.A Noire Review Information Game - L.A Noire Publisher - Rockstar Games Developer - Team Bondi Release Date - 17th May 2011 Genre - Action/Adventure Trading Cards - None Achievements - yes(60)When i first saw this game at the store i wondered wether it's gonna be worth it,Rockstar games famous for making games like GTA,Manhunt and Red Dead Redemption gonna make a cop game!? It was a change from their usual games and quite a brave move.I thought this was gonna be a game nobody would remember,but boy was i wrong...   Categories Details   Story In LAN you play as an LAPD cop and later detective named Cole Phelps a former war hero in WW II. LAN is set in the Los Angeles of 1947 which has been created beautifully.In the game you start up as a cop and later get promoted due to your notable breakthroughs.At first it seem LAN has no story and it's just random cases which you have solve but later on as you proceed you unravel a story of army surplus Morphine racketeering and land bussiness scam which has Cole personally involved as his former army freinds are being murdered.It also features many sub-plots and also shows past incidents of Cole's life in the army which forms a major part of the  plot. The game's story is very well told,the way each case in the later part of the game coincides with the plot revolving around the protagonist is wonderful.The cases which are not related to the main plot are very well told as well and most of them are inspired from real life crimes which kinda gives you creeps when you play the missions featuring gruesome murders.The voice acting and facial acting is very well done as well. Yes i said facial acting. Team Bondi has used some technology using multiple cameras and used the real expressions of the actors in the game which along with good voice acting adds to the atmosphere. When the characters talk you feel like they are real people.It is one great feature of L.A Noire. SCORE: 9/10    Gameplay The gameplay of LAN is simply unique.The gamplay ranges from gun fights,melee fights,foot chase,car chase,tailing missions(both in car and foot),driving cars,puzzle solving(riddles and stuff)investigating clues,interrogation.You play the game as a cop and paly through various departments. You start the game as a patrol man then get promoted to be a detective at the traffic department,then to homicide then vice and finally arson.The best missions are the one in homicide and vice.The game's uniqueness lies in it's clue finding and interrogation.In the interrogation you question your witness and when you are answered by the suspect, you must determine wether he/she is telling the truth or lying. You are given three options in this mater, 1st option is truth which you select if you think the suspect is telling the truth,2nd option is doubt which you choose when you think your suspect is lying but don't have any proof and the 3rd is lying when you think your suspect is lying and you have proof to back up your charge.You may wonder how to determine wether your suspect is lying or not well it's by studying the expression of the suspect.As I told you earlier the technology used in this game is unique and the real expression of the actors are used. When people lie they make all sorts of silly expression(susupicious) and when telling the truth they look straight faced.If you accuse a person the of lying make sure you have got proof and from the clues listed in your notebook you have to choose the correct ones as selecting the wrong one will get that question wrong.Though making mistakes won't totally fail the case but getting less than half the questions on the case right fails the mission.Passing the missions is not the only aim,you are even rated from between 1-5 stars,the more stars you get the more salary you earn.Detucting these truth-lie mechanisms are sometimes easy and sometimes hard.You have to stay attentive in order to get the correct clues to branch to the questions. Wether they ae lying or not is mostly easy as while lying the actors make silly suspicious faces,selecting the real clue is a challenge.As this is a cop game you cannot always carry around your gun on the streets and use it,they can only be used during gun fights.Driving mechs are simillar to that of the GTA games and you can take any car on the street and drive it,only this time you don't punch people on the face but show off your batch take the car saying you need it for upholding justice.Driving is pretty easy but don't expect to see Lambourghinis as this is set in the 40's.The game has side missions in the form of street crimes that is crimes that have sprung up immediately and the crime is still in the act where you have to respond quick,it can be chasing the criminals or fighting them.The puzzles and riddles are very well done as well, most of them really challenge your brain while some are very easy.Open world is not directly in the main game(as u r actually solving a case at the beginning of all cases) but from the menu you can select the free world mode and play it but there is nothing of much interest.Crashing cars and damaging properties will affect you rating and minus your salary(though they are of no use in the game).Killing people while driving be penalised as you fail the mission in doing so. Though it has got some unique feature palying LAN at a stretch might get boring. SCORE: 9/10     Graphics The graphics of LAN are mordern considering the date of release of the game(2011) and are sweet to the eyes even now(2015).This graphics quality along with the facial feature technology used in this game for the first time in video gaming history is awesome. The city of Los Angeles of 1940's looks beautiful and is realistic(even features racialy biased cops),It really feels like your are in the LA of 1947. SCORE: 9/10 L.A Noire is a great game for all lovers of adventure and action and suspense story and noire theme lovers and every gamer(until you r a hard core COD fan who feels that COD deserves GOTY).The game is really well done and is worth every penny.Also get the DLC bundle of this game(which i had,and it gives you extra missions).Playing LAN made me feel like a real detective.Go get it,it's a must have in your library.  Overall:9/10 If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page [ http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												LA Noire is a rather interesting title. It's a Rockstar game but it was developed by an Australian developer named Team Bondi. Why this is relevant is many of the developers from Team Bondi made an eerily similar game called The Getaway which also focused on cinematic action.LA Noire is unlike the Grand Theft Auto games it gets compared to. A big focus of the game is it's cinematics and it's interrogation mechanic. Where the player is required to tell if a character is lying or not. While I would say it was implemented fairly well, unfortunately the developers confuse you every so often with the range of options. Sometime a suspect isn't lying but rather just not telling enough information. And instead of selecting lie you're supposed to select "doubt". Thankfully the developers also implemented a lifeline style mechanic where you can ask the community what the most commonly selected responses are.While I would say LA Noire was an excellent game unfortunately it was an imperfect one. The game starts out exceptionally well and the quality of the writing stays consistant until the middle. After the homicide desk the writing begins to get worse and worse, to the point when you get to the ending you begin laughing at how ludicrous the entire thing is. I wouldn't say the experience isn't worthwhile but don't go into this expecting it to be Red Dead Redemption levels of satisfaction.It's unsurprising to find out this game had two entire desks cut (of which 4 remain in the final release) considering the storyline remains just a little half baked. It's unfortunate to see with such an ambitious game, but since it was in development for 8 years it's surprising that it came out at all.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												Many have complained that the game wont start. The soultion is to, turn off  "Beta testing" option in Steam and the game will work again. The other problem people might have is 30 fps, this can be fixed by using the "wide screen" option in desktop/ graphics option prior to the game menu.  This is a flawed masterpiece and one of my absolute favourites along with GTA, Max Payne and Mafia 2.L.A. Noire's absorbing investigations and intoxicating sense of Noir style make it an unforgettable journey through the seamy side of the City of Angels.L.A. still had streetcars in 1947, but it was a city quickly becoming dominated by the automobile, and that's the only way to travel in L.A. Noire. Thankfully, driving is fun. The gunplay is very easy to pick up. You can hide behind cover, and pop out to squeeze off shots. L.A. Noire isn't all about badgering people, though. This is still an open-world game. You're free to deviate from a case, explore faithfully recreated 1947 Los Angeles, and tackle more action-oriented missions. No, you can't run wild like in Grand Theft Auto (you're a cop, accept it), but there are some other things to do. Forty "unassigned cases" come in as calls on the radio.Gunfights, foot chases, car chases, and the occasional simple brawl don't just spring up during cases. They're also a regular part of the street crimes that are reported over the radio, which you can choose to respond to or ignore. The voice acting is good and the visual face effect when someone is tense after telling a lie, is brilliant made. The  game has car chases, gunfights, and a point-tally to judge the quality of your police justice, but it's a slow-paced, meditative experience. The focus isn't on how good you are at scoring headshots with a pistol but instead your ability to read a suspect's face and determine if he or she is telling the truth, holding something back, or flat out lying.I felt that even if the  game had  21 cases, some of which can take more than an hour to complete, L.A. Noire drags at times because it recycles the same drama and you cant help feeling a sense of Deja Vu. There's an omniscient narrator in the early missions of L.A. Noire who disappears halfway through and never returns. I also felt that Phelt story was forcefully told and often too hasty and in bits so you never get the whole picture about his personality or his past.

number of helpful: 20 of 22 people (91%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												L.A. Noire is about a detective named Cole Phelps that worked in post-WW2 late 1940s Los Angeles. Gameplay is open world and consists entirely of interviewing/interrogating people, chasing suspects with cars/on foot, shootouts with criminals, and walking around crime scenes or area of interest to find clues and evidence. This is a pretty unique game since it's made by Rockstar, which is well-known as the creator of GTA. You get to be the good guy this time, including chasing & ramming cars that will be ended with you busting the suspect GTA-Style (remember Busted scene in GTA? you're the cop here).  Even with obvious low-budget graphics, the story was very well made and the characters expressions (face and voice) are EXTREMELY 'alive' compared to other games. This is because you get to judge whether someone is lying or not by facial expression/voice tone. Ah, if you're a classic car lover, this game paid a lot of attention to them. In short, L.A. Noire is a very out-of-the-box interesting detective game that is definitely worth the price.Now let's talk about the good things first. I'm no policeman and I have no experience in any police work, but I dare to say that with a huge amount of available cases and side missions, the game will definitely satisfy your thirst of 'problem solving' or 'mystery' or straight out 'detective work'. I definitely can't say it's realistic (apparently, shooting someone in the leg made fatal chest wounds) but it's...well-designed. The cases are all realistic with carefully designed motives and chain of events. You'll find the thrill of being in a crime scene looking for clues like footprints, shoe sizes, blood traces, injury marks, and other 'detective stuff'. You also get to judge whether someone is telling the truth or lying by looking into their faces and voice tone. Facial expression is carefully designed to show real-life 'lying' or 'truth' or 'holding out' expression (e.g. eyes looking left when lying). Bored of the same routine? Whenever you're driving, you'll receive dispatch calls that will give you side-missions. So yeah, the main advantage of this game is its well-designed gameplay.The bad parts of the game is really not that much and does not affect the gameplay. Graphics looks very low-budget, it's as if they put all of the graphics money into character's facial expression realism. But in my opinion, it's still in the acceptable level. The weapon choice is also very limited, only Colt 45, Thompson, M1 Garand, and BAR. Since the game is not focused on the gun fights, this issue has miniscule effect.  And as a good guy, you don't get to do the legendary GTA reckless driving. You don't have to follow traffic rules and all but you can't run over pedestrians or ram cars that cut you off if you don't  want your case report to be ruined. Some of the cases are also pretty complicated, giving you a long list of person of interest and clues. This particular mission gave me the 'What am I doing? Who the heck is this guy? Whoa, now who are you? What's their connection to the case?' moment. But that's the fun part, right?In conclusion, the gameplay is very unique and I don't think there are many open-world detective games out there. This advantage makes this game a 'must-play' for me and it's worth every cent. I spent over 13 hours and I'm not even a quarter finished of the whole game. The cons of the game is almost meaningless and it will not ruin the gameplay. I definitely recommend this game, it's worth it.

It's one of my favorite game among of any other games I owned and still replayable until now. So the storyline sets in 40's, this game made by Rockstar but you didn't expecting to be a gangster or a criminal just like any other Rockstar games but instead you became a police officer all the way to a detective in Los Angeles and your task is to protect the city by.... you know, solving crimes and stuff. For investigating the crime scene, you can find some clues around the place like blood, weird paycheck or any other interesting things for you to show some evidence to anyone you're going to interrogate. The game has very intensed motion capture to show the emotion of certain victim, suspect or anyone you're questioning whether you see his/her face like♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off or really sad and its up to you to confirm if they're lying or said the truth. Graphics are good too for a game that releases in 2011 and you can see some tiny details popping out from the map. Talking about the map, its not really that 'open world' just like GTA series but there are some random activities you can do like chasing a criminal while you're on free time or collecting some vintage car somewhere around the map to keep you hooked up. Oh you can also change the game colour into black and white if you prefer the 50s Noir Movie-ish. So thats really about it and why not you pick this game up if you feel like to become a detective and want to play something different than the other. But I recommend for you to pick this game up on sale but hey thats just my opinion. Also I'll give it 8.7/10 :)

"SHUT YOUR FU*KING MOUTH. SINCE WHEN DOES A BAG MAN WORK A CASE?"It's been almost a year since I wrote something up here. But well, everybody is at some point back, where he started, so I figure it out, why just don't write up the review for a game, which is in my personal TOP 10. Right?When I look back, and check all the products, that Rockstar Games has put out, I'm not even sure if I'm able to name at least one, which was average or even under that. They even made a fantastic movies, didn't they?When they try to make open world game, it's understandable that comparision with Grand Theft Auto is not anything bad.  Red Dead Redemption v. GTA. / Bully v. GTA. / The Warriors v. GTA (My lord, The Warriors are even better than GTA in some way) / and also Midnight Club for some reason. And there comes the L.A. Noire. New genre that R* step a foot in, and got out as a king again and again and again. L.A. Noire is as you of course know the detective game set in 40s Los Angeles. You can compare this to Sherlock Holmes games, and Cole Phelps will be still better detective. Story is so gripping that one case might drives you crazy, and then you realize that Rockstar is just master of art in the gaming world.There is one thing, that I also realized during the exploration of LA which is really huge and more realistic than GTA V would ever be. However, the developer itself pretty doesn't give a flying f*ck if people discover beautifulness inside. I am talking about hidden spots and interesting places all over the Los Angeles. It's pretty usual that some devs puts spots out to player to see them. R* is not doing that way. They put tons of spots, and hide them even more than usually. This game is filled with landmarks, and especially golden film reels which are pretty difficult to spot. Thing is, that even after discovering 30 of various world-famous places and 50 hidden golden films, you can go further, explore on your own, and discover spots that wasn't made for casual player, but for true explorer. I've been to LA this year, and I must say, that a lot of places that are shown in this game, looks practically same (not just landmarks, also the standard streets at some point) no matter the time game is set was more than 70 years ago. I've talked a lot about the town, but I have to be honest with you, but town is most enjoyable thing for me personally in the game. More than the characters, more than Cole and more than the story and cases. More than 20 cases ready for you (which lenght of the one might be easily above 40 mins) 40 side street crimes, and enormous spots to discover for you. Great thing was, that besides the main story line, there was a lot of different stories going all way along and meet each other in the end.I've got to tell you much more, but I will leave it. I don't want this review to be another Saints Row 3 review of mine :XBonus Point: AtmosphereRating: 10/10

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Well, there has been some time since I've played a game this intriguing. L.A. Noire is more like a classical 'noir' movie rather than a computer game, and you get to play the star of the movie! The storyline centers a young, promising police officer -later detective- named Cole Phelps in 1940s Los Angeles. His tale has everything: crime, murder, trauma, love, politics, justice, conflict of interest and ethics... mostly conflict everywhere.The atmosphere is magnificent, graphics are more than satisfying and story builds around many twists and turns, always keeping you wondering about what might come next. The investigation process is well displayed, heavily depending on observation, whether it be a mimic of a suspect, or a tone in the witness' voice. The environment is wast and it is possible to get lost if you're not following the map indicators. You carry the full option of roaming the streets of L.A. to hunt for all kinds of achievements, and even venture out to solve trivial street crimes. I once again agreed that Rockstar never abstains from investing in environment design.Controls of the game is a bit hard to master in PC though, I think this game is better suited for PS or Xbox in that manner. Vehicles are impossibly hard to control - at least for me, but my reflexes were never that great so I'm not the one to have a final call on that -  and that would be the sole minus for me that I've observed so far. I found myself preferring my partner to drive rather than myself, and that's a bit disappointing. Oh, well: I'm not in for the perfection anyhow.I recommend it with CAPITAL CHARACTERS; for the story, graphics and display altogether.

number of helpful: 18 of 20 people (90%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												This is the best detective game on Steam at the moment. You play as Cole Phelps, a veteran who went into police work in order to keep serving his country and dispense justice. As you play, you say to hell with procedure and take the initiative to solve the crimes the lazy detectives are glossing over. This gets you promoted to become a full-time detective, and you make your way up the hierarchy of crime investigators.I'm not gonna bother dividing these things into pros and cons. If you need a detective game in your life, buy it. If you don't, read this review and buy it.GAMEPLAY:You're not buying the game for this:- This is a third person open world game, yet it has nearly nothing to find or do in terms of free roaming. Between missions you may accept a street crime side mission, but they often boil down into a chase, a car chase or a shoot-out, all of which probably won't get your blood pumping. Do yourself a favour and just follow the story; it's pretty long.- The combat is boring and generic. The weapons bear no real feeling of impact and you can take a lot more bullets than the bad guys. Melee combat is practically unexistant. The combat is merely a way of prolonging the game and supplement the story.- No reward or change if you decide to go for a non-lethal arrest.- The driving is nothing spectacular. It's far less enjoyable than in most Rockstar games in that it's pretty slow and car chases force you into just trying to keep the driver in sight until the game decides that he's arrived at his final destination. Occasionally you will be able to have your partner shoot out the suspect's tires, which feels alright, but you won't be aiming.- Interrogation is a pretty fun mechanic which is probably what this game is known for. You have to read the suspect/victim's facial expressions and pick up on uncertainty or curious claims, then decide if they're lying or telling the truth and reveal more info/clues if you answer correctly. Sometimes you'll be dealing with good liars that the game won't tell you about, who tell you their side of the story very rigidly and confidently, but without the facts adding up. This is to make sure you know have an overview of the case and it's a very nice touch.- Facial features and animations are great, since a fairly thorough facial motion capture method was used for every character and gels very well with the story. As a result, every character in the game looks like the person who performed the voice.- The game is locked to 30 FPS for the facial motion capture to work.STORY:The reason this game is nothing short of phenomenal:- Between cases, you will sometimes get a clip that goes back to Cole's participation in the war in Japan after the attack on Pearl Harbour. From the very beginning of the game, you'll be seeing these clips/flashbacks and they will play into the story as you progress. The way the game creates parallel story lines that eventually cross into eachother is absolutely fantastic.- The cases are often connected to eachother in some way; I can't say much without spoiling it. - They're also fairly devoid of plot holes and create a comprehensive and complete experience.- The job eventually expands into your personal life, even though it initially doesn't seem like you even have one.- Characters from the story occassionally appear in the side missions (street) crimes, which is a nice touch but it won't mean or matter much.- The atmosphere is extremely immersive and convincing; when you launch this game, you turn into L.A.'s top detective in a realistic city based on real places with real landmarks. The music amplifies the detective noir vibe and is probably the final aspect that gets you into the role.Every character wears clothes and sets their hair in a way that is true to the time period as well.- The voice acting is absolutely beautiful and convincing in every aspect. Team Bondi really scratched together some very talented people.L.A. Noire does what is does very well, and as long as you're willing to look past the FPS cap and just follow the main story line, you will be an experience richer.The interrogation mechanic might get dull after a while; for this I recommend you consider what you'd answer in a situation and then look up the correct answer in a guide to keep you trekking along.

												The Maltese Falcon, The Big Sleep, The Big Combo. Why am I mentioning these movies? Because this game is a movie. The name is L.A. Noire. It takes a lot from the style of film noire of the 1940s. With that being said you're in for one hell of game. Absolutely fantastic story and characters; combined with a beautiful map and fun gameplay. It's a very unique game in my opinion; there aren't many like it. I stretched the game out for a long time (almost 6 or 7 months) so when I finished it was almost like I had binge watched a tv show on netflix and it was coming to a close. One of the few games that actually made me emotional at the end. I highly recommend it to anyone who's considering it. The game is usually very cheap during $ales and the game is rather lengthy so it's a steal. WHERE'S MY SEQUEL?!

number of helpful: 14 of 14 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												Finally a game where you play as a cop! And not some traffic warden but a Los Angeles detective Cole Phelps.The investigation process is the second best part of the game, after the story (see below). The search for clues will make you really punctilious and bring deep insight into all cases. The interogation is even better with the best game facial animation I have ever seen making some characters an obvious liars whereas others might seem honest. What kind of police officer would you be without chasing criminals? This takes me to the third part of police work and that are the gunfights and chases on foot or in cars. These elements aren't the main plus of the game since it's not a shooter of any kind - if you want to buy the game for the action only, don't. However, though these are weaker than in Mafia II for example, they are a nice contrast to the peaceful investigation and they balance the neat investigating with some action, which is important for you not to get bored from finding clues only.Apart from the extraordinary facial animation the graphics is about average. The city of LA is really big and contains lot of hidden secrets, such as cars, sights etc. for completionist gamers. Though the city really is wonderful, it doesn't feel as lively as it might be. Apart from the cases and street crimes, there isn't much to watch. But that isn't much of a drawback - not many games have that (maybe the Watch Dogs will).Finally, the story. There's a lot to spoil so I'll take this just briefly. It focuses on many things and mentions lot of important topics, which make it really strong. As set in the year 1947, it connects the horrors of war and Cole Phelps' military history with the police investigations and lot of other topics, you'll encounter in the streets of LA such as drugs, racism, prostitution, rapes and lot more. I enjoyed the last Arson desk a whole damn lot because it shows nobody is plain black or white, evil or good. Some characters are antagonists, though you feel the morale in their acting, others have it the other way round. It also shows how thin line lies between good and bad, between friends and enemies.To sum up - this game promises something quite different from others as you'll be playing at the right side of the law meaning lots of new aspects and a fantastic story. The weakest thing I can think of is that you cant skip the ending credits :)9/10

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												L.A. Noire is a beautiful tale of the grime that lurks just below the surface.GAMEPLAY:     There are 4 main types of gameplay at work here the first is investigation, the second is interrogation, the third is car chases, and the fourth is gunfights. The first and second forms mentioned make up the meat of the game with 90% of the game consisting solely of walking around, picking things up, and talking to people. The gunplay and driving could both be improved, but they both occur so infrequently and can be skipped that it is hardly considered a real negative. The biggest issue I have with the gameplay is the "Truth, Doubt, Lie" function. The majority of the time you'll be going out on a whim if you doubt or lie. The best you can do is choose lie first to see where Cole takes it, and if you didn't mean to head that direction choose doubt instead. Also a lot of the time what you need to present for lie will be a toss up for 2 items and the one you choose probably won't be it even though it could work. The fact is though I can't think of any way to solve the issues it has.STORY:     This is what the game is about. I don't want to spoil anything about the story, but just remember to never take a single thing you hear at face value not even the character you play. The set up is you play as Cole Phelps a war hero turned LAPD detective in the mid-late 40's. One of the best qualities of this game is the writing of all of the characters. Every single aspect of the characters was clearly taken and cared for to be formed into one of the best experiences that can be given to anyone who is willing to look one step deeper.SOUND:    Limited repeated tracks with hit-or-miss voice recordings (some people sound like they were recorded in a cardboard box while standing in the middle of the street) leave much to be desired.Cons:*30 FPS locked*Lots of random stutter*Large wonderful but shallow overwold.OVERALL:If Phoenix Wright had an affair with the 40's this game would be what pops out. And I loves meself some Phoenix Wright. L.A. Noire deserves to be on the forefront of anyone's "to-play" list if you have a marginal interest in Noire or love a good  story.

It's a lot like the Dark Souls PC port, which is also terrible. And like that game, it's highly rated. These games are TERRIBLE on PC, yet have glaring ratings. This is why you shouldn't trust Metacritic with console ports. Everyone is over rating these because the console version is good... that's nice and all... except that we're talking about the PC version here, in the PC section, and on Steam. You can also read plenty of reports about crashes or freezes(from people that have actually played it).If you want this, get it on a console. Do not get it on PC. The PC version is absolutely terrible, and most of the reviews(even in the PC section of Metacritic) are praising it because of the console version, aka, idiots that'll probably never even try the version they are giving positive ratings to. Rockstar is another company that cares very little about the PC players, usually just shovelware porting their console games onto the platform. Btw, it also has Rockstar Studios attached to it, even on the Steam version.

number of helpful: 13 of 13 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												PROS+Collecting evidence, examinating corpses and locations and interrogating suspects (or just witnesses) is usually interesting and nice to do, though it does have its flaws (more on that later).+Dialogues are excellently written and acted, watching the plot unwrap or just listening to Phelps and his partner's chatter is always interesting. Helped by the great and highly advertised facial mocap, which still holds its own years later.+The atmosphere is gorgeous, I don't think i've ever seen a more faithful videogame representation of the noir genre and the post-WWII America in general.+Most cases are well written and don't have an obvious solution or an easily guessable culprit. Often, it's not easy to find the evidence to nail him/her and then actually use it in an interrogation to call him/her out on his/her bullcrap, so unless the somewhat slow pace of the game doesn't bother you, you'll rarely get bored.+The overarching plot of the game is interesting too, and you'll be surprised by how many things mentioned or seen early in the game make a lot more sense later.CONS-Some cases are clearly below standard, mostly padding material: they're either short, bland or both, and they'll feel pretty "meh".-Free roaming is an option, but it's pretty much just there for the sake of it: apart from some Guide Dang It level collectibles, there is hardly any reason to wander around L.A. if not to enjoy the scenery.-Finding clues can sometimes get tedious, mostly because sometimes some interactable, often important objects are way off course: yeah, i don't want everything blatantly slammed in my face or the game would be too easy, but certain pieces of evidence are in really obscure locations, and usually they're crucial for correctly accusing a suspect or lampshading a lie. Keep the "clue music" on, it's nice and it'll help you understand wether you're done or there's an improbable object hidden 60 feet away from the main crime scene.-The PC porting of this game leaves much to be desired: settings are minimal, graphic quality, apart from the higher resolution, isn't better than the console version (buildings were quite basic and low-detail even when the game first came out) and the frame-rate is locked at 30 fps due to the peculiar technology used to mocap the characters' faces not allowing higher values.-Driving and shooting are meh. They're there, some chases and shootouts can help spice things up in an otherwise still good adventure game, but they were clearly not the focus of the development team. They're not bad, simply blandly average.SUMMARYBuy this game if you love its awesome noir atmosphere and you've always wanted to literally be in books like The Black Dahlia, or just because it's a solid adventure game with top notch acting, good longevity and, unfortunately, not a lot of replay value (though if you screw up your investigations you'll probably want to do them again for those shiny 5 stars). Avoid it if you were looking for an action game with deep shooter mechanics or, worse, for a 1940s GTA. This is not that game.
