number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Story - I should start off this review by saying I am totally biased in favor of this game and it is my favorite game in my library at the time of writing.  I love the setting of the 1940's and especially the noir and detective aspects.  This game is the closest you will get to playing L.A. Confidential: The Video Game.  I found the story and even the individual cases to be very engrossing and they feel like actual crimes that could have been committed.  I love a video game with a great story above all else and this one totally delivers on that.  All of the characters feel very real and have more depth than in other Rockstar games.  Cole Phelps, the protagonist, at first seems like a squeaky clean detective, but as the story goes on, that changes and you become very engrossed in him as a character.  When you add a deep and perplexing murder myster to that, I was hooked.  There are even real historical characters (gangsters like Bugsy Siegel) in the game and scientology makes an appearance (in an interesting way) too.Gameplay - You assume the role of Detective Cole Phelps and investigate crimes, interrogate suspects, tail suspects, and sometimes get in shoot outs and fist fights.  I really like the way L.A. Noire handles investigations.  You have to find clues at the crime scenes by picking up and examining objects.  When you find suspects, you can interview them and respond in three ways (truth, doubt, or lying) depending on what they say.  This is probably the most challenging part of the game because unless you're very good, it can be hard to know whether to doubt or call the suspect a liar.  You can and will arrest the wrong person if you get too many questions wrong or don't find all the evidence.  Fortunately, there are plenty of guides out there to help you if you are worried about getting it wrong.  In total, the game has somewhere between 20-30 cases and it took me around 30 hours to get through them all.  I never got tired of playing L.A. Noire and would have played many more cases if I could.A lot of the other game play is really similar to Grand Theft Auto.  Driving is arcadey in a good way and shooting is cover based and pretty fun too.  While you spend more time investigating in missions than doing shooting and car chases, the game also offers street crimes which are often foot or car chases with a shoot out or a fist fight thrown in.  These aren't necessary to beat the game but they are fun and were a nice addition.  Presentation (Graphics and Sound) - The graphics in L.A. Noire are both dated and incredibly impressive at the same time.  I'm pretty sure this game uses a version of the Grand Theft Auto 4 engine and while the graphics are solid, they do look like a PS3 game and if you have a good gaming pc, you can certainly find games that look better.  What makes this game great though is the acting and animation of the characters.  L.A. Noire uses a newer animation system that captured the way the voice actors looked and acted when delivering the lines.  This makes it possible to see when someone is lying and it also makes the characters look really distinct and believable.  I hope we'll see more games use this technology in the future.  In addition, the makers of this game put an incredible amount of detail into replicating the Los Angeles of the 1940's.  The city looks and feels real.  There is so much detail and nothing feels recycled when you drive around. The sound is excellent from the voice acting to the authentic music on your car radio when you drive around.  I love the theme song for this game and think it sets the mood for the game better than almost any other I've seen.  Overall - As I said at the beginning, I truly love this game.  From the story to the realism to the satisfying game play, I think L.A. Noire has it all.  If you don't care about these things, especially a great story then it is very possible you will like this game a lot less than I do or lose interest in it before beating it.  I've certainly heard people say that they felt this way and I think this is just one of those games that some people will really love and others will just find to be pretty good.  However, if my review sounds appealing to you, this game is one of Rockstar's best and that is really saying something.As far as achievements go, this game is very easy to get a high percentage on by playing through the game once and trying to grab achievements as you go.  You will want to find a good guide for getting five stars on every case and for making sure to use all the weapons in the game or you will have to repeat parts of the game.  The one that kept me from trying to get them all is an achievement that makes you drive every car in the game.  There isn't an easy to find all of these cars and you almost need some luck to get them all.  That one is a bit of a bummer but I would still say that compared to other games, L.A. Noire has more reasonable achievements, especially if you can live with getting 90% or so of them.9.5 (out of 10)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												For all it's flaws, I loved L.A. Noire.The port, first off, is woeful. After you've contended with Rockstar Social Club updating and generally being a nuisance, the fight is getting the game looking pretty while keeping the framerate consistent. I played the whole thing through at the locked-in 30fps, and had a fine time.For it's time, this is a beautiful, innovative game. The facial models make characters readable and relatable, and the generally minimalist nature of the game - few HUD features popping in or out, heavy reliance on sound rather than visual signposting - allows the game to unfold like a dense TV series rather than a videogame. The atmosphere is exceptional, and period music and vehicles only add to that.The story is good, although it wanes towards the end. The same goes for the gameplay - it is fun, unique, and rewarding, but also blows its wad off the bat: by the endgame, you're doing the same things you were at the very start.Even still, a fantastic single-player experience.

content:
Posted: April 23
												Set in the 1950s Los Angeles and in the aftermath of World War II, Team Bondi conceived an amazing game that balances between cinematography and mystery-solving. This game require intuition and patience as the gameplay focuses mainly on collecting clues & evidences and judging suspect’s statements.The storyline mainly focuses on Cole Phelps, a dishonored World War II veteran and an ambitious yet intuitive LAPD detective. Cole Phelps started as a simple patrolman, but with time, he showed initiative and solved his first murder case, and gained his Captain’s attention. Not long, he got promoted to the Traffic Desk solving more cases, and cases after cases he is now a member of the infamous Vice squad.You will also briefly follow the footsteps of Jack Kelso, Phelps' old friend and arson investigator. Near the end of the game, you will be contacted and hired to investigate a house fire, but along the way, you will uncover the dark intentions of a certain building contractor, and offered a new job as the DA's investigator.The gameplay is based on "Cases", but most people would call them "Missions". Here, you will be taken to Cole Phelps' consciousness and try to solve said cases with your partner. You will start in the briefing room, the Captain will give you a new case, and you will have to drive to the crime scene, search for clues, question or interrogate suspects and witnesses, fight and occasionaly kill uncooperative suspects, and calling R&I. Your standard issue notebook contains all informations regarding to the case, and Detective Phelps will write down new clues and persons of interest. Each actions will result in a different outcome of the case (You arrested the wrong person, the true suspect escaped, etc.) but said outcomes will result only but slightly to the next case dialogue, unfortunately.The action sequences include on-foot pursuits, vehicle pursuits, fist-fights, and shootouts. Amidst the cases, you can respond to street crimes. (robbery, shootouts, etc.) The interrogation sequence is unique. When intercepted with a dispute, you will be given three options, which is Truth, Doubt, and Lie. The first two options are pretty self-explanatory, but the third option, to prove that someone is lying, you must present adequate evidence regarding his/her statement. You can also judge the P.O.I's statement by carefully watching their facial cues. (Some suspects are far more resilient than others though).If you have completed a "Desk" or even all cases available, and if you are bored, you can select "The Streets Of L.A." which is a free-roam mode for you to collect gold film reels, collect cars, respond to street crimes, or just simply sightseeing.The storyline also features flashbacks of Cole's war-time adventures, and these flashbacks will cross paths with the main storyline and the ending would place the final piece of the puzzle.An amazing game of its time.Ten out of ten.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												A masterpiece falling short.Had a long think about this review. The technology is nothing short of breathtaking and well worth it as a tour de force of what great tech can add to a game.The gameplay feature of reading the charactors tells is, i think, a great inovation and also, a difficult whip to crack. It can feel a little lopsided as some of the acting i over egged and thus paints the conversion as somewhat bipolar. Although this could of been negated by yet more acting, I can understand that the complexity of such would of either burnt out the actors or moved the game into a different year for completion. I've heard of the heartache associated with the production of the game and can understand why. Its easy to dismiss when coming from a place of ignorance with some of those slight bugs but when looked at as a whole, the game broke some ground, not only in gameplay but technology aswell, not to mention tying them together. I applaud the huge undertaking this game was. One thing that was a little underwhelming though.....the driving... its not a driving game as we already know, its really a detective game but the driving elements, for me, could of been more fun with you being driven around rather than do the driving. I like driving games but when the driving is profuctory rather than part of the game, its best left out. Would of really enjoyed being driven around and take in the sights, scouting for suspects etc....perhaps have a little gun fight along the way etc. I think that would of lended better to a detective game than a sort of limited driving sim with lowend mechanics. Last thoughts, although the main portion of development missed the driving aspects its understandable when you have such attention paid to a rather breathtaking level of charactor detail and nuance.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												L.A Noire is a game set in Los Angeles after World War II, during the "Golden Age of Hollywood". You play as Cole Phelps, a detective who must work his way through the LAPD, solving cases and making arrests. This is one of the best games I've ever played, and I sincerely congratulate Rockstar on their fine work.Firstly, it should be known that the voicework and character animations in this game are fantastic; without this, the game wouldn't work half as well as it did. The characters move and interact seamlessly, due to the innovative use of motion capture technology. During interviews, the player has to read into facial expressions and determine whether a suspect is lying or telling the truth. Due to the impressive animations on display, you can read every eye twitch, uneasy posture and downward glance. These interview sections are the highlight of the game, and it was genuinely entertaining to complete them using evidence and intuition.The basic game mechanics function just like any other Rockstar game; a large (beautifully made) open world, in this case, the grime and glamour of 1950's Los Angeles. You can roam the city on foot or in a vehicle, resolving street crime cases and responding to pleas for police intervention. During a case, you'll often have to travel around the city to meet suspects and other characters, so you'll easily notice the size and attention to detail put into the open world. Additionally, during a case you have to analyse different pieces of evidence, and you'll quickly learn how to integrate these pieces of evidence into the case. It was truly immersive to act like a proper detective, and fans of old crime shows will be delighted here.Without giving anything away, the story is quite investing, and you'll find yourself truly interested in Cole Phelps' story. I don't want to spoil anything, but Rockstar really knows how to make a decent narrative.The only flaw with this game is the horrible optimisation for PC; the graphics are high quality and very consistent, but the port is not well optimised at all. I can barely maintain an acceptable framerate throughout the game, but I persisted due to the quality of the game content. This may be my own error due to using an AMDD Graphics card.Overall, L.A Noire is a highly worthwhile and entertaining experience. The immersive story and gameplay really held me right to the end, but the poor optimisation is the only thing holding this game back from a 10. Well crafted, and I'd love to see a sequel to this one. 9.5 / 10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												What an incredible game. Been playing for 30 hours now and haven't finished it yet. Still have a couple of cases to go and some street crimes.Edit: Finished the game 100% and managed to get every achievement. Loved every minute of it.When you first play the game, the story might go a bit slow, but it doesn't take long before you get sucked into the whole story and drama. For those who are looking for some kind of shooter and/or action game, you've come to the wrong place. L.A. Noire is a detective game and meanwhile there are moments you end up in a gunfight or a car chase, basically the game is about finding every clue and correctly interrogate every suspect. This is what makes the game so much fun and unique. It's something I've never experienced before.And not just that. Every case just gets more and more interesting. Heck, some of them are even close to disturbing. L.A. Noire isn't afraid to hold back.Another thing I love in this game is that the music really helps you. Like when you are walking around on a crimescene, looking for clues, just listen to the music. It will give you a hint where to find things. Same goes for the interrogations. The music (or more like a jingle) will let you know if you, for example, correctly accused someone of lying. Of course, when you do the latter, you have to make sure you have the right evidence to back up your accusation, which is another thing what makes L.A. Noire so much fun.The whole atmosphere of the game is nicely done as well. L.A. Noire takes places in the 1940's and (like the title already suggests) in Los Angeles. I really enjoyed roaming the streets in those wonderful cars (and I'm not even a car-fan!). Roaming the streets (of even just going to the next location for your case) can be dangerous though. One of the things I really, really disliked where all those other people ingame, on the streets. The traffic is horrible, cars just run into you or stop right in front of you for no reason. And sometimes it doesn't even help to turn on the sirens. Some people even JUMP right in front of your car. So yeah, driving around in L.A. Noire can be very frustrating.Another thing I had to get used to were the graphics. They aren't bad, but they aren't very lovely either. At first it kind of had this cardboard-feeling. And it took me a while to get used to the faces, in the beginning I just kept thinking "what is going on with their mouths?". But, it turned out that the way the creators of L.A. Noire used expressions on the faces worked very well. The faces are very expressive and can really help you out during interrogations.Overall L.A. Noire is a really great game, which I have enjoyed so very much (and still am!). It's been a while since I've been so enthousiastic about a game. I definitely recommend this game.Pros:Strong storyAll the casesInterrogation systemAtmosphereMusicGreat main character, very likableFacial expressionsThe carsCons:TrafficTrafficTRAFFIC (especially pedestrians)Moving, sometimes you get stuck

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												I'd forgotten how much of an immersive and distinctive storytelling experience L.A. Noire is in the four years since I completed it on the Xbox 360. It's essentially a hardboiled detective novel brought to life in a highly cinematic gaming experience. I just picked up the complete edition on sale for dirt cheap, and before I knew it, I was spellbound and had spent the entire evening playing it for several hours straight in a single sitting. As the minutes turned into hours, I found myself once again drawn into the game's shadowy world of vice, corruption, and murder that brilliantly captures the atmosphere of 1950s Los Angeles in a medium it had never been explored. The narrative revolves around one main character and a few minor ones and slowly (some would say tediously; this is not a typical open world sandbox game, so don't approach it like one...it requires patience and an open mind) progresses through a series of cases in which you repeat many of the same gameplay elements (inspect crime scenes for clues, go to new locations they lead you to, track down and interrogate suspects, and rinse & repeat in various orders with some chase & gunfight sequences thrown in for pacing as well as optional dispatch missions you can take on in the middle of a case), but the writing, variety of rich settings, and overall presentation are top notch and keep the formula fresh and the mysteries (both in individual missions and the overarching story) tantalizing regardless of linearity. The graphics have aged a bit (even running on maximum settings, pop-in is more evident, draw distance is shorter, and environmental textures that comprise foliage & buildings are much less detailed than the current standards), but none of that detracts from the experience or the dense, vibrant world and performances that made this game so great back in 2011. The motion capture technology it employs is still great, allowing it to showcase very nuanced facial expressions. This PC port is optimized very well, running at a high, stable frame rate and improving on an already visually compelling console game.If you haven't played this yet, I highly recommend it, especially since you can now get the complete package for around $5 which includes the original four standalone DLC missions and two previously console-exclusive missions that are inserted into the campaign, making this akin to a director's cut. A smart, savvy game with dark themes for mature audiences.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Pois é, mais um "retro game". Uma estrutura de história incrível e bem intrigante. E claro, o fato de que tem que lembrar constantemente das pistas. Muita gente dizia que Mafia 2 era melhor que L.A, e vice-versa. Mas quando joguei, percebi que um é muito diferente do outro, e os dois são bons. Porem essa analise é do L.A, então continuando: Os graficos são bonitos, podiam ser melhores, mas é bem aceitavel. A jogabilidade com o carro é um pouco artificial. Não gostei muito de dirigir nesse jogo (Mas a Rockstar facilitou pra quem não gostou, e a maioria das missões voce escolhe se voce ou seu parceiro dirige). O sistema de interrogar as pessoas foi bem planejado, e é um grande enfoque no jogo.L.A lembra bastante filmes que retratam a década de 1940 e 1950. E agora a melhor parte: As expressões faciais!!!Cara, é realmente incrível. Muito bem feito o FaceCap desse game. Um dos primeiro com qualidade. Sem isso o jogo não seria o mesmo (Não MESMO).Nota: 9,2

Posted: January 7, 2015
												Love the visuals. The voice acting and usage of facial implementation in this game is outstanding. Having a setting in the 1940s Los Angeles really works well for a free-roaming detective story.The gameplay can be tricky at times, especially with a gamepad. If you're not used to shooting with lock features, it may lead to frustration.Because of said visuals, it can really show its difficulty when it comes to investigations and interviews, as it is a factor: collecting clues, getting information from witnesses, all to get a perfect case performance. You're not supposed to rely completely on memory to succeed, but rather your awareness on scenes, faces and possible evidence.There's no trigger happy experience for Grand Theft Auto or Postal fans. It seems that the branded cars, food products and other memorable landmarks in the city are the spotlights of the game.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I felt the need to beat the game before I wrote a review on it just so I could get a full-scale view on it. I think I've put about 27 hours into the game before I finally did beat it (and that's without any DLC), so if you're looking for a long game that is worth your money, then L.A. Noire should definitely be considered. You play as Cole Phelps, a war veteran that has returned to the States to enlist as a police officer in Los Angeles. Throughout the game, you will solve cases by collecting evidence around crimescenes, conducting interviews on suspects or witnesses, and driving around the city. Lots and LOTS of driving (Since driving will take up a large chunk of time, the game allows you to "fast Travel" to the selected area by holding "E" next to the car). Every so often, you'll get promoted and moved to a different set of cases (Such as Arson, Homicide, and *Motor Crime*). *I'm not familiar with what Motor Crime is known under*Phelps' life in the war is shown through flashbacks between each case, slowly placing the parts to make a giant picture.The gameplay is pretty simple:  You are assigned a case and you must piece together the clues to solve it. L.A. Noire offers many features that aren't availible in other detective/mystery games. First, the map. L.A. Noire is a gigantic free-roam map (you'll mainly be driving) that takes a LONG time to drive from one side to the other, even going 80 mph. The city is filled, and I mean FILLED with AI life that walks or drives along through the city, making it feel like an actual city. Many of the places on the map are real places or based on real places that were/are in Los Angeles as well. Another feature that I must mention is the interrogation. When you interrogate a person, you will ask them a question, to which they will respond with an answer. You then must decide if they are telling the truth, if you doubt them, or if they are lying (and you can prove that they are lying). You can decide these based on evidence you had found at a crime scene and by looking at the amazing facial expressions the character emits. For example, if a character is staring straight at you while talking, they're probably telling the truth, while if a character keeps avoiding eye contact, you might want to push for more information. The facial expressions in the game are spectacular and the mouth-to-voice dialog is spot-on. Yes, they deserved their own little two-sentence paragraph right here, that's how good they are.I got 27 hours out of the campaign and bought it while it was on sale for $10. After playing, I know that I would have bought it for the full price, due to the well-planned and just delicate features that the game highlights. I must mention one bug that I had with the game...at times, the game would run slow. Most of the time, it ran smoothly and I had no problem with it, but at times, (when Rockstar was busy perhaps) the game would be slightly laggy. Not enough to make the game unplayable, but enough to be quite annoying. Fortunately, if I left and came back a few hours later, I would experience no lag. Finally, I want to promote the different action there is. Often while working a case, you'll be driving and get a call over the radio to respond to a street crime, essentially a side mission. There are many different types of action you will face in the game. There are car chases, police shootouts, tracking missions (missions where you follow the suspect without being seen), running-for-your-life-missions, and many more.Overall, I give the game a 9/10.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												I have to admit I'm quite a sucker for Rockstar games.  I played All GTA games (except 5), all Max Payne games, And some of the Midnight Club and Manhunt games.  When I decided to play this game I knew I'll love it. I knew it from the day I heard of it. And I do.  L.A. Noire has an unique noire feeling that actually make you think you are there and everything seems very real and alive. Unlike GTA where you (or at least I don't) don't actually care much about many of the characters you encounter, here you literally have to discover the life of every victim to solve the case and the fact that you see the victim covered in blood and all beat up makes it more real and somehow personal.  The more you play, the violent the murders are and this makes you really wanna get the murderer and kick his #$@!.  The game comes with an awesome soundtrack and offers an extra goodie - you can actually play the game in grayscale.Literally noire. This is the only game with this kind of feature I've encountered so far.  Unfortunatelly, L.A. Noire revealed again (if this was ever the case) that Rockstar #$#% at porting games to PC. In the past few years I noticed that every new Rockstar PC port is worse than the old one and so on.  But L.A. Noire is by far the worst port ever, technically speaking.  I haven't encounter gameplay bugs but the game is not fluid and has serious FPS drops when you least expect it. You get to see trees and cars and houses materializing up out of thin air (the effect is interesting - unlike GTA where those actually popped up, here I see a Star Trek teleport-like effect :|) Moreover, It doesn't seem to get better when lowering the settings.  In the end, I really want to downvote this game but I can't. Despite it's technical issues, L.A. Noire is a really unique game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I felt the need to beat the game before I wrote a review on it just so I could get a full-scale view on it. I think I've put about 27 hours into the game before I finally did beat it (and that's without any DLC), so if you're looking for a long game that is worth your money, then L.A. Noire should definitely be considered. You play as Cole Phelps, a war veteran that has returned to the States to enlist as a police officer in Los Angeles. Throughout the game, you will solve cases by collecting evidence around crimescenes, conducting interviews on suspects or witnesses, and driving around the city. Lots and LOTS of driving (Since driving will take up a large chunk of time, the game allows you to "fast Travel" to the selected area by holding "E" next to the car). Every so often, you'll get promoted and moved to a different set of cases (Such as Arson, Homicide, and *Motor Crime*). *I'm not familiar with what Motor Crime is known under*Phelps' life in the war is shown through flashbacks between each case, slowly placing the parts to make a giant picture.The gameplay is pretty simple:  You are assigned a case and you must piece together the clues to solve it. L.A. Noire offers many features that aren't availible in other detective/mystery games. First, the map. L.A. Noire is a gigantic free-roam map (you'll mainly be driving) that takes a LONG time to drive from one side to the other, even going 80 mph. The city is filled, and I mean FILLED with AI life that walks or drives along through the city, making it feel like an actual city. Many of the places on the map are real places or based on real places that were/are in Los Angeles as well. Another feature that I must mention is the interrogation. When you interrogate a person, you will ask them a question, to which they will respond with an answer. You then must decide if they are telling the truth, if you doubt them, or if they are lying (and you can prove that they are lying). You can decide these based on evidence you had found at a crime scene and by looking at the amazing facial expressions the character emits. For example, if a character is staring straight at you while talking, they're probably telling the truth, while if a character keeps avoiding eye contact, you might want to push for more information. The facial expressions in the game are spectacular and the mouth-to-voice dialog is spot-on. Yes, they deserved their own little two-sentence paragraph right here, that's how good they are.I got 27 hours out of the campaign and bought it while it was on sale for $10. After playing, I know that I would have bought it for the full price, due to the well-planned and just delicate features that the game highlights. I must mention one bug that I had with the game...at times, the game would run slow. Most of the time, it ran smoothly and I had no problem with it, but at times, (when Rockstar was busy perhaps) the game would be slightly laggy. Not enough to make the game unplayable, but enough to be quite annoying. Fortunately, if I left and came back a few hours later, I would experience no lag. Finally, I want to promote the different action there is. Often while working a case, you'll be driving and get a call over the radio to respond to a street crime, essentially a side mission. There are many different types of action you will face in the game. There are car chases, police shootouts, tracking missions (missions where you follow the suspect without being seen), running-for-your-life-missions, and many more.Overall, I give the game a 9/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Wow, what a spectacularly dull game. To all those complaining you can't get it to launch, youse are the lucky ones... well that's not true but the game's not great. First of all Cole Phelps is just an extremely dulll and unlikeable character. His smug, smarmy facial expressions are captured perfectly with the only real reason to take a glance at this game. The facial animation is still better than most today however the texture quality has not aged well and coupled with the choppy framerate it just doesn't look as good as it once would've. The story doesn't seem to be going anywhere interesting after more than six hours (I've played an hour or two offline as well), it just seems to be a kind of episodic deal. Crime or two, promotion, another crime or two. If you're into detective stuff and noir style then maybe, just maybe you can get into this as there is kind of a gap in the market for this stuff. Just don't expect much in the way of action.This game essentially plays itself during any action sequences. You just hold the trigger down and move forward until the other guy stops running. The shooting is very basic, not bad in any real way, there's just nothing to it. There's nothing really noteworthy to say about the driving either. The meat of the gameplay is the detective stuff. This consists primarily of listening to people talk and using the advanced facial capture stuff to read faces and determine if they're lying, with the help of evidence and context of course. Oh and bad acting works to your advantage too sometimes. You literally just pick Truth, Doubt or Lie which is just doubt but you have to pick a bit of evidence to back it up. You also walk around picking things up and looking at them with great interest. The thing that bugged me the most with this is the fact that it immediately tells you if you got the dialogue tree wrong which just compels me to retry until I get it right and subsequently I end up hearing the same bits of dialogue a dozen times. It'd be more immersive if it just sort of went forward with no specific indication, at least not until the end of the case. For the last one I just used a walkthrough but that made it thrice as boring which is when I realised that I was not enjoying it enough to play anymore.Long story short, don't play it if you're autistic.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Let's start with the graphics. For starters I was actually amazed that L.A. Noire was the first console game that had near-flawless if not flawless anti-aliasing. I kid you not, you could take a look at the telephone wires from up close or from afar and there would be no jaggies. Nevertheless, I attempted to convince myself that my mind was playing tricks on me and that some anti-alised objects were just polished to perfection. I was partially right; it's only the telephone wires, cars and some other objects that have no jaggies.The graphics settings for the PC version are:Antialiasing: 1-3Anisotropic Filtering: 1-4Ambient Occlusion - Yes/NoFacial Quality - Quality/PerformanceTexture Quality - Quality/PerformanceShadow Quality - Quality/Performance/BalancedLighting Quality - Quality/Performance/BalancedEnvironment Map - Quality/Performance/BalancedLevel of Detail Quality - Quality/Performance/BalancedScreen Space Ambient Occlusion - On/OffGlobal Detail Level - Quality/Performance/BalancedAnd there's also a command line for various set-up options.If you have a high end PC you can get 30 FPS if you pick all Quality.However, if you choose Performance, you ALSO get 30 FPS.So they converted the game to PC yet they forgot to raise the FPS cap, hmmm weird. Honestly, I did not notice much difference between the PS3 and the PC version graphic-wise. I mean all those extra graphics options are nice for the ego-boost but I had a hard time telling the difference especially with the frequent texture popping.What I mean is that the game's graphics suffer immensely when you drive your vehicle for instance. Objects just pop out of thin air and grow out of the ground slowly enough for you to notice. You may drive and look ahead at some of the box-like buildings when all of a sudden they begin to acquire the necessary features such as windows, doors, color, etc.Also, in many instances the game practically plays by itself. Again, that was done with the controller movement in mind. You may run after someone through the rooftops, fire escape ladders, alleyways and what not and be automatically redirected to pursue the suspect. The game GUIDES you forces you after the suspect because it assumes you may not be able to make that sharp turn with your controller; all you'll have to hold is the "forward" button.-----Part 2Make no mistake, this is not GTA set in the 1940's. There are no friends to call, bars, memorable and charismatic characters, outrageous cinematics, funny encounters, motorcycles, TV shows, dating, witty radio broadcasts describing the decadent elements of American Culture. This is a very mature, somewhat dry and serious game, perhaps it is too serious. There is a fair amount of thin adult humor that might not even catch your attention but the dialogue is extremely well written to say the least. The game plays and feels just like one of those black and white detective movies. Maybe the game is too serious in fact, there is little room for fun. Nor is there a single set objective mission to complete per se. You just keep the L.A. populace safe from petty and serious criminals.If anything, the game is divided into chapters much like in Mafia 2 and there are some miscellaneous missions to complete aside from the main story. Each story starts with a few seconds video showing what happens to the victim. There are actually clues within those short videos that might help you solve the crime better and faster. So this is like a sand box game with no toys to play. Sure there are 30 secret cars spread out around the city to find and there are badges and newspapers to look for (if you like achievements) but otherwise there is little to do in the city.The driving is very unrealistic, it feels arcadish but at least you don't get annoyed every time you try to make a sharp turn and attempt to regain controls. However this unrealistic consolish driving feels out of place in this serious game. I guess they had to make it easy for the controller. At first you may think to yourself "wow, how did I manage to make that turn, not run over the pedestrian and still be able to pursue that vehicle" - again, the game helps you do all that.For the most part the shooting is okay except when it's not. True, I still prefer the mouse to a controller but once you enter a confined area, the constricted camera speed will force to you aim as slowly as you would with one of those analog sticks.Crime-solving is where the game shines, or supposed to shine at least. Sometimes it will get tedious and samey even though the scenery, the objects, the part of town and the characters are different. At least it got tedious sometimes in my case because I had to pay attention to almost everything. If you have an analytical mind, it will help. If you have a short-attention spam, then good luck. Every case requires your utmost attention and even if you mess up with most clues, facts and interrogations you will still complete the mission only with a low rank. As a result, you will advance slightly slower in the game and have access to less suits, fame and what not. So there is no real sense of danger or fear of messing up HOWEVER you cannot reload your game if the interrogation goes awry for one reason or another, not unless you want to start the chapter all over again. So there is plenty of incentive to not mess up; you want gain those experience points and exchange them for intuition or ask the community option to help you conduct interrogations more effectively.In the end, the 6-year period to make the game and a million dollar debt among other things forced Rockstar to close down their Team Bondi Studio. What can I say, next time, try to make the game faster and RELEASE THE PC VERSION ALONG WITH THE CONSOLE VERSION TO INCREASE THE REVENUE.Thank you very much.

												The first few hours, I found myself genuinely interested but that slowly dwindled away as I realized the game was the same mechanic, wash and repeat for 50 hours. The plot was somewhat complex, which I admire, however it became incredibly absurd. At one point, the main character suddenly does something completely out-of-character and way out in left field.Honestly, the facial animations are good but the face textures are just god awful that it takes away. This is a complete game, but man what a borefest. I found myself anticipating the ending so much just so I could get my closure and move on.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												        Okay let us get started with this.This game has a great story, amazing gameplay, stupendous voice acting and outstanding facial animations. One of the best games out there along with GTA 5. This game is a pure classic.        HOWEVER, HOWEVER, HOWEVER, there is one thing about L.A. Noire that pisses me off tremendously. The game is capped at 30 frames per second. As a PC gamer with a powerful rig, this pisses me off because i play most of my games (90% of them) at 60 fps and higher. Playing at 30 fps did not seem right at all. It feels sluggish, and it does not look smooth at all (to me at least).          Nonetheless, you can uncap the framerate by using WideScreenFixer. You will be able to play it at 60 fps if your PC is powerful enough but then uncapping the framerate would mess up one thing. The driving. Driving is one of the key elements of this game and after you have uncapped the framerate, driving physics will be slightly altered. It will be harder to drive around as the vehicle will feel "floaty" like how the driving in GTA 4 feels like. But if you can get used to that, then there should not be a problem at all.          That would be the only issue in this game so if you can overcome it, you will have a great experience playing it. I would definitely persuade anyone out there to purchase L.A. Noire.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												This is really quite sad example of how the game industry sometimes works. The game may not be on the top shelf of quality, barely fitting 'the solid-good' one. And yet it IS a good game. And not in the way of 'guilty pleasure' good, no. This title is a great example of a sereis in which the second one corrects every mistake of the first one. Unfortunatelly we do not have the possibility to play second one and we are left with this flawed piece of a 'sketch'. And whilst it is a quite nice idea for a drawing, it is not by any means perfect one. Starting with a mediocre graphics, very hard to rate depending on which side we are looking at (faces and interiors are really nice, the rest is... meh). The gameplay is I'd say quite poor and very repetitive. And yet this title took more than 20 hours of my life. And I do not regret it at all. Because as far as the plot, the character, the music adn the climat goes the game is just outstanding! I could really, (without any problems whatsoever) close an eye on a technical side in this case. Take it without a hesitation if you are the player for whom the story development is more important than a gameplay. Especially if you liked the Sabouteur and you are keen on the 40s, noire, and jazz

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												I give this game a pass and recommendthat you do too.Honestly, there's nothing wrong with the game.  Everything is functional and works fine.  It plays well.  The problems for me are twofold: other games have done all of the elements better, and context.Running is fine, shooting is fine, the sound effects are fine, driving is fine, the open world is fine, interrogations are fine, investigations are fine.  There's nothing particularly wrong with any element and like I said the game is functional.  It works.  It's just that so many other games do everything better.  Pretty much any sandbox -- though most notably GTA -- does almost all of the elements better just because of context alone: it makes sense when you're in a huge gunfight or you're firing randomly at people, or driving like a maniac down the road.  Or, you know, stealing a ♥♥♥♥ing car.  I'm not saying that these events never happen if you're a police officer but I have to scratch my head at the ideas of it.Interrogations are fine.  They're ok.  They're acceptable.  However, any game in the Turnabout Courtroom series does the interrogation model so much better.  I never thought I would miss saving between interrogations because of life totals, but holy♥♥♥♥♥♥I do now.  This one and done ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is just aggrivating, especially when the answers are so vague at times (Hi, I'm showing you a blood stained weapon found in your car, in relation to a question about blood all over your car.  Why is this deemed wrong?  And now I'm out of the interrogation).  I get that you can ♥♥♥♥ the interrogations up and your progress isn't stalled but it is frustrating to have so many options before you and see that several could work.  At  least in Turnabout courtroom I'm just slightly perplexed when one of them is wrong, because you know what?  I can keep going and try again.The open world makes no sense to me.  I don't understand why it was necessary for this game, as a large part of it is just driving from one point to another for story missions.  Sure, on occassion a crime pops up, but you have to accept that as your new mission anyway.  It's not like you drive by and one is going on, and you can take care of it or ignore it.  There's no organic feel whatsoever.LA Noire does create a very wonderful world that I enjoyed to drive around, it's just that it was hollow.  You know, like the rest of the game.It took me a few weeks of not playing to decide but I came to the conclusion that I did not want to finish this game.  I'd seen enough of it and felt that, after 6 or so hours, it would just be more of the same.  I'm open to being wrong, and maybe I'll open it up again later and change my mind, but for now I'd rather just play another game.  One that's actually fun and not aggrivating.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												This game was awesome during the seemingly Tutorial. Everything seemed smart and clueful. But a few missions into the detective game and I am frustrated by trying to get a perfect case in an bull**** rigged question and answer system. In this 'case', I refer to the Ambassador's stolen car The consul's car.When talking to a witness, you get 3 choices of answers: Truth; Doubt; Lie. But in this certain case, I doubt the witnessess are telling the truth, and I have no proof he and she are lieing, so I choose doubt. My guy blows his top and calls the witnesses liars, and the game tells me I failed to choose correctly. So I restart the case many times. Finally I chose that the witness is telling the Truth. My guy calmly tells the witness he is lyeing, and the witness confesses and gives more evidence. Game tells me I chose correctly this time. WTF!?!?! This is bull****!!! The two answers are backwards, but are scripted as if it were correct. This kept happening during this certain case, and I have to wonder if the rest of the cases are also scripted to mess with the player instead of acting correctly. Its so frustrating to be told you are wrong when you were correct, and slapped on the wrist for it, until you answer incorrectly and are rewarded for it.The fun parts though are the action scenes if you are driving a squad car. You stop for a bank robbery and kill all the bank robbers in 40 seconds. Then you wish there were 10 more bank robbers so you felt it was a challenge. Most of the time there seemed to be 4 bank robbers, but then there were 5 or 6 the last time, so I hope that my level increases the difficulty of the action scenes. On the downfall, most of the action scenes are incredibly easy. I assume its because I learned the controls really well, but I hope they get incredibly difficult.The worst part was running the case again forces you to re-live the entire storyline times X. There is no scene skipping, EVER! I looked on the RockStar page and someone asked for a kb key to press to skip scenes and they said backspace, and this was also shown in the control options. But backspace does not work! So... replay 25 minutes of scene footage to get to the part where you ask 3 questions to a witness again. Aaarrgghh!! Now this is frustrating. I wish it told me what I was going to say before I chose an option. Like:Truth: I bet you know more than you are letting on.Doubt: You know you are lieing, tell me the truth!Lie: You're lieing! I have proof you did it in the lounge with the candlestick!but... it doesn't. You have to play 25 minutes to see what you are going to say during a questioning.Cons:Citizens look too much alike. I question one citizen, and in the next case there is another citizen who looks exactly like the previous citizen. I don't get it... in a small town, or a big city, all main characters should look unique. At least change their clothes and their hair.Backwards choices.Catching bad guys not involved in your case does not lead to opening new cases against them.Unlock cars by stealing them. Can't buy them.No money system. Except for some sort of city damages that doesn't seem to affect you.Easy action missions.Can't skip scenes.Can't skip chatting.No reason to explore the world if its not involved in your own mission.Can't use your gun, unless the game makes you take it out. And its not wise to use your gun even when the game forces you to take it out.Can't pull your fists out, unless the game makes you.Your guy yells at people on his own. You aren't controlling him. Its a movie, not a game.Mini-map does not rotate. No options for the mini-map.Large map takes 2 seconds to load, and 3 clicks to get back to game, which is 8 seconds. This is frustrating since there is no GPS. You are likely to drive into a long tunnel, instead of going towards your destination.As you play, you realize there is less and less of a reason to explore anything unless it is literally handed to you. (Marked for inspection at the scene by a previous officer.) (Look for shining objects, cause if its not shining then its not ever important.)Many items to inspect are blocked by other items to inspect, making it hard to inspect even if you know that it is there to inspect. a missing flag on an argentinian ambassador's car is blocked by a missing license plate. This type of clue blocking happens in many cases.Can't look at your watch in game.Can't tell what date it is. But many records of the date when someone signed something.Pros:Feeling you are smart when you catch someone in a lie. (If the game feels like being truthful.)Open world.Environment feels real, where there are loads of things to look at, but seldom does anything belong to the case you are working on. You get used to this, and stop looking at things that don't belong to any case ever.Game is set before finger printing, and everyone grabs a gun and fingers the crap out of it no matter what. Game shows how a police officer can walk right into anyone's house if they are invited inside for a different reason, then beat up the citizen and search his house for any reason what-so-ever. No need for warrants when police are invited inside.70+ cars to unlock.Fun (but easy) action missions.No GPS guidance, because you are in the 1940's.tl;drAll in all... I feel to answer what you want to answer, you need a walk-through. But this goes against playing the game and sleuthing! Why not just watch a youtube video of this game instead?If the game had a second tutorial on how to think like the developers thought that investigators should interogate citizens, then this game could have been a ton of fun and a shining star. Otherwise, you are left with writers trying to outsmart a player through cheap tricks. And by tricks I mean: thinking you Doubt someone, so you say Truth so that you "Doubt".

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
 Pros  There's a big world for you to explore. The clue solving and lie dector gameplay is entertaining The street crime (minigames?) are really fun It tells good stories (I'm not sure if there is an over-arching plot)  Cons   While the world is big, there is NOTHING to do outside of the main objective and street crimes.  The lie dector gameplay is broken and gets stale fast. you can click lie for everything, it will go through a scripted sequence, and if you're wrong, you simpily take the statement back. Also I couldn't tell the answer 99% of the time just based on their face.  There are a few street crimes and they get looped after a while (I liked them, but after the 100th time they're no fun)  You only get your gun in (some) street crimes (and maybe a few missions)  The characters aren't fleshed out enough (Partners are jerks that have no real purpose and switch after a few missions. The main character has no real background story with the exception of the war flashbacks that happen inbetween missions)  The controls are slippery (cars feel like they have butter under the tires and the character movement is awful in a way I cannot explain). OVERALL L.A. Noire is an interesting game that is fun, but only for a few hours. I can only recommend it if it goes on sale for $5 or if you're a real fan of 1950s(?) detective games. Don't buy this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2013
												[7/10] – L.A. Noire is a very entertaining action detective simulator that has incredible attention to detail and a phenomenal animation system. Yet sadly, its 30fps cap, and dodgy controls at times leave a small void inside me. Even with its flaws, it’s a very fun and mature title, and worth the price of admission. If you like GTA/Mafia II style open world games, but want the intellectualism offered only by more mature titles, then this is for you. It definitely makes you think, and punishes you for poor detective skills, so good problem solving is a must. There are also some pretty awesome action moments with a Hollywood feel to them, and usually don’t disappoint. Overall I thought it was a good ride while it lasted.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												The year 1947 the case "The Red Lipstick Murder", a woman is found murdered and brutally beaten then dumped at a park just across the LAPD Police Station. Your job as a new dectective is to scout the scene, find clues, find the suspects and interogate them using your intuition and facts to chase down the killer. This is just one example of fantastic cases that you have to figure out and bring down the killers and criminals who commit crimes across L.A. You play as Phelps, a World War 2 veteran and all around do-gooder. Phelps is an honest man who has a strict honor system and puts his all into a case that he is working on. Phelps starts out as a common on the beat cop who likes to put his nose where it usually doesnt belong. He quickly excells through the ranks and without giving any spoilers he becomes a hero cop and is promoted to detective on the trafiic cases. I find this incredibly interesting since you dont immediately start out as this recognized protaganist in a game filled with crime and criminals. But these guys and gals you come across in L.A arent people you really expect to be murders and rapists. These people are your average run of the mill, hard working citizens who just try to make a living in the city.But looks are deceiving. Some of the citizens are actually complete psychopaths!While the core story is really interesting the gameplay is somewhat lacking and the visuals if inspected have small bugs. I found on serveral occasions that some doors i tied walking through would sometimes bug and stay perma shut until i restarted the game. I dont know if that was a problem with my PC or just in general a problem. However I have never encountered it another game. Anyway combat reminds me alot of Red Dead and they are made by the same developer so it was good to see that the combat was very detailed and carefully made. Combat really only comes into play every now and then so if you are a gamer that needs tons of action L.A Noire is not for you. Gamers with patience and pay very close attention to facts and facial expressions will succed in L.A Noire on some occasions. (there is a part where you have to deal with an actress, nasty buisness and very deceiving) L.A Noire also requires gamers who are very mature because there is nudity in L.A Noire and it will go into detail about the cause of death. So if you are quesy I wouldnt recommend this game for you. Finally the last thing to talk about is the enemy mechanics and investigation mechanics. These are really the most important parts of the game and sometimes they do incredibly well. On very few occasions the Ai would suddenly come out of cover shooting but instead of returning back to cover, they stayed there trying to shoot me. Once they needed to reload you could easily gun them down and fire at the next enemy. Like I said, this rarely happened so i wouldnt really be too concerned about it. The criminals who arent firing at you are usually running away from you or trying to fist fight you. Never once encountered any problems with the runners or the fighters. Fighters usually ended with you knocking them out and arresting them, and the runners could completely take a turn for the worst. On one occasion, the criminal took a man hostage and you have to gun the criminal down but be careful not to shoot the hostage or then you will be bagging a body and letting the criminal have the last laugh. But in another spot, there is an  insane man that you have to run down and catch before he can fatally hurt himself. I loved parts of the game like this and suggest you do the side quests that come up as they have their own unique part in the game.Now to the investigation mechanics, these are incredibly well thought out and cleverly displayed! When you enter a crime scene a chime and mystery music begins to play. This all together adds to the atmosphere of a late 1940s crime thriller and does an excellant job at setting the mood. Also the music plays a part when you are investigating, when you here a chime that mean that there is something that could be a clue. I think this is all together inventive and really nails a video game thriller. I recommend this game but am going to give it a 7.5 / 10   Mainly because the lack of combat will push some of the gamers who need action in the game, another reason is some bugs really just throwed me off.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2012
												You could say L.A. Noire is a GTA where you play the cops, but that would be selling the game short. It's definitely not as "sandbox" as its counterpart, since you play through each case in succession. However, every single one of your decisions can have an impact on the rest of the case; and your career.Graphically speaking, there's only one thing that bugs me: the 1940s Los Angeles seems to lack detail, most notably because of a very aggressive LOD policy. Some textures are also low resolution. But it's a very minor thing.The facial animation of this game is just insane and brings an incredible amount of life to the characters; they're really believable, and you can observe the suspects while you're taking notes — it can help you determine whether they're lying or saying the truth. The acting is top notch, and does not seem forced for the most part.The game is slightly confusing at first, but the immersion it offers afterwards is breathtaking. I really recommend playing it.

												To start with, I can honestly say I've never had a love for a video game like I've had for L.A. Noire. The graphics are not the greatest ever seen, detail in objects lacks; how ever during interrogations, facial expressions are very well drawn. I don't full-on action games, I like ones that have a strong story line to aid it; L.A. Noire's story is the best graphical story I've come across so far. The characters are very well described throughout the story and scenes in the game make you think. There is no shortage of surprises and suspense is not scarce. If you're one to enjoy a mysterious but thrilling action game (with some very nice jazz in the background), then L.A. Noire is without competition.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												Here is my review for L.A. Noire, i'll keep it as simple and short as i can.Pros and cons;+ Open world game with a really big map and a lively city allowing free roaming if you want to.+Excellent graphics, beautiful made city+ The soundtrack is awesome, fitting the game atmosphere perfectly.+Probably the best character models i have ever seen, their faces are exactly like the actors impersonating them, with real expressions.+ Fantastic voice acting.+The characters, both protagonists and antagonists, are well made.+Fantastic and well made cases, the game has a really good plot  with an explosive finale.- Sometimes the game was a little buggy while it was raining, i dont think it was my PC since it is top notch. Im not sure why i had that problem, you might not have the same.- Repetitive gameplay that after a while it got a bit frustrating and boring, you almost always do the same thing; go to crime scene, investigate, visit a bar or another place related to crime, chase suspect, interrogate, decide who is guilty.So, as you can understand on your own, this is a really good game that i think all fans of detective-crime games should try it. It might be a little difficult for some while interrogating and making the proper questions, but after a while you will get the hang of it. It can also be a little challenging while finding evidence, but thats what i liked about it. Just buy it, its worth the money, it was an awesome experience for me.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Ugh...I am REALLY conflicted about L.A. Noire. I bought it back during the Steam sale, and I loved the game--or rather, I loved what I was able to play. The game is not technically compatible through Steam with Windows 8, but it initially ran fine on an AMD Radeon 7750. I had buyer's remorse with the AMD card, bought an NVIDIA card with higher benchmark scores, and suddenly the game didn't recognize my new card even though the game supports it. I spent weeks over email trying to resolve the issue with Rockstar, only for them to tell me to run it in compatibility mode (something you can't do through Steam) because it's incompatible with Windows 8. If you have Windows 7/XP, buy this game because it is very well-acted, pretty, and has a very cool approach to being a cop in LA. If you have Windows 8, be very certain your system will run it before purchasing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												If you're okay with finding ways to work around horrible framerate (changing resolution back and forth for me) and an fps cap of 30, you'll find a great game in L.A. Noire. This game is really unique. You get thrown around into every police department, which keeps cases fresh. From homicide to arson, you always have a big case to solve. The face capturing is the best I have ever seen. It's so accurate that you'll recognize many actors' faces. I found it very challenging and rewarding when correctly interrogating suspects. As someone who searches around for treasures and such in games like Uncharted and Bioshock, I enjoyed looking for clues, many of which are well hidden. The DLC is a great edition, with awesome side missions like Nicholson Electroplating and Reefer Madness. The driving is kind of bland, but the 1940s L.A. map is huge and the hidden cars were a nice touch. Plus you can have your partner drive you everywhere if you want. I also found it nice to place a Rockstar game with historically real places, vehicles, criminals, and social paradigms. There are even fictionalized versions of real crimes like the Black Dahlia Murder (which you actually get to solve). Overall, the cinematic feel, great acting and gameplay made L.A. become one of my favorite games. If you're really into mid-19th century film noire, you can even put the game in black and white. Pick up the complete version during the next steam sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2013
												L.A. Noire, by Rockstar and Team Bondi, is, without a doubt, a unique experience. The advanced facial technology which is by far the game's most famous feature really is incredible and for that alone everyone should try it out because there's nothing like it.It's a slow-paced, methodical game. There are action sequences but these are an exception, not the rule, to this game. This game's main strength lies in its investigation and interrogation sequences, coupled with excellent acting and good plot. Note that I'm typing "acting" and not "voice acting". The technology in this game has finally reached the point where I can say that every character in this game is acting, and not just lending their voice to the game.You can totally mess up in your cases, by the way. Like completely. But even if this happens to you, the main storyline will still keep progressing, albeit in dynamic and different ways. Your partners, peers, and superiors will comment on how you couldn't get that one case done, or if you did, praising you on your foresight. I found this really neat and a lot more investigation games should go for this dynamic direction as well instead of keeping you stuck until you find the perfect solution. (I'm looking at you, Phoenix Wright, and some point and click adventures as well)As the title implies, it perfectly evokes that feeling of a 40's Los Angeles in a dark, depressing, noir setting. The vehicles, buildings, city, music, up to the radio commercials themselves are spot on. There is freeroam as you'd expect to find in your average GTA, and street crimes which are always action oriented as fun sidequests. The story of LAPD detective Cole Phelps is very interesting and involved, and while this game is about solving crimes, it's also about telling the story of this man, who isn't perfect, has its ups and downs, and is just amazing to go through. Fantastic protagonist.I will say though that the ending felt kind of rushed, and there were a few loose ends. Closure where it was mainly needed was given though, so don't worry, this game didn't pull a Mass Effect 3.More games like L.A. Noire need to exist. Even though I've had a LOT of cases to solve, I'm still yearning for more, and I'll definitely replay this after a few years at the very least so my memories won't be as clear and I can fumble about again, because it actually makes it enjoyable and realistic for me, that even the star detective such as Cole could get fooled and get it all wrong once or twice.It's not all rainbows and sunshine though! This game is a bad PC port. Rockstar are known for being subpar when it comes to the PC, and L.A. Noire is no exception. I've had to open up a bunch of launch commands, even get a .dll file to get my game into a playable state. It doesn't help that its capped at 30 FPS either, because according to Team Bondi, the facial animations could get wonky were you to go any higher than that. 60 FPS fixes were applied and this wasn't seen though, so it's highly debatable.If you can get this on the PS3 or Xbox 360, then do so as you won't have to deal with these issues. If you can't though, at least try to give it a go anyway because like I said, this is an awesome game if it happens to like your PC and everyone should play it. I'm all for a sequel or a game set in the same style as this one!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												WARNING: Possible spoilers ahead, read at your own risk.Pros:A very well put together narrative, which catalogues the rise and fall of it's characters, in typical Film-noir fashion.Strong, believable characters with excellent delivery both from their respective actors and the awe-inspiring motion-capture technology utilized.Your partners. Their random banter and distinguished personalities are a joy to behold, they act both as the lancer and the foil to Cole's personality, and do an excellent job of playing off of Cole's own musings.Meh's:Lack of penalty for not upholding laws (especially when dealing with traffic), Cole can drive as recklessly as he wants, even right next to other cops without them giving a damn.The structure of the cases, especially between Homicide and Vice. In Homicide, you just finished solving a case that had made a mockery of the LAPD, and in turn, acted as a very rewarding end to that desk. BD would have served as a greater case to end the game with, although given the circumstances, I'm inclined to believe that the narrative was constructed before the individual cases, and that the cases merely served to facilitate Cole's fall from grace.Cons:The save system is check-point based, which is fine, until you realize you have to restart a case and lose an hour's worth of gameplay because the game decides to auto-save after a failed interrogation.Combat, atleast on the PC version, is rather finnicky and temperamental. The gunplay itself works, but the cover system is unresponsive and has baffling key-binds.All in all:If you're willing to deal with slow gameplay coupled with investigatory work and puzzle-solving, this game is right up your alley. It's not a masterpiece, but it will serve as the industry-wide standard for detective games in the future.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												This game cured my porn addiction during the Homicide cases! 10/10 No doubt!However, there are in-fact downsides... Even if you do have a computer capable playing Grand Theft Auto IV, you may still suffer very bad gameplay experience because of its limited 30 frames per second refresh rate and some other technical bits about the bad performance of the game...Since this game is not using Rockstar's Advanced Game Engine but a modified unnamed engine, I guess you may find that some driving aspects and shooting mechanics are slight different in the works from GTA IV...Workarounds are of course limited and not throughly proven to fix all solutions surrounding the game, example:-str or Single Threading game setting-nonv to disable nVidia 3D stereoscopic view (if you are using AMD or Intel GPU)-npd works by extending the compatibilty of GPUs which are not in their native supported DirectX version. If you have a DirectX 10 GPU but there's no DX10 option, you better choose DirectX 9 renderer and add -npd to the command lineBut if you managed to iron out (or even ignored) these NG stuffs, you will really get to experience the game at it's best!Played on an Intel Pentium Dual Core processor PC with 2GB RAM and Intel HD Graphics with some drawbacks.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												The atmosphere in the game is great. Music, cars, scenery, clothing, you really get a feel for the time period. The start of each new chapter gives the feel of a new episode of a crime drama on TV. This is a good fit, as the game is quite a bit like an interactive movie.The game controls are a bit like Bully (also from Rockstar). Grand Theft Auto controls would have been better, but the game plays perfectly fine with a controller.The graphics are quite good. The latest and greatest lighting and textures may not be present, but the game does a great job with facial expressions. This is a good thing, as most of the game revolves around your ability as a detective to identify when someone is not telling the truth.Gameplay has youin the role of a detective. You look for evidence, question suspects and in your "off time" run down street criminals as sort of little mini missions.The evidence searches are quite easy if you set the controller to vibrate when they are nearby. Without the aid of vibration, it would be very easy to miss a clue without clicking every shred of paper you walk close to.Suspect interviews are a little tougher. You ask a question and get an answer. Then you have to  decide on facial expressions (shifting eyes, a smile, looking away...etc. if the suspect if not giving the full story, or if they are flatout lying. If you choose correctly, you are rewarded with more information and some points. Choose wrong, and you will fail to be promoted.There are intuition points you earn that can help to find evidence and determine if someone is lying, but you can burn though these quickly and will need to solve more crimes to refill your suply.There are fight scenes with guns and fists, and chase scenes in vehicles. If you fail these smaller missions several times in a row, the game shows you merry and allows skipping the mission without penalty.As I said, the game is very much a story that you are taking part in. Gameplay is not very difficult, and while you can replay missions to do better, the story and cutscenes do not really make for interesting replay value. I'm enjoying the story, and am intrigued enough to keep going. Overall the game is good. I think the only downside is a low replay value.There is some type of online social component to the game, but I've not been able to connect to it, The game is a few years old, so maybe the servers have been shutdown?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Most games compete in certain brackets and standarts, so their flaws and advantages are defined compared to those that are similar. That means that games which don't fit into those regulations should be judged differently. L.A. Noire, no matter what anybody says, is truly a unique and unrivaled experience, unlike anything you've ever played before. In that light, it deserves any player's attention and respect. It has its flaws, but those are heavily outweighed by the game's positive sides.Since the pros are a lot more significant than the cons, lets start with the drawbacks.Cons:-"Fake" Open world. In the beginning of the story, the player is thrown into an immensely large world of the late 40's LA. Its level of detail and magnitude are on par with those of the GTA Series. The world is HUGE. But I couldn't help but feel like a prisoner in the middle of a desert. With such freedom, there should be a lot of thing to do, right? And that's where LA Noire struggles. Frankly, there's almost nothing to do other than the campaign. The Street Crimes, although elaborate, are extremely repetitive: all consist of drive to the scene, then catch this guy/shoot them/trail the bandit. No real variety there. Other than that, the Landmarks, although crucial for certain cases, are uninteresting; the same story is with the movie reels. The game world is only saved by the outstanding atmosphere and the overall great representation of the 40's LA: it is simply entertaining to just drive around, pay attention to details and feel the history in your hands.-Repetitiveness. Though it is clear Team Bondi tried to include as much variety as possible(neither street crimes nor main cases are exactly the same), the true nature of the game is very plain and monotonous. In some cases, especially the homicide desk, the gameplay comes down to "go to scene, inspect, go there, interrogate, go there, done." At that point in the game, it is repetitive, boring, and disappointing. It has to be said though, it may be a good thing. I have never worked as a detective and cannot judge whether that's just realism; maybe so.-The ending. Objectively, it might not be bad. But it does not fit any of the criteria for a good, satisfying ending: it doesn't connect with the major plot lines and characters, it doesn't intrigue or send a great message, it doesn't fit the style of the story itself. Some say that it fits the "Noir" genre and can only be understood by "mature audience", don't really understand what "noir" means. At least LA Noire puts an end to the story, unlike some other games where the ending is DLC'd.Now onto the good parts,Pros:-AMAZING immersion and atmosphere. Truly incredible to play a game where the player feels so related to Phelps and others. There are only several titles I can name which come close in atmosphere to the perfectly replicated post-war Los Angeles of LA Noire. Everything feels realistic, smooth, and satisfying. The city of LA is alive and full of cool landmarks and details to explore. Some characters are relatable and felt for, some are disgustingly unpleasant. When major plot lines come up, the emotional response to the fate of the story and characters is deep and real.-Uniqueness. LA Noire is truly one of a kind game. Noir style is objectively interesting, detectives are appealing to some people. In gaming those two styles aren't seen often; in fact, a simple google search for both yields the fact that this game is exceptional. No other game provides such feel of responsibility for your actions and requirement for logic and attention to detail. The face-capture technology also allows interrogations to reach a new level. All interactions with suspects and your notebook are something completely new and very interesting.-Vice and DLC cases. To put it plainly, none of the cons apply to the Vice desk and most DLC cases. Both are a undoubtfully a 10/10 experience. Early on Ad Vice, the player learns true responsibilty for actions as minor characters may actually die depending on the success or failure of the detective. As other desks cases can get tidious, Vice provides an outstanding variety of settings, actions, locations, and colorful characters, connected by an highly entertaining and unexpected plot details and twists. As for DLC cases, they are the same way - incredibly fun and interactive. 5 awesome cases - a great value for 1$, no doubt. The last one is a real visual treat as well.-Face capture technology. Something new and fresh. A real improvement to the industry introduced in a game which really needs it the most. The game and the characters feel much more alive and responsive than even before, which provides for a true detective experience.In conclusion, LA Noire is entertaining but inconsistent. Some parts of the game are a masterpiece, some are an unfortunate failure. Overall, definetly worth trying out for both fans of Noir/Detective and non-fans. 7.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2012
												Rockstar have done it again. They've created another game with a richer story than you'd get from a modern Hollywood blockbuster.They combined it with a new style of game. L.A. Noire tells the story of Cole Phelps, an LAPD detective in post-war Los-Angeles. While the game has the same look and feel of GTA IV and Red Dead Redemption.L.A. Noire's gameplay is completely different. Gone is the ability to shoot up the average passer-by; as Cole Phelps, you're a good cop in a world of corruption. Instead of pumping lead into the criminals, you now have to coerce information and confessions out of them. Suspects must be interrogated in order to open up new avenues for you to investigate. This game takes a bit of brainpower and skill in order to read whether your suspect is telling the truth, or if they're trying to serve you a plate full of stinking lies. Revolutionary, refreshing and compelling. L.A. Noire will keep you hooked as long as you can appreciate it for what it is.8.5/10

Nontheless well made, you wont be playing it over and over again but the one time you will, you will enjoy it.
