												If you're okay with finding ways to work around horrible framerate (changing resolution back and forth for me) and an fps cap of 30, you'll find a great game in L.A. Noire. This game is really unique. You get thrown around into every police department, which keeps cases fresh. From homicide to arson, you always have a big case to solve. The face capturing is the best I have ever seen. It's so accurate that you'll recognize many actors' faces. I found it very challenging and rewarding when correctly interrogating suspects. As someone who searches around for treasures and such in games like Uncharted and Bioshock, I enjoyed looking for clues, many of which are well hidden. The DLC is a great edition, with awesome side missions like Nicholson Electroplating and Reefer Madness. The driving is kind of bland, but the 1940s L.A. map is huge and the hidden cars were a nice touch. Plus you can have your partner drive you everywhere if you want. I also found it nice to place a Rockstar game with historically real places, vehicles, criminals, and social paradigms. There are even fictionalized versions of real crimes like the Black Dahlia Murder (which you actually get to solve). Overall, the cinematic feel, great acting and gameplay made L.A. become one of my favorite games. If you're really into mid-19th century film noire, you can even put the game in black and white. Pick up the complete version during the next steam sale.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												L.A Noire plays out in the mid-20th century, just after the Second World War. You play as Detective Cole Phelps, a good hearted cop who was a soldier in the pacific during the second world war. The game confronts you with a time period where racism was rampant, drug abuse was growing, and violence was all too common. The city of L.A is one of the major stars in the game. Every street is full of life, with people going in and out of bars and shops, people reading the daily newspaper before going to work. The game feels as though its actually come to life. MotionScan, a neat piece of technology which Team Bondi created to capture the emotions of the characters on screen. It works splendidly, giving each conversation an engrossing hook that typically associated with great film and television dramas. When a character lies, you can see it in their face. Interviewing a suspect is the hardest and most important thing you will do in the game. You ask a question, listen to their response and then attempt to decipher whether it's a lie, the truth or something you should "doubt" and inquire further about. You don't only listen to what they saying, but you have to look very carefully at their faces as well. The slightest twitch in there cheek, or there eyes darting quickly to the left can help you uncover the truth. There is more to L.A Noire than just interrogation. There is a fair amount of crime-scene investigation, patrolling and beat work. At crime scenes, you are able to examine the victim up close to try find clues. You will walk around crime scene picking up all sorts of objects to see if they hold any clues. Outside of the regular story. L.A. Noire offers a few other tasks. You can explore the city and look for historic L.A. landmarks, tackle random side mission crimes as they come to you over your C.B. radio, as well as play additional DLC cases. Once you have finished a story, you are ranked to how well you answered questions, how many you got right, and how much damage you did to your car and the the city of L.A. The sounds in the game are amazing, with cars and busses going by, to the sound of the sparks coming from the electric wires as the tram drives past you. The acting is completely believable and really helps set this game apart from other detective games. The Verdict:For all of its attention to detail, L.A. Noire hits the occasional false note. But if you put that aside, L.A Noire can be a very entertaining game, with an open world to explore and lots of interesting cases, The awesome performances and great facial capture make every interrogation and investigation a riveting affair. L.A Noire is a perfect game that I would definitely recommend to everyone. Pros:+ Open world of an authentic and outstanding 1940s style of atmosphere+ Memorable story+ Great use of motion capture+ Compelling investigation and interrogation mechanics + Amazing graphics+ Brilliant acting + Amazing soundCons:- Some restrictions during pursuits and shoot-outs feel artificial- Can become a bit repetitive at timesScore: 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												As a cinematic experience, LA Noire is very good. It has a stack of content, compelling stories, great voice acting and revolutionary facial animation. It tackles challenging themes in a mature manner. It offers a large area to explore, built with great attention to detail.As a game...it's a mixed bag. The distractions - driving, shooting, tailing and collecting items - are nothing special. The core is the investigation - searching for clues and interrogating witnesses/suspects. The former is decent, with helpful difficulty options. The latter has its moments, both good and keyboard-smashingly bad.Two examples. A witness is asked about a document found in the possession of somebody else. There is no reason to be sure, or even reasonably suspect, that she is aware of it. When she denies knowledge of it, an appropriate choice response would seem to be "Doubt". According to the game, it's "Lie" - even though her response seems to confirm that she was unaware of it, making the "Lie" a strange choice. Even worse, there is another situation where you are expected to select "Lie", when the actual lie arises from the response to your challenge upon choosing "Lie"!The single checkpoint save is also frustrating. Realise you made a mistake (seeing witness in a certain order cuts out a possible question in an early mission, for instance) or encounter a mission-breaking bug after a checkpoint save, and you have to go back to the very beginning - 30+ mins of unskippable dialogue and driving.There's also port issues - a woeful 30fps, graphical pop-in and the like.For all that...it's still a compelling experience. As much as it annoys me, I keep coming back. It may require a new keyboard by the end, but it'll be worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												You're one of the LA's finest, a former military veteran who is looking to build a successful career out of law enforcement in 1940's post World War II L.A. with fancy suits and muscle cars. It's men's world.Playing L.A. Noire is like taking part in an interactive movie. It's more than just watching the action as you get to take part in it. And the outcome of the cases is determined on your gut, your attention to detail, and interrogation skills rather than just wating the actor to state their line. If there is at least a tiny bit of detective in you and you want to get to the bottom of things then you'll find the storyline captivating and it will drag you in like honey.As of gameplay, mouse & keyboard combo is tolerable. Walking and running around with keys and using mouse to look/aim works fine most of the time. Driving is slightly awkward when you want to drive straight or especially when trying to take sharp corners in high speed due to the fact that the camera turns slowly behind the vehicle unless your mouse hand is in sync with your keyboard hand. Many times I've ended up smashing bumpers with oncoming traffic or rear fender taking contact with nearby mailbox or lamp post. However, as this is not the most important mechanic I bare with it. Car chases are still fun.Interrogation of people is the one that gives you the most "what ifs". Do I believe what this person is saying with their eyes rolling out of their heads or do I push my luck to squeeze the last bit of information they have? Or do I dare to state they're lying and then provide them with evidence that I know what the real case is? And you'd better have the evidence with such allegation or the conversation may be short lived.The gameplay involves occasional chases both on foot and on wheels, some gunfights and brawls. They play out decently not getting too much attention from the story itself. In overall, there's a nice balance of action, seeking and dialogue to my taste and it keeps me tempted to replay a case after a case until I get the gist of how it should have been.If you have no patience and you couldn't care less about the story then this might not be the game for you. But if you're into the era and the mysteries of police detectives then I highly recommend L.A. Noire.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												this game was excellent, it's largely something unlike the majority of game experiences i've had. I really enjoyed the interrogation mechanics and the use of the motion capture technology for the actors faces to be realistically portrayed in the game was just awesome.the game loses some steam right after the early sections, it becomes sort of repetitive and the action sequences (driving and shooting sections) are spaced out a little too far for a few hours of gameplay, but make it through this slower section and the game's story and action pick up and hook you into the experience hard enough to push through to the more exciting final chapters of the game.I experienced a few minor technical issues - mostly with the controls at certain sections of the game, navigating tighter spaces when looking for clues can be a bit clunky and the cover shooting mechanics felt very unpolished and I tended to avoid using the cover system because of that.9.5/10 experience overall. Had the pacing been a little better in the second act of the game, and the control issues not been there it could've been a 10/10. These two small issues didn't keep me from loving the game regardless though. Probably a top 10 game of all time for me.get it now

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2012
												Rockstar have done it again. They've created another game with a richer story than you'd get from a modern Hollywood blockbuster.They combined it with a new style of game. L.A. Noire tells the story of Cole Phelps, an LAPD detective in post-war Los-Angeles. While the game has the same look and feel of GTA IV and Red Dead Redemption.L.A. Noire's gameplay is completely different. Gone is the ability to shoot up the average passer-by; as Cole Phelps, you're a good cop in a world of corruption. Instead of pumping lead into the criminals, you now have to coerce information and confessions out of them. Suspects must be interrogated in order to open up new avenues for you to investigate. This game takes a bit of brainpower and skill in order to read whether your suspect is telling the truth, or if they're trying to serve you a plate full of stinking lies. Revolutionary, refreshing and compelling. L.A. Noire will keep you hooked as long as you can appreciate it for what it is.8.5/10

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												L.A. Noire is one of those games that can really surprise you with how good it is. While it has some open world aspects to it, the game is actually quite linear as far as mission structure and story are concerned. This is not a bad thing. It's like watching an old mystery movie, combined with point-and-click game concepts, and GTA mechanics and gameplay. It all fuses together to form a unique game that is very interesting to play through.The visuals are quite good, and even today could be mistaken for next-gen quality. The faces are very expressive, much more so than most games in general. This is because part of the game is about reading your subject when interrogating them to see if they are lying or not.While the different elements of this game are derivative from many games you've probably played before, the experience and setting make this a game feel unique. It is certainly worth the playthrough for just about any gamer.7/10 "Good"

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												WARNING: Possible spoilers ahead, read at your own risk.Pros:A very well put together narrative, which catalogues the rise and fall of it's characters, in typical Film-noir fashion.Strong, believable characters with excellent delivery both from their respective actors and the awe-inspiring motion-capture technology utilized.Your partners. Their random banter and distinguished personalities are a joy to behold, they act both as the lancer and the foil to Cole's personality, and do an excellent job of playing off of Cole's own musings.Meh's:Lack of penalty for not upholding laws (especially when dealing with traffic), Cole can drive as recklessly as he wants, even right next to other cops without them giving a damn.The structure of the cases, especially between Homicide and Vice. In Homicide, you just finished solving a case that had made a mockery of the LAPD, and in turn, acted as a very rewarding end to that desk. BD would have served as a greater case to end the game with, although given the circumstances, I'm inclined to believe that the narrative was constructed before the individual cases, and that the cases merely served to facilitate Cole's fall from grace.Cons:The save system is check-point based, which is fine, until you realize you have to restart a case and lose an hour's worth of gameplay because the game decides to auto-save after a failed interrogation.Combat, atleast on the PC version, is rather finnicky and temperamental. The gunplay itself works, but the cover system is unresponsive and has baffling key-binds.All in all:If you're willing to deal with slow gameplay coupled with investigatory work and puzzle-solving, this game is right up your alley. It's not a masterpiece, but it will serve as the industry-wide standard for detective games in the future.

												Play as a detective in post war L.A. and solve multiple cases. The characters' facial animations have been done in a totally new way and it looks superb. content:
Posted: August 4, 2013
												Respect to Rockstar for originality. Really refreshing gameplay, never played anything like it. Overall pretty much all of the elements are high quality too, nice visuals, great soundtrack, interesting and mature story. The action and driving although far from perfect are decent enough. The investigating, interrogation and story is were the game excels though. Plus I enjoyed the use of the motionscan technology (facial expressions).I did feel it dragged on a bit but remedied by taking a break now and again, one of the main flaws was the most fun part of the game - interrogating suspects and witnesses sometimes failed due to the way the system works and how it is named. Finally it seemed a shame that in such a lovingly crafted and detailed  world there was very little, if any reason to explore away from the main story. A favourite film of mine is Chinatown and LA Noire at points made me feel like I was taking part in my own similar movie. I hope they make a sequel one day and it remains in that era. 9/10

content:
Posted: May 18, 2013
												Really incredible. The game play itself isn't anything spectacular, but the world that Rockstar has created in 1947 Los Angeles is really something to experience. I have spent hours just driving around, sightseeing, listening to the radio, finding various secrets. My dad lived in L.A. In the mid 50s, so I got to share a bit of his youthful memories through the game. He even recognized the song playing on the radio!An interesting side note: Rockstar used over 180,000 aerial photographs in order to more accurately reproduce that noire feeling of 1940s Los Angeles. Actual radio broadcasts, commercials, and music (The Bickersons, The Jack Benny Program, Louis Armstrong, Ella Fitzgerald) were also used to further immerse the player.A fun game, but if you're at all into 40s Americana it's worth buying just to cruise down Holywood Blvd in one of the 95 vintage cars listening to Bing Crosby.I certainly enjoyed it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2012
												You could say L.A. Noire is a GTA where you play the cops, but that would be selling the game short. It's definitely not as "sandbox" as its counterpart, since you play through each case in succession. However, every single one of your decisions can have an impact on the rest of the case; and your career.Graphically speaking, there's only one thing that bugs me: the 1940s Los Angeles seems to lack detail, most notably because of a very aggressive LOD policy. Some textures are also low resolution. But it's a very minor thing.The facial animation of this game is just insane and brings an incredible amount of life to the characters; they're really believable, and you can observe the suspects while you're taking notes — it can help you determine whether they're lying or saying the truth. The acting is top notch, and does not seem forced for the most part.The game is slightly confusing at first, but the immersion it offers afterwards is breathtaking. I really recommend playing it.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												LA Noire makes a bit of a compromise between genres to appeal more players, in this case a mix between a free roaming and a Noire novel adventure. I believe that if the whole town was to be depicted in a smaller way, there could have been a far better and deeper rendition of some beautiful places you happen to walk through (and that could have left more resources for other "details" as a better plot for some cases and more gameplay depth). As it is, the game is a good adventure that lacks quite a bit of everything to really sparkle. The plot as a whole is interesting, the last chapters and the end are rather...sad and bitter. I think the Metacritic score is quite appropriate, i wouldn't give more than 7,5-7,8 to L.A. Noire.P.s. being a console port, it will perform average at best.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												I joined the site when Steam made me an offer I can't refuse which is this game. Borrowed and played it on my Playstation 3 for a while and got bored but something about the "Noire" aspect and the era the game is set in drew me back to this title which is why I decided to buy it, this time on PC.After playing just a bit farther than I had in the past, I have to admit that I missed out. I get the hype and I get why people love this game. It has so much more depth as the story progresses. It is beautifully written and most of the actors involved are brilliant (kudos to the casting director!). The story keeps you hooked and if I  was a decade younger I'd be playing this game nonstop from start to finish in one seating.The graphic quality is not on par with its PS3 counterpart, it's better. It's a given that you need a decent GPU to run it and fortunately I got a pretty good one installed on my laptop. Control leaves something to be desired since the mouse can't never replace a Dual Shock controller once a game is optimized for said controller which this game certainly is. But it's still more than playable, just needs some getting used to when inspecting a crime scene. In many ways this game is just as good as the PS3 one just with more customizing options. Get yourself a nice controller and you might be able to enjoy this game more. It's such a shame that the game developer (Bondi) is shut down, we need more games with the same innovation they brought to this one. I mean, performance capture for games? It's absolutely brilliant! Hope other devs would look into the same technology and use it to make story-driven games like this one here.If you have never played the game or don't have a copy of it on Steam or what have you, get this game. It's a classic (literally)!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												This is yet another masterpiece of a game delivered by Rockstar. The addition of 'real' facial expressions may seem a bit gimmicky but is essential when questioning suspects. It is up to the game player to determine whether suspects are telling the truth or lying, and this can be done by carefully watching facial expressions. However, if you accuse a suspect of lying you will need to have some kind of proof to back it up. Graphically, the developers has done an amazing job - there does not seem to be a noticable repetition of buildings within the map. Vehicles are rendered beautifully and appear to be fairly faithful to the real things. It is a shame that the game is limited to 30fps on the PC but it is a solid 30fps (played with Fraps running to check). The XBox 360 version has moments where the FPS drops well below 30. Sound is used very well, using a dramatic score when something important is happening in the game. Music is also used during the searching of clues and helps the game player stay within the 'search area'. NPCs have dialogue but it can be quite repetitive. Sound effects are spot on, even down to the sound of aircraft flying high up overhead and chirping birds, etc.L.A. Noire will appeal to gamers who like to think and solves clues. It may appear to be similar to the GTA series but the missions are in no way similar. If you are an arcade game fan this game will not appeal as it is very difficult to pick it up for a quick blast.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												My overall impression of the game is - it should have been done differently. Even though I enjoyed its setting and atmosphere, I can't help but think that there are so many things that could have been improved - such as the storytelling (after 35 hours of gameplay I still can't say that I fully understand the main character's motivations) or graphics (beautifully done faces plastered on fake looking bodies didn't exactly work for me). The city is unnecessarily big and, sadly, feels quite empty. Perhaps the game would have been better off without the forced sandbox feel. However, I enjoyed the majority of the cases and would deffinitely want something similar to be developed in the future - just without the aforementioned faults. I'd rate L.A. Noire 7 out of 10 - even with all its small issues, the game managed to hook me for the whole 35 hours. I don't think I will come back to it though; it's just a one-time experience.

												This game is underrated, but it is suprisingly an amazing game. In L.A. Noire you're playing as a cop that goes by the name of Cole Phelps. During thetime you play the game you really get that feeling that the city is supposed to be 1940's L.A., when almost everyone wore a suit and a hat! They actually did a good job with the music as well, because you can only hear old music, and not dubstep or house music.Also, the facial expressions in this game is amazing. Too bad they haven't used this technique in other games.The PC-port for this game has been criticized, and I agree that the PC-port could be alot better. However, the game itself is amazing, the PC-port doesn't ruin the experience of playing the game, in my opinion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												It's like playing a movie, in the best way imaginable.I've seen previews of it, and I was intrigued. I heard more about it and I really got interested. I saw someone demo it and I was immediately sold. This game is not for everyone, however. It has gritty visuals and intense subject matter. If you like the Black Dahlia film or Noir detective stories, you may like this. The sound direction is superb, and the music is very well done. Some tracks can wear on the nerves, but the action tracks put you in the moment.This game plays very well on Windows 7, but crashes do happen on occasion.Overall, this is a very excellent title, and the actors are superb, for the most part. If you watch Mad Men, you may see more familiar faces than just Phelps. This is a huge leap for in-game visuals, as the talking heads do look very good most of the time. Some glitches can be jarring, but they're few.It's a large game, and requres a lot of RAM and a very capable video card. Nevertheless, it's well worth the visit to 1940's Los Angeles if you want a good detective procedural.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Worth reviewing for a lump of coal or a badge. However...Highly engrossing. Some say it's repetitious, probably due to each case essentially having you starting from scratch. I don't see how it's any different to highly popular crime shows. Watch a whole DVD of that in one sitting and I'm sure you'll see repetition too.It was a very ambitious choice to mix a number of elements. Undoubtedly compromises had to be made to make them fit which I think were minimal. I also applaud their foresight to employ new technology and use it to create a critical element of the game (face capture).Finally the atmosphere is just great. So much polish, so much attention to detail. It feels a shame this whole world was built and may never be used again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												This game supposedly doesn't work for windows 10 users but after I upated my PC I never had any issues. Aside from that the game is amazing. I still haven't beat it, but I'm really close to the end and so far I love the story. It would seem like the gameplay would get repetative after a while but it's really not. The game constantly has you on the edge of your seat waiting to see where the case takes you next, and believe me, it takes you to some really unexpected places. The whole game revolves around searching crime scenes and various other places related to your current case for clues, interrogating various people, and the occasional fist fight, gun fight, or car chase. This game will teach you right off the bat to pay close attention to detail and never rule anything out. You have you be very thorough with your investigations of crime scenes and anywhere else the game has you search (apartment buildings, bars, railroads, etc.) even the most minute things could be an important clue in helping you solve your case.The interrogations are brought to life by the face caption which essentially puts a real actors face on a game characters body. This helps a lot because the main point of the interrogations is to read the suspects face to determine whether they are lying or not. This would be incredibly difficult to do with a game character's face. You have three options when interrogating someone, they will make their statement and you have to choose truth, doubt, or lie. Truth is pretty obvious, lie is for when you know they are lying and have proof of it, and doubt is for when you think they may be lying but don't have any solid evidence to back you up. Most of the time you can tell if people are lying because they will try to avoid making eye contact, fold their arms, shake their head a lot, etc. Essentially what someone does if they are actually lying to you in real life. You can also tell if they are lying by the way they speak, if they are lying they may stutter a lot, have a lot of voice cracks, or just generally speak in a higher pitched voice. And most of the time if they are telling the truth they will have no hesitation when they speak, they will maintain eye contact, etc. The combat in the game is nothing special, it seems like it was ripped straight out of GTA. This isn't a bad thing because it's not the main focus of the game, and it's still pretty fun nonetheless. But again, nothing special. The car mechanics can be somewhat tedious at times but for the most part it's just like any other game. Nothing new there.There is a lot of sequences where you will find yourself chasing a suspect through a back alley or across rooftops. You can try to gun down the escapee, shoot into the air to scare them, or just try to get close and tackle them.The city of L.A itself is very big and well designed. It looks really good and feels very alive. You can drive around for hours just enjoying the sights of L.A. There is also a lot of side missions and events to keep you entertained.The story is really enjoyable, I don't want to spoil anything, and trust me, you don't want it spoiled for yourself. Just do your best to avoid spoilers and enjoy the story for yourself.The game also has several platforming sections, but uh... we don't talk about those... best to just get them over with and then forget they ever happened in the first place...That's about all I have to say. You should definitely buy this game if you're into detective stuff, or if you just want to have a fun experience.Also, like I said earlier I had no problems launching the game, but if you do I know there is fixes for it. It is definitely worth it still to buy the game, even if you have to do some wonky stuff to get it to work.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												A great experiment with mixed results, the use of face capture technology is very impressive but probably won't age well. Tying the unique tech to an interrogation mechanic is a great idea, though sometimes the interrogations themselves can be frustrating and illogical, even to the point that I'd just restart the mission if it became a wash. Shooting and driving are both passable and functional, except for a frustrating sequence in the finale which involves way more shooting than the rest of the game. What I love most about this game is its adherence to Noir style, complete with all the backstabbing intrigue that comes with it. Nearly every Noir trope is in full effect here, and there's some truly excellent acting to be found, on par with Hollywood productions, probably because there are a great deal of talented character actors involved that you'll probably recognize from this thing or that. The story is solid and kept me hooked, and its final scene is brilliantly delivered. As with others I've enjoyed, this is a game I recommend not for the strength of its mechanics, but for its "feel", and in terms of making you feel like a hard-boiled Noir detective, you won't find anything better on the market.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												A great game that has an interesting setting and gameplay mechanic.The game world is based around post-WWII LA.  The story is focused around detective work on various cases that range from traffic crimes, to homicide, to arson, and vice cases.  Each case has clues you have to discover as the scene and from the various people you question about the case.  Finding more clues gives you more options in questioning.  The question mechanics involves you paying attention to how the person acts, basically you’re trying to tell if they did the crime, had a part in it, or are innocent.  This mechanic also extends to trying to get information out of some people, i.e. do you gently try get more information or go on the aggressive and force them to tell you.  The better you do at questioning and clue finding will result in a higher case score.If you have trouble questioning people there are points you can spend to either narrow the choices or if you’re online can see what the majority did.  These points are earned through various success levels on completion of a case, i.e. the better you do the more points you get.The cases are divided into the various desks you work at while on the force.  Each desk also represents a promotion in rank on the force.  Due to the theme of the game some of these cases can be extremely graphic and like with the age and culture your dealing with the language can also be mature.Gameplay involves you or your partner driving to the scene of the crime.  If you drive you'll be able to do side missions, street crimes, that come in from dispatch while you’re on the road.  These street crimes are not the best element of the game as they mostly have you running and gunning down criminals, they get repetitive quickly.  Once at the scene of the crime you’re able to look for clues and get information from other characters (other officers, the coroner, and witnesses), from there it tracking down leads, questioning people, and the occasional car chase.Overall, the game does provide a unique experience and is definitely worth picking up.  However, you should buy the Complete Edition as it adds a number of cases that extend gameplay, without them, I wouldn't advise picking up the game.  The reason is because there are some desks that don't have many cases and the additional content adds a lot more meat to the game. If you don’t own the game and see it on for a 75% off or higher sale I’d highly recommend picking it up.  Game length would be about 40-50 hours if you do most or all of what it has to offer.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2013
												L.A. Noire is an incredible interactive experience where you play the role of a detective in a wide variety of different police cases. The first noticeable thing is the amazing detail of the faces. And this is important because it is the player's job to determine whether people are telling the truth or lying based on their facial expressions during interviews.The gameplay is essentially broken down into driving to different scenes, searching for clues, interviewing people, and occasionally chasing down suspects. It is really unlike any other game on the market and it does a great job at drawing you in. Musical chimes are used to let you know when you are next to something relevant so it is important to keep an open ear.The story feels realistic and is broken into shorter chapters meaning it's easy to pick up again after not playing it for a while. The acting is superb. All the characters feel genuine and it is obvious they put their heart and soul into their roles adding to that sense of realism. The game also showcases some great music as well. With 30+ hours of enjoyment, this is a must play game in my book.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												I joined the site when Steam made me an offer I can't refuse which is this game. Borrowed and played it on my Playstation 3 for a while and got bored but something about the "Noire" aspect and the era the game is set in drew me back to this title which is why I decided to buy it, this time on PC.After playing just a bit farther than I had in the past, I have to admit that I missed out. I get the hype and I get why people love this game. It has so much more depth as the story progresses. It is beautifully written and most of the actors involved are brilliant (kudos to the casting director!). The story keeps you hooked and if I  was a decade younger I'd be playing this game nonstop from start to finish in one seating.The graphic quality is not on par with its PS3 counterpart, it's better. It's a given that you need a decent GPU to run it and fortunately I got a pretty good one installed on my laptop. Control leaves something to be desired since the mouse can't never replace a Dual Shock controller once a game is optimized for said controller which this game certainly is. But it's still more than playable, just needs some getting used to when inspecting a crime scene. In many ways this game is just as good as the PS3 one just with more customizing options. Get yourself a nice controller and you might be able to enjoy this game more. It's such a shame that the game developer (Bondi) is shut down, we need more games with the same innovation they brought to this one. I mean, performance capture for games? It's absolutely brilliant! Hope other devs would look into the same technology and use it to make story-driven games like this one here.If you have never played the game or don't have a copy of it on Steam or what have you, get this game. It's a classic (literally)!

												L.A. Noire is a game released in 2011 by Rockstar Games and Team Bondi. You play as Cole Phelps, who just entered the police department of Los Angeles. You'll play as him, you'll have to solve all sorts of cases. Nearly all the characters of the game are really charismatic, and you'll love some of them and hate others. When i play it for the first time i was like "Well it just looks like a Movie-Game" then i finished it and i said "Wow, i need to get all achievements for this game !" So i did this, after 40 hours i got them all. If you play the game without trying to get all achievements I guess 10/15hours is enough to finish it, it's already a nice lifetime for a game like that. Once again, Rockstar prove that they can do something else that GTA and that the render is awesome. If you want to get all cases with 5 stars without any guide/walkthrough, i can tell you that you'll have some difficulties.. The game have such a growing difficulty, i mean at the begginning it's quite easy, items you need to find are easy to find, people that you investigate doesn't hide that much their expressions, but when you're at the middle of the game it's getting harder and then at the end, harder again :)As i said before, the story is really branching i mean, i was re-acting as the ingame characters, and the cases are interesting. If i had to rate this game it would be: -Graphics 19/20-Gameplay 18/20-Audio 20/20 (depends of you but, i loved it)-Accessibility 18/20GLOBAL RATE: 18.75/20 Hope you enjoy that review, leave a like if you did :P

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												L.A Noire plays out in the mid-20th century, just after the Second World War. You play as Detective Cole Phelps, a good hearted cop who was a soldier in the pacific during the second world war. The game confronts you with a time period where racism was rampant, drug abuse was growing, and violence was all too common. The city of L.A is one of the major stars in the game. Every street is full of life, with people going in and out of bars and shops, people reading the daily newspaper before going to work. The game feels as though its actually come to life. MotionScan, a neat piece of technology which Team Bondi created to capture the emotions of the characters on screen. It works splendidly, giving each conversation an engrossing hook that typically associated with great film and television dramas. When a character lies, you can see it in their face. Interviewing a suspect is the hardest and most important thing you will do in the game. You ask a question, listen to their response and then attempt to decipher whether it's a lie, the truth or something you should "doubt" and inquire further about. You don't only listen to what they saying, but you have to look very carefully at their faces as well. The slightest twitch in there cheek, or there eyes darting quickly to the left can help you uncover the truth. There is more to L.A Noire than just interrogation. There is a fair amount of crime-scene investigation, patrolling and beat work. At crime scenes, you are able to examine the victim up close to try find clues. You will walk around crime scene picking up all sorts of objects to see if they hold any clues. Outside of the regular story. L.A. Noire offers a few other tasks. You can explore the city and look for historic L.A. landmarks, tackle random side mission crimes as they come to you over your C.B. radio, as well as play additional DLC cases. Once you have finished a story, you are ranked to how well you answered questions, how many you got right, and how much damage you did to your car and the the city of L.A. The sounds in the game are amazing, with cars and busses going by, to the sound of the sparks coming from the electric wires as the tram drives past you. The acting is completely believable and really helps set this game apart from other detective games. The Verdict:For all of its attention to detail, L.A. Noire hits the occasional false note. But if you put that aside, L.A Noire can be a very entertaining game, with an open world to explore and lots of interesting cases, The awesome performances and great facial capture make every interrogation and investigation a riveting affair. L.A Noire is a perfect game that I would definitely recommend to everyone. Pros:+ Open world of an authentic and outstanding 1940s style of atmosphere+ Memorable story+ Great use of motion capture+ Compelling investigation and interrogation mechanics + Amazing graphics+ Brilliant acting + Amazing soundCons:- Some restrictions during pursuits and shoot-outs feel artificial- Can become a bit repetitive at timesScore: 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												As a cinematic experience, LA Noire is very good. It has a stack of content, compelling stories, great voice acting and revolutionary facial animation. It tackles challenging themes in a mature manner. It offers a large area to explore, built with great attention to detail.As a game...it's a mixed bag. The distractions - driving, shooting, tailing and collecting items - are nothing special. The core is the investigation - searching for clues and interrogating witnesses/suspects. The former is decent, with helpful difficulty options. The latter has its moments, both good and keyboard-smashingly bad.Two examples. A witness is asked about a document found in the possession of somebody else. There is no reason to be sure, or even reasonably suspect, that she is aware of it. When she denies knowledge of it, an appropriate choice response would seem to be "Doubt". According to the game, it's "Lie" - even though her response seems to confirm that she was unaware of it, making the "Lie" a strange choice. Even worse, there is another situation where you are expected to select "Lie", when the actual lie arises from the response to your challenge upon choosing "Lie"!The single checkpoint save is also frustrating. Realise you made a mistake (seeing witness in a certain order cuts out a possible question in an early mission, for instance) or encounter a mission-breaking bug after a checkpoint save, and you have to go back to the very beginning - 30+ mins of unskippable dialogue and driving.There's also port issues - a woeful 30fps, graphical pop-in and the like.For all that...it's still a compelling experience. As much as it annoys me, I keep coming back. It may require a new keyboard by the end, but it'll be worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												WARNING: Possible spoilers ahead, read at your own risk.Pros:A very well put together narrative, which catalogues the rise and fall of it's characters, in typical Film-noir fashion.Strong, believable characters with excellent delivery both from their respective actors and the awe-inspiring motion-capture technology utilized.Your partners. Their random banter and distinguished personalities are a joy to behold, they act both as the lancer and the foil to Cole's personality, and do an excellent job of playing off of Cole's own musings.Meh's:Lack of penalty for not upholding laws (especially when dealing with traffic), Cole can drive as recklessly as he wants, even right next to other cops without them giving a damn.The structure of the cases, especially between Homicide and Vice. In Homicide, you just finished solving a case that had made a mockery of the LAPD, and in turn, acted as a very rewarding end to that desk. BD would have served as a greater case to end the game with, although given the circumstances, I'm inclined to believe that the narrative was constructed before the individual cases, and that the cases merely served to facilitate Cole's fall from grace.Cons:The save system is check-point based, which is fine, until you realize you have to restart a case and lose an hour's worth of gameplay because the game decides to auto-save after a failed interrogation.Combat, atleast on the PC version, is rather finnicky and temperamental. The gunplay itself works, but the cover system is unresponsive and has baffling key-binds.All in all:If you're willing to deal with slow gameplay coupled with investigatory work and puzzle-solving, this game is right up your alley. It's not a masterpiece, but it will serve as the industry-wide standard for detective games in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Well, the game is broken. Most people can't seem to launch it since a recent patch, hence the many negative reviews. However, one community member, namely Nightbreed, found a solution to make the game work fairly easily. And it is reported by many members to work.You can find his solution here:http://steamcommunity.com/app/110800/discussions/0/366298942102103678/So, once we're through with launching the game (even though Rockstar tried hard to make it impossible), we have a nice game after all. There is noire, there are realistic facial expressions (which we have to learn how to read if we want to crack all the cases), and the story itself creates a nice atmosphere. Maybe one of the greatest trait of this game is that it's one of a kind. Trust me, there might be other detective games, but none other recreates the unique game experience that L.A. Noire provides. It's not action pumped, although it does have shootings once in a while, but instead it entrails us with well written dialogues, interesting, and often mind-boggling cases, a knack of humour, all presented to us in a 50's style, with a hint of noire in it.One of the greatest cons I could highlight from this game is a technical one: As it seems, the game is limited at 30fps, so those who have a keen eye for 60fps and beyond, might need some time to get used to it.Other than that, if we get past that tiny little thing, that the game doesn't start in it's original form, I could hardly come up with cons. And why would I?Fix the game, then play the hell out of it. Case closed.

												UPDATE: Thanks to Nightbreed, the game is playable right now. Full review incoming when I finish it.To fix launching issues, try Nightbreed's guide. Don't forget to rate it if it helped you! And, if you meet him, buy the man a beer, willya.


Problems launching L.A. Noire? Try this fix! 
A Guide for L.A. Noire
By: ƝƖƓӇƬƁƦЄЄƊ

			I made this guide because the thread I posted to the community forum seems to have helped a lot of people. With this information in the form of a guide I'm hoping that it serves as a better source of knowledge on what...		


OLDER VERSION OF THE REVIEW HERE***************************************************THIS IS NOT A REVIEW OF THE GAME ITSELF, BUT ITS CURRENT PLAYABILITYAs you might notice from a lot of recent reviews, L.A. Noire is currently unplayable on Windows 10 64bit, and perhaps other operating systems too.I tried all the fixes out there, checked the integrity of .NET framework (both 3.5 and 4), have latest upgrades and drivers installed. Compatibility modes, run game as administrator, run Steam as administrator, reinstall, check game cache, everything. Nothing worked.It just shows the loading screen after the loader and stops working. Windows Event Viewer shows an error saying 0x40000015 unknown application exception. The faulty module is MSVCR90.dll (part of VS2008 runtime, THIS IS NOT THE MISSING MSVCR90.DLL PROBLEM).Seems like the problem has persisted for quite a while, and Rockstar isn't too keen on fixing it (and has one of the worst customer support websites out there).This is the reason of a negative review - I am yet to play the game. If they fix it at all, that is.The reason why there aren't more negative reviews out here is that I was forced to farm "playtime" by repeatedly trying to launch the game to be able to write this time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												What is so amazing about a 2011 game and a love letter to old noire movies like "The Untouchables" and "The Black Dahlia" from rockstar and team bondi that puts you into the shoes of a rookie detective Cole Phelps? Everything. L.A. Noire is all about amazing you with its crisp gameplay, groundbreaking facial capture technology (at the time), and great atmosphere and setting.Set in 1946 Los Angeles, the second world war has come to a close and living soldiers have to make a living somehow. Cole Phelps decides to go into law enforcement, and the story ramps up from there, no spoilers at all from me, you just have to trust me. I bought this game on my xbox360, ps3, and now my tablet, (surface 3), and the game still manages to feel new to me. The controls on PC are great, I love the default control, but you can easily adjust and edit those controls in the options. You can use any game controller as well. One thing for tablets though, using the right click if you have no mouse gets troublesome pretty fast, but for desktop users it is fluid, no doubt.The graphics are beautiful, but the game is capped at 30FPS (I believe) and that might bug people, but you can always tinker with the graphics in  game anytime. ANYTIME. No more launcher people!Facial capture technology is what really shines here though, as it displays the emotions and "tells", (which you need for interrogations and questioning people at the crime scene). perfectly. The gameplay is fun if you like puzzle games, third person games, story rich games, or even just noire like games. The feeling and atmosphere as stated above is just incredible. Just incredible! It has.... Puzzle solving and deducing. Gunplay. Car chases and on foot chases. Hand to Hand combat. Tough decision making. Drivingand more.The length of this game is also fantastic, though near the end, I began to lose track of the story as I didn't like something that happens. I won't spoil it completely, but you'll know what I mean. Why was that necessary? Stick with the ideas you had. Not to mention, I didn't entirely get the ending, it is a bit underwhelming, and very unexpected.All in all though, this game is definitely worth a buy, even more if you can pick it up on sale. Here's to hoping for L.A. Noire 2 folks :)Get Cole Phelp'd

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2012
												Rockstar have done it again. They've created another game with a richer story than you'd get from a modern Hollywood blockbuster.They combined it with a new style of game. L.A. Noire tells the story of Cole Phelps, an LAPD detective in post-war Los-Angeles. While the game has the same look and feel of GTA IV and Red Dead Redemption.L.A. Noire's gameplay is completely different. Gone is the ability to shoot up the average passer-by; as Cole Phelps, you're a good cop in a world of corruption. Instead of pumping lead into the criminals, you now have to coerce information and confessions out of them. Suspects must be interrogated in order to open up new avenues for you to investigate. This game takes a bit of brainpower and skill in order to read whether your suspect is telling the truth, or if they're trying to serve you a plate full of stinking lies. Revolutionary, refreshing and compelling. L.A. Noire will keep you hooked as long as you can appreciate it for what it is.8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												LA Noire is a unique and fun game in the aspect of how it plays. The main goals are to collect clues, interview witnesses and solve crimes with a cast of very real characters. I don't mean this lightly, having worked in security and talking with LEO, the different characters are people you will or have met before. The game is nearly six years old now, but still feels and looks pretty modern. Casual and veteran players alike will enjoy most of the game. People living in LA will appreciate the games setting and take on a fictional 1940s. Don't come in expecting action like GTA, it's quite the opposite, but in a nice way. Think of it like listening to music from this time compared to modern tracks. Where I feel the game lacks is namely it's pace after a certain point of the game and it's main character, Cole Phelps. Much like Zero Punctuations comments, Cole comes off as a robot and for me I don't see much change at all. It makes controlling him quite boring after a certain point. Yes, he is a straight as arrow cop wanting to redeem himself, but he's so detached for most of the game it feels a bit akward and the few times he does seem to show emotion or connect, it's almost like filler. Lastly is the ending, I won't spoil it, but to me it felt lackluster and as if the team inteded to make a sequel, but got canned before they could. I still would recommend the game for it's unique approach to gameplay, but don't go in believing all the hype, because honestly, if they had made Cole develop as a character more, and the ending a bit more concluded, I felt the game would have overall been a fair bit better.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												L.A. Noire is a wonderful game with a detailed story. Its packed full of twists and turns at every corner. It gives you an amazing, detailed account of the past and takes you through one of the best detective mysteries thats been written. If you are a fan of Noire material, you'll get a kick out of this. Its challenging, detailed, and can get you at the edge of your seat at the drop of a hat. I highly advise this game if you are a fan of the old times, and if you're a history buff like me. I give L.A. Noire a 10/10.

												Fun detective game.  Before you engage in interogating or talking to anyone, search the area for clues.  You can back out of some conversation but once you blow it, you have to reload.Facial animations are incredible, like Deus Ex or better.  But I can't say they're as accurate, sometimes when I think someone is lying they're telling the truth, and when their body language says they're lying, they're telling the truth, or when they seem to be telling the truth they're lying, vice versa.  I'm not a psychiatrist or anything, just seems hard to tell sometimes.  You have a cheat "intuition" system that helps you deduce these investisgations, pretty handy.Locked at 30fps, can force 60fps with 3rd party software (Artmoney works).  Awesome at 60, facial animations a little buggy, mostly their blinking is too fast, so they look a little nervy.$5-6 on sale.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												The suspect was taken into the station. I searched the place for more clues. Didn't get much out of it. I went back to interrogate the suspect. He was with me on okinawa, he was never really my friend, but he wasn't really my enemy. I started with small talk about the war back in the day. But he's fed up and said cut the crap. So i started questioning him about the murder. He got no alibi at the time of death. It was a simple question, but a complex answer.Now the hard part, I have to decide. Is it the truth? Or a doubt? Or maybe a lie. I decided to trust him. And he gave me another lead. I went on with that lead with my partner. It was pretty convincing, so i decided to take him as another suspect and brought him to the station. While searching the place, i found the murder weapon and proceed to interrogate him. He gave an alibi. I chose the lie, and show him the evidence. I charged him, and the DA will do the work next.I went home, not to the usual place. It was a blue room, i saw an angel singing i always kill.  I was tempted. The next morning i went to the office, there's another murder. So i went to the crime scene, expecting a new body. But i was wrong. It's the same mark as before, the murder didn't stop. At that moment i knew that it was him. I went to his place and dragged him back to the station. He insisted that it wasn't him. And i said that's a lie. But it was pretty convincing, so i persuaded him to gave up names. He's a tough guy, he won't gave up his friends. So it must be on our unit back in the army. Just before i went to continue the investigation, the boss called me. There's a picture of me with the germans. My wife left me, and i got demoted. It was my partner, he rat me out. Then i wondered, who's really the enemy, and who's really the friend? I got caught in the truth and the lie. So i forgot the doubt. Then i doubt the LAPD, i doubt my partner, i doubt my wife, i doubt him. And the most important one, i doubt myself. I said goodbye to the angel. Forever.Then i went home to play L.A Noire.

												UPDATE: Thanks to Nightbreed, the game is playable right now. Full review incoming when I finish it.To fix launching issues, try Nightbreed's guide. Don't forget to rate it if it helped you! And, if you meet him, buy the man a beer, willya.


Problems launching L.A. Noire? Try this fix! 
A Guide for L.A. Noire
By: ƝƖƓӇƬƁƦЄЄƊ

			I made this guide because the thread I posted to the community forum seems to have helped a lot of people. With this information in the form of a guide I'm hoping that it serves as a better source of knowledge on what...		


OLDER VERSION OF THE REVIEW HERE***************************************************THIS IS NOT A REVIEW OF THE GAME ITSELF, BUT ITS CURRENT PLAYABILITYAs you might notice from a lot of recent reviews, L.A. Noire is currently unplayable on Windows 10 64bit, and perhaps other operating systems too.I tried all the fixes out there, checked the integrity of .NET framework (both 3.5 and 4), have latest upgrades and drivers installed. Compatibility modes, run game as administrator, run Steam as administrator, reinstall, check game cache, everything. Nothing worked.It just shows the loading screen after the loader and stops working. Windows Event Viewer shows an error saying 0x40000015 unknown application exception. The faulty module is MSVCR90.dll (part of VS2008 runtime, THIS IS NOT THE MISSING MSVCR90.DLL PROBLEM).Seems like the problem has persisted for quite a while, and Rockstar isn't too keen on fixing it (and has one of the worst customer support websites out there).This is the reason of a negative review - I am yet to play the game. If they fix it at all, that is.The reason why there aren't more negative reviews out here is that I was forced to farm "playtime" by repeatedly trying to launch the game to be able to write this time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												It's like playing a movie, in the best way imaginable.I've seen previews of it, and I was intrigued. I heard more about it and I really got interested. I saw someone demo it and I was immediately sold. This game is not for everyone, however. It has gritty visuals and intense subject matter. If you like the Black Dahlia film or Noir detective stories, you may like this. The sound direction is superb, and the music is very well done. Some tracks can wear on the nerves, but the action tracks put you in the moment.This game plays very well on Windows 7, but crashes do happen on occasion.Overall, this is a very excellent title, and the actors are superb, for the most part. If you watch Mad Men, you may see more familiar faces than just Phelps. This is a huge leap for in-game visuals, as the talking heads do look very good most of the time. Some glitches can be jarring, but they're few.It's a large game, and requres a lot of RAM and a very capable video card. Nevertheless, it's well worth the visit to 1940's Los Angeles if you want a good detective procedural.

												Worth reviewing for a lump of coal or a badge. However...Highly engrossing. Some say it's repetitious, probably due to each case essentially having you starting from scratch. Watch a whole DVD of that in one sitting and I'm sure you'll see repetition too.It was a very ambitious choice to mix a number of elements. Undoubtedly compromises had to be made to make them fit which I think were minimal. I also applaud their foresight to employ new technology and use it to create a critical element of the game (face capture).Finally the atmosphere is just great. So much polish, so much attention to detail. It feels a shame this whole world was built and may never be used again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												What is so amazing about a 2011 game and a love letter to old noire movies like "The Untouchables" and "The Black Dahlia" from rockstar and team bondi that puts you into the shoes of a rookie detective Cole Phelps? Everything. L.A. Noire is all about amazing you with its crisp gameplay, groundbreaking facial capture technology (at the time), and great atmosphere and setting.Set in 1946 Los Angeles, the second world war has come to a close and living soldiers have to make a living somehow. Cole Phelps decides to go into law enforcement, and the story ramps up from there, no spoilers at all from me, you just have to trust me. I bought this game on my xbox360, ps3, and now my tablet, (surface 3), and the game still manages to feel new to me. The controls on PC are great, I love the default control, but you can easily adjust and edit those controls in the options. You can use any game controller as well. One thing for tablets though, using the right click if you have no mouse gets troublesome pretty fast, but for desktop users it is fluid, no doubt.The graphics are beautiful, but the game is capped at 30FPS (I believe) and that might bug people, but you can always tinker with the graphics in  game anytime. ANYTIME. No more launcher people!Facial capture technology is what really shines here though, as it displays the emotions and "tells", (which you need for interrogations and questioning people at the crime scene). perfectly. The gameplay is fun if you like puzzle games, third person games, story rich games, or even just noire like games. The feeling and atmosphere as stated above is just incredible. Just incredible! It has.... Puzzle solving and deducing. Gunplay. Car chases and on foot chases. Hand to Hand combat. Tough decision making. Drivingand more.The length of this game is also fantastic, though near the end, I began to lose track of the story as I didn't like something that happens. I won't spoil it completely, but you'll know what I mean. Why was that necessary? Stick with the ideas you had. Not to mention, I didn't entirely get the ending, it is a bit underwhelming, and very unexpected.All in all though, this game is definitely worth a buy, even more if you can pick it up on sale. Here's to hoping for L.A. Noire 2 folks :)Get Cole Phelp'd

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												LA Noire is a unique and fun game in the aspect of how it plays. The main goals are to collect clues, interview witnesses and solve crimes with a cast of very real characters. I don't mean this lightly, having worked in security and talking with LEO, the different characters are people you will or have met before. The game is nearly six years old now, but still feels and looks pretty modern. Casual and veteran players alike will enjoy most of the game. People living in LA will appreciate the games setting and take on a fictional 1940s. Don't come in expecting action like GTA, it's quite the opposite, but in a nice way. Think of it like listening to music from this time compared to modern tracks. Where I feel the game lacks is namely it's pace after a certain point of the game and it's main character, Cole Phelps. Much like Zero Punctuations comments, Cole comes off as a robot and for me I don't see much change at all. It makes controlling him quite boring after a certain point. Yes, he is a straight as arrow cop wanting to redeem himself, but he's so detached for most of the game it feels a bit akward and the few times he does seem to show emotion or connect, it's almost like filler. Lastly is the ending, I won't spoil it, but to me it felt lackluster and as if the team inteded to make a sequel, but got canned before they could. I still would recommend the game for it's unique approach to gameplay, but don't go in believing all the hype, because honestly, if they had made Cole develop as a character more, and the ending a bit more concluded, I felt the game would have overall been a fair bit better.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												Note: Review based on console version. Don't let the low play time fool you!LA Noire is a wonderful experience in gaming. There aren't many games like this out there, which is a shame. Take on the role of a Police officer in post WWII Los Angeles. The city has been lovingly re-created with all the streets and famous landmarks. However, don't expect a GTA style sandbox; this game is very linear and all about the main story. Also, while the city has been expertly crafted, you won't be given much reason to explore it; no non-mission specific buildings are able to be entered and there is very little to no interactivity with anything in the city. Getting past those faults though, this is a great detective game with a unique twist. You must read the facial expressions of the people you interogate and make assumptions based on that. While this doesn't always work smoothly, it's super cool trying to read the characters and try and tell if they're lying or not. This game also has a great style. If you couldn't tell, it's a classic Noire style presentation and can even be played in black and white (recommended for that legitimate noire feel). This game is not for everyone. It can be slow and after finishing the game, some may not want to replay missions when they already know whodunnit. If it does pique your interest though, pick this up on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												I just finished the game and I'm looking for a word to describe it but I can't find any other than 'masterpiece'. I got the Complete Edition, invested 40+ hours in it and enjoyed every single bit. I am going to write some  pros and cons and I want to mention that the cons are purely subjective.+ Remarcably designed city and cars.+ Formidable and progressively complex cases.+ Well made characters and personalities.+ Tons of historical, cinematical and musical references. I believe the work invested in the game's documentation was huge.+ Educational stuff.+ Much attention payed to the details even if sometimes there are mismatches.+ Intermission movies.+ Great soundtrack.+ Jack Kelso .- Car control (sometimes). It is true that the game's main goal are the cases themself but the cars and the driving  constitue a substantial part of it. The cars doesn't feel heavy enough and the driving is really arcadish especially during some chases. I don't say that it's ruining the game, it's not a car simulator, but it was a bit disappointing.- Enemies never shoot you when you are climbing a drain pipe. - The gunfights are pretty much easy. Except for a few, gunbattles are not challenging at all. Taking less damage before you fall it could have been more interesting or bad guys with better accuracy.- Jack Kelso parts. Too short and too few. I loved that character and his side of the story and it wouldn't hurt to add a bit more of it.- The ending. Left me with many unanswered questions. I was waiting for a more detailed explanation of the latest events. But I won't give any spoilers. Overall this game was a great experience. I would give it a 10 for the design, 9+ for the action and 11 for the research behind it. Therefore I recommend it with great, great pleasure.

												L.A. Noire is a fantastic game. I personally give it a 10/10. Because it has a fantastic story that is unparalleled even in today's movies and books. The game play is amazing, and to be honest im gonna leave it towards other people to go on about that. I just wanted to put my peice out there saying that this game is worth your money.But also because i wanted to end all the claims of how bad a port it really is. Yes it is not the best port, but compared to  GTA IV and its GFWL port, it's pretty damn good. People saying 30fps is a con are just wrong, flat out wrong. People need to put it under a plus. 30fps is so smooth in this game, because the engine was NOT designed for 60fps. I myself have played about half an hour at an uncapped 60fps and i couldn't go on any longer, while yes it looks smooth as ♥♥♥♥, the driving is horrible, like driving on a ice skating rink and the brakes don't work, and the facial animations look worse.To fix the framerate though because it does have trouble keeping a solid 30fps. Copy and paste this in your command line in the launch options.-npd -str -nonvIt works for most people, including me.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												L.A. Noire is a game released in 2011 by Rockstar Games and Team Bondi. You play as Cole Phelps, who just entered the police department of Los Angeles. You'll play as him, you'll have to solve all sorts of cases. Nearly all the characters of the game are really charismatic, and you'll love some of them and hate others. The story is really attractive and you'll not stop playing this game till you have finish it. When i play it for the first time i was like "Well it just looks like a Movie-Game" then i finished it and i said "Wow, i need to get all achievements for this game !" So i did this, after 40 hours i got them all. If you play the game without trying to get all achievements I guess 10/15hours is enough to finish it, it's already a nice lifetime for a game like that. Once again, Rockstar prove that they can do something else that GTA and that the render is awesome. If you want to get all cases with 5 stars without any guide/walkthrough, i can tell you that you'll have some difficulties.. The game have such a growing difficulty, i mean at the begginning it's quite easy, items you need to find are easy to find, people that you investigate doesn't hide that much their expressions, but when you're at the middle of the game it's getting harder and then at the end, harder again :)As i said before, the story is really branching i mean, i was re-acting as the ingame characters, and the cases are interesting. If i had to rate this game it would be: -Graphics 19/20-Gameplay 18/20-Audio 20/20 (depends of you but, i loved it)-Accessibility 18/20GLOBAL RATE: 18.75/20 Hope you enjoy that review, leave a like if you did :P

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												L.A Noire plays out in the mid-20th century, just after the Second World War. You play as Detective Cole Phelps, a good hearted cop who was a soldier in the pacific during the second world war. The game confronts you with a time period where racism was rampant, drug abuse was growing, and violence was all too common. The city of L.A is one of the major stars in the game. Every street is full of life, with people going in and out of bars and shops, people reading the daily newspaper before going to work. The game feels as though its actually come to life. MotionScan, a neat piece of technology which Team Bondi created to capture the emotions of the characters on screen. It works splendidly, giving each conversation an engrossing hook that typically associated with great film and television dramas. When a character lies, you can see it in their face. Interviewing a suspect is the hardest and most important thing you will do in the game. You ask a question, listen to their response and then attempt to decipher whether it's a lie, the truth or something you should "doubt" and inquire further about. You don't only listen to what they saying, but you have to look very carefully at their faces as well. The slightest twitch in there cheek, or there eyes darting quickly to the left can help you uncover the truth. There is more to L.A Noire than just interrogation. There is a fair amount of crime-scene investigation, patrolling and beat work. At crime scenes, you are able to examine the victim up close to try find clues. You will walk around crime scene picking up all sorts of objects to see if they hold any clues. Outside of the regular story. L.A. Noire offers a few other tasks. You can explore the city and look for historic L.A. landmarks, tackle random side mission crimes as they come to you over your C.B. radio, as well as play additional DLC cases. Once you have finished a story, you are ranked to how well you answered questions, how many you got right, and how much damage you did to your car and the the city of L.A. The sounds in the game are amazing, with cars and busses going by, to the sound of the sparks coming from the electric wires as the tram drives past you. The acting is completely believable and really helps set this game apart from other detective games. The Verdict:For all of its attention to detail, L.A. Noire hits the occasional false note. But if you put that aside, L.A Noire can be a very entertaining game, with an open world to explore and lots of interesting cases, The awesome performances and great facial capture make every interrogation and investigation a riveting affair. L.A Noire is a perfect game that I would definitely recommend to everyone. Pros:+ Open world of an authentic and outstanding 1940s style of atmosphere+ Memorable story+ Great use of motion capture+ Compelling investigation and interrogation mechanics + Amazing graphics+ Brilliant acting + Amazing soundCons:- Some restrictions during pursuits and shoot-outs feel artificial- Can become a bit repetitive at timesScore: 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												As a cinematic experience, LA Noire is very good. It has a stack of content, compelling stories, great voice acting and revolutionary facial animation. It tackles challenging themes in a mature manner. It offers a large area to explore, built with great attention to detail.As a game...it's a mixed bag. The distractions - driving, shooting, tailing and collecting items - are nothing special. The core is the investigation - searching for clues and interrogating witnesses/suspects. The former is decent, with helpful difficulty options. The latter has its moments, both good and keyboard-smashingly bad.Two examples. A witness is asked about a document found in the possession of somebody else. There is no reason to be sure, or even reasonably suspect, that she is aware of it. When she denies knowledge of it, an appropriate choice response would seem to be "Doubt". According to the game, it's "Lie" - even though her response seems to confirm that she was unaware of it, making the "Lie" a strange choice. Even worse, there is another situation where you are expected to select "Lie", when the actual lie arises from the response to your challenge upon choosing "Lie"!The single checkpoint save is also frustrating. Realise you made a mistake (seeing witness in a certain order cuts out a possible question in an early mission, for instance) or encounter a mission-breaking bug after a checkpoint save, and you have to go back to the very beginning - 30+ mins of unskippable dialogue and driving.There's also port issues - a woeful 30fps, graphical pop-in and the like.For all that...it's still a compelling experience. As much as it annoys me, I keep coming back. It may require a new keyboard by the end, but it'll be worth it.

												If you are looking for a detective game and find the CSI series too boring you should definitely buy L.A. Noire. The game's set in 1947, after the second world war. The gameplay is set in an open world similar to GTA. You work cases, ranging from homicide, vice, arson and traffic as the main story line unfolds itself. You can play the game multiple times and discover new clues which lead to a deeper understanding of a case. You may miss vital parts or accuse an innocent person, or let a guilty one go if you don't find all evidence and process each crime scene. Definitely buy this game it's worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												More like a movie rather than a game, L.A. Noire is a splendid interactive translation of a noir novel, in particular Black Dhalia and L.A. Confidential by J. Ellroy (which I also recommend). The 1950 Los Angeles is immersive and realistically reproduced, framing a brilliant plot and a character developement worthy of a book. Interactive dialogues are the soul of the game, being also the key to conduct interrogatories and solve cases: for this purpose a very detailed facial motion capture permits to evaluate emotional reactions and to expose lies. Detective work is realistic and capturing, allowing personal investigation lines and always letting the player to deduce and judge in first person.Although cinematographic narration overwhelms the gameplay, L.A. Noire is another confirmation of what level of care Rockstar puts in his videogames.93/100

Let's Play L. A. Noire: Craziest Glitch Ever! Headless Game in Medias Res! Nosy Old Hag, No Head Bug 
A Video of L.A. Noire
By: Knave of Hearts

			Watch the rest of my playthrough of L.A. Noire, starting from Homicide department and cases related to the BD Tex / Black Dahlia murders:...		


Worst PC port ever, to even launch the game you need to find somewhere and download an old version of Rockstar Social Club, install in, back it up, let the game autoupdate it (it won't launch without updating and the last update doesn't load the game) THEN delete the new version and restore your backup. After all of that you need to set compatibility in the new back♥♥♥♥♥♥way for Windows 7/8 and repeat every time before launching... A hidden gamble is if it'll launch from Steam directly or from the game folder. It's like roulette, really! "Rockstar" can't do PC games and swindled actual developer (Team Bondi) out of money... even Japanese developers with no experience on PC make better ports. Never buying a game from a publisher with such a pretentious name, even on a big sale. Oh and it's so full of bugs it's barely playable.That said, the game itself is amazing. "Rockstar" games just needs to crawl under a rock and slowly die, since they manage to be a publisher worse than EA, Ubisoft and Capcom all together.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												Solid, interesting crime thriller, but with rough edges. Good things:-Paints an incredible atmosphere of 1940s L.A., with stunning historical detail. -Unique and innovative way of moving through cases based on being able to read lies through social cues. -Interesting companions with a lot of fun, banter-y dialogue. -Fun car chase mechanics - you can't run over citizens when you're a cop, so you have to restrain your GTA urges. -Really strong voice acting and motion capture.Bad things:-Driving AI is atrocious - other cars will swerve straight into you, and you suffer the blame for it. Also, civilians are horrible at avoiding your police car, even with full sirens blazing. -The Truth/Doubt/Lie mechanic can be a little harsh and often slightly unfair with how it determines a 'correct' response. -Slightly repetitive and formulaic for the first 3/4 of the game. -Roy Earle's existence. I'd definitely recommend picking this game up in a sale, especially for the thrilling crime atmosphere of a noir cop. At full price, though, I'd have to think hard about recommending it, because it often frustrated me, or felt a little too repetitive by the middle sections.
