number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9
												This game is absolutely amazing, allowing you to explore a faithfully-recreated long-dead Los Angeles in its 1940s heyday, while solving crimes and unraveling a well-written story. Remarkably, the developers managed to create a world that actually feels like 1947, rather than just feeling like a 1940s-flavored game world that doesn't fully convince you a la Mafia II. What adds to the realism is that the characters, particularly some of your partners, are astoundingly politically incorrect for any medium from the 2010s (although certainly a historically accurate portrayal of how people might have behaved).The face-replication technology creates, for the first and only time in my gaming experience, faces so realistic that real-life actors can be easily recognized in many cases. The only downside to this game is that the developer went under, and while they were planning a second game in this mold,  titled ♥♥♥♥♥ of the Orient and set in the political turmoil of 1930s Shanghai, it was finally officially canceled in 2016. I am deeply saddened by this and I hope that one day there will be a sequel to this game. Had a series of these games come out over the past few years, we may have seen a mini-revival of the adventure genre, but unfortunately this will stand alone, and in my case will be replayed every year or so.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												Pros:- Its Fun - Its a 100% full Noir experience - A very great detective game- The Graphic is amazing- The Story is very addicting and unexpected- The gameplay is great- The cases and objectives are challenging - The characters, map and objects are simply beautifulCons:- Can't do much on the streets, just driving your cars and visit places. You cant actually shoot anyone- Some of the case's inquisition progress are actually kinda hard, you really cant tell weather what option to choose, look through wikia for some tips.Conclusion:If you're really into detective games, this is definitely a Must for you. L.A. Noire tells a story of Detective Cole Phelps, a veteran who returns to Los Angeles and taking on work as a Police officer of the LAPD. Your main objective is to crack cases and solve mysteries throughout the whole game. Not only L.A. Noire allows you to be a true detective but also it gives you a full experience on the Noire world like in the movies: The Godfather, The Untouchables or Gangster Squad. I'll definitely recommend you to play this game.Personal Advice:- L.A. Noire is nothing like Grand Theft Auto, you won't be able to walk around the streets and shoot somebody, all you can do is just drive around and visit places. Just stick to the story, solve the cases, and enjoy the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												More like a movie rather than a game, L.A. Noire is a splendid interactive translation of a noir novel, in particular Black Dhalia and L.A. Confidential by J. Ellroy (which I also recommend). The 1950 Los Angeles is immersive and realistically reproduced, framing a brilliant plot and a character developement worthy of a book. Interactive dialogues are the soul of the game, being also the key to conduct interrogatories and solve cases: for this purpose a very detailed facial motion capture permits to evaluate emotional reactions and to expose lies. Detective work is realistic and capturing, allowing personal investigation lines and always letting the player to deduce and judge in first person.Although cinematographic narration overwhelms the gameplay, L.A. Noire is another confirmation of what level of care Rockstar puts in his videogames.93/100

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												CSI: Los Angeles 1947 style...Developed by Team Bondi, L.A. Noire sets you up as detective Cole Phelps. Unlike in previous Rockstar entries (ie GTA), you play asThe story is unique and has a few twists to keep you interested. You start of as a rookie cop, after returning home from army service from Japan. After a series of cases you move onto different cases including homicide, vice and arson. Gameplay involves a mix between evidence gathering, chases and combat. In each case, you need to look to look for clues at the crime scene. This will involve interacting with items at the scene (picking up and observing stuff) as well as questioning witnesses. When you intereact with items (e.g. bodies, cups etc) you can move the item around to observe them from different angle and therefore hopefully finding the sclues you need. Some of the items that you pick up at the crime scene may add no value to solving the case what so ever, so they would have best been left uninteractable to the player to save time.A unique mechanic to the game are the detailed facial expressions from characters. You need to look at character's facial expressions closely when asking questions to tell whether they are telling the truth, lying or you have doubts. If you choose truth, then you proceed in asking other questions. The lie option involves you showing proof (from the evidence you collected) that they are indeed lieing. The doubt option is used when you have a feeling that they are lieing, but you don't have the evidence to back it up. Furthermore, you may recognise some of the faces from actors you know.Combat is decent but not spectacular. You are limited to the weapons that are in you police trunk. Most of time you will have a shotgun in the trunk,but if you have DLC you can get the tommy gun as well. There is a cover system, so you can hide behind cover such as cars, buidlings and furntiture to avoid bullets and heal. Your health is indicated by the screen turning red and regenerates over time when you're not being shot. You can also pick up enemy weapons if you ran out of ammo. Combat is quite rare and generally occurs near the ending levels of the game during police raids or chases.During chases the aim is  to catch and interrogate the suspect. this involves sprinting at them and trying not to get too far behind. When you are close enough,  you need to aim your gun at the suspect for a period of time before you can apprehend him. Sometimes chases may be in vehicles,. In this circumstance, you need to chase and ram the other vehicle until they get stuck and therefore arrested.There is a free roaming element to the game, however your activities are far more limited than GTA. You can't pull out your gun and shoot civilians. You can ram down civilians during cases, but that will lower your score. You can't buy stuff either and there are only a limited number of buildings  you may enter. There are some random crimes which you can solve while free roaming the city as well as collectable items and cars. Otherwise your free roaming options are more limited compared to GTA games.The audio is fantastic. Music does a great job at settiing the 1940's atmosphere. Character voice acting sounds perfect as well.The graphics are decent for the time. Character modles may not look that great, but the city of Los Angeles definitely looks like it was from the 1940's. There are some noticeable landmarks as well, which you can find.If you're looking for a detective game that oozes with 'Noire' feeling and American 1940's atmosphere, then L.A. Noire is the game for you. However, those looking for a GTA game will be dissapointed.

Posted: March 20, 2016
												I hate writting this review because i did play this game on xbox 360 years ago and absolutely adored it!But i could not make this game run in a playable state at first and now i can't get it to run at all.I've tryed the command line prompts and compatibility mode, but it refuses to work in 1920x1080p in dx 11 on my main montior. dx 9 version ran the first day - horribly. sub 30 fps with frame dips while driving, uglyyyy textures. and♥♥♥♥♥♥draw distance. I simply could not stomach looking at this game that i used to love so much in such an awful light.It's a real shame that i bought this from a very popular steam key sight because i 100% would've made this my very first steam refund, and i'm not saying that to be a cynical twit. I know that I personally enjoy playing this very game, but there's a wall of non-compatiblity preventing me from enjoying it again. Wether it's AMD, or windows 10, i understand issues with older games can and do exsist. I just wish it didn't have to be L.A. Noire that it all had to cumulate in.Update - i've upgraded my gpu to a gtx 1070 since the original review. It now launches in dx11. alt+tabbing ruins the aspect ratio and forces you to switch to another resolution then switch back to the original that you want to fix it. After the first drive to the gun shop i've found the pop in to make the game unplayable. cars floating off the planet until the road pops in mere feet away. also after driving at some speed you can stop the car and watch light poles and benches pop in one by one. it's far too distracting to take the game seriously and i just have to accept its dead. Rip L.A.Noire (or atleast until we get a remastered edition).

												One of the best games Rockstar ever made? La Noire is about a cop named Cole Phelps that keeps getting promoted (from Patol desk then all the way until arson desk.) you can do it in color or in Black and White (I think Black and White is better for this type of game.) this game is like is like a lie dectector, but you have to pay attention to details instead of a machine telling it or no. when asking questions to witnesses you can choose 3 things when they answer, Truth, Doubt or lie. this is when paying attention to details comes in you have to see how they have say their answers and their face expressions they have also pay attention to how many times they blink or move their head all over the place. but without anymore detail about the game it's a true classic game and a masterpiece of a game. 9.5/10

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												I played this on the Xbox 360 when it came out and I loved it so after I built my PC I wanted to check out if it had any differences and whatnot. I'm glad to say it looks even better and the gameplay is just as awesome as I remember. I wasn't fond of the ending, but I won't spoil it for anyone who hasn't played it yet.Developed by Team Bondi and Rockstar Leeds and published by Rockstar Games, this is another gem for their vault. There is more than enough content in this game plus the DLC that it was well worth the money I paid. I've always been fond of police/detective type games so this was a good mix of that as well as action and great storytelling.The graphics in this game are well done for its time and when you're interviewing people the facial expressions are amazing. The storyline had me invested throughout the whole game and I was disappointed at a few points, but that's because it was based on what I'd say/do in those situations and not the main character.Anyway, if you haven't tried this game out yet I'd highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2013
												L.A. Noire is an incredible interactive experience where you play the role of a detective in a wide variety of different police cases. The first noticeable thing is the amazing detail of the faces. And this is important because it is the player's job to determine whether people are telling the truth or lying based on their facial expressions during interviews.The gameplay is essentially broken down into driving to different scenes, searching for clues, interviewing people, and occasionally chasing down suspects. It is really unlike any other game on the market and it does a great job at drawing you in. Musical chimes are used to let you know when you are next to something relevant so it is important to keep an open ear.The story feels realistic and is broken into shorter chapters meaning it's easy to pick up again after not playing it for a while. The acting is superb. All the characters feel genuine and it is obvious they put their heart and soul into their roles adding to that sense of realism. The game also showcases some great music as well. With 30+ hours of enjoyment, this is a must play game in my book.

Posted: June 25, 2013
												Америка 50-х годов, одна из моих самых любимых тем для игр. Обычно нам давали побегать за мафиози, и мы в его роли проварачивали всякие грязные делишки, постепенно становясь более искусной машиной для убийств.. В данной же игре нам предлагают примерить костюм защитника закона, честного и неподкупного полицейского в лице Коула Фелпса. Честно говоря, сначала игра мне не очень понравилась, все казалось через чур простым, но затем дела пошли более трудные, улики оказались спрятаны по всей окрестности, а во время допроса уже стало трудно определить, лжет ли ваш собеседник, или говорит правду. Сюжет в игре выше всяких похвал: он показывает нам коррупционную сторону правительства, да и не только его. Обязательно поиграйте в L.A. Noire и станьте свидетелем жизни обычного человека, который боролся против преступного, лживого, коррупционного мира Города Ангелов.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15
												8.5/10 Masterpiece. The game took 5 years to finish the development and you can see why as you play.The game invites you to a world of crime and do not hold your hand while you do your best not to miss any single clues or ask the wrong questions. It is surprisingly realistic when it comes to investigations, and if you enjoy crime themed shows, or enjoy books like Sherlock etc, this IS the game for you. Especially the intensive interview part of the game is unique and you really have to look into your notes (that you took while investigating) and read their expressions, tones etc to really hack the cases. As the game progresses the case gets harder and harder and it pushes you little bit at a time.Overall, the game is beautiful and well designed and the gameplay is solid and unique. Although the freedom part of the game is relatively inclusive but it is intentional in order to focus you to the police work.The only thing I dont like about the game is the fact that it requires quite a good computer considering the fact that the game came out quite a long time ago... but still, a masterpiece.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												Such a great game. The story, the facial expressions, the humor of it is so perfect. You play as a cop in the 40's and work your way up the ranks by completing the missions assigned to you, the game starts out pretty fast but gets slower by the last "desk". My favorite part of this game was the homicide desk because there was so much mystery involved, therefore making it so you have to search everything contributing to your addiction to the game. This game is great and I recommend it to anyone who is tired of playing as a gangster in the GTA series.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												LA Noire is a game that completely nails the gumshoe detective atmosphere but loses a bit on the overall narrative. Each case is about 1.5-2 hours long, and replayability is non-existant if only because by the time you finish the game you're tired of the simplistic mechanics. By "simplistic mechanics" I'm referring to the GTA style driving- and shooting-mechanics.Aside from that, the meat of the game is in detecting people's reactions to your pointed questions. The ability to see a doctor put his hands behind his back and suck on his lower lip as a telegraph that he isn't telling the truth is something that is very difficult to pick up at first but once you get the hang of it you start to really appreciate the development work that went into making it more about sussing out liars and cheaters than about reaction time and purchased upgrades. This game comes highly recommended also because of the way it draws you into post-WW2 Los Angeles: a city that is exploding with the popularity of movies and the pursuit of the american dream. The connecting narrative involving the eventual conspiracy scenario really didn't do too well to provide a driving force from case to case. The villains in the game seem very static and aren't fleshed out too well. As a result, actually finishing the game took some determination because you really don't care by the end.That being said, I highly recommend playing this game which is now super-cheap in 2014. There are quite a few memorable experiences in it and the concept and execution of the atmosphere is well-worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Basically GTA for the faint of heartPros-Unique Gameplay-Cool Technology used to make it, Motion Scan Techonology-Some Replay Value-Dark and Twisted Story-Open World (-ish)-Over 30 hours of gameplay-Feels like a movie-Noir feel to the game-Game takes a long time to finish, so alot of gameplay delivered-Dark but sometimes funny writing-Collectables-Strong Voice Acting-Can get multiple people playing in this game since they can discuss about which choice to pick during an interrogation-Vehicles all drive differently-Made by Rockstar :)Cons-Not like GTA or Max Payne, you play as a good cop, you must obey the law-Game randomly throws twists at you mid-game which don't feel clever or shocking-During the Arson desk, it destorys everything it has done to build up to an conclusion-Some of the driving parts, i just gave it to my partner because some parts the place you go is the other side of town-Cars won't drive out of the war when your siren is activated-Ending, made me sad but still it is a rockstar game so what do you expect?Overall, L.A. noire is a must play, you'll probably never play a game like this for a while or until they release a sequel. The feel to the game is truly unique and makes me click launch L.A. Noire every time I go onto steam. Even though parts of the game are delivered weak, majority of it outshine the cons therefore making the cons not really not that big of a deal. Even though the ending for me was a let-down, overall I loved the game and wanna play it again.Rating: MUST BUY!Final Verdict: 10/10Yes,yes there are cons in this game, alot of em but this is one of the only games that I actually WANT to finish. Normal games I play for 10 mins then just never come back again but not this game. I actually WANT to play this game and I regret nothing paying money for this game. You may think I am over-rating it but if you look at my gamelist, tell me how many games have I actually finished?

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												This game tickled me in all of the right places.  I love the period setting (40's, post war), the motion capture (using MotionScan) of facial expressions, the cars, the story...it all worked for me. A brief mention of a technical detail is necessary however.  The game is capped at 30 FPS and this can result in some performance degradation.  You'll read numerous complaints about it being a console port and that it's unplayable.  True it is a port, but unplayable?  That is completely unfounded. Now that we've gotten that out of the way...If you're a fan of film noir and the crime thrillers of yore, you will enjoy this game.  It is not even necessary for you to be particularly good at gaming to complete a play through.  While there is action woven into the cases, most of the time you're putting the pieces together or interviewing suspects.  Some cases had me stumped at times, but I found that all the more encouraging to examine the evidence, make connections and solve it.  My recommendation to anyone considering playing this game, don't be tempted to find a walkthrough to breeze through the cases on auto-pilot.  Give them an honest try and use what's given to you. Games have boundaries so use that to your advantage to make your deductions.  You won't regret it and when you get that 5 star rating at the close of the case, you'll start believing you're ready to join local law enforcement (I jest). I have to emphasize the MotionScan technology used to capture facial expressions.  This was a necessary and very impressive component to the game.  While interviewing suspects you have to examine their facial expressions and behavior to determine if they are lying or telling the truth.  It is impressive...I don't think enough people give the studio credit for this achievement.Story wise, I was intrigued by the fact that the story emphasized the impact of WW2.  I don't want to talk about the story too much as to give anything away. The actors casted for the characters were believable and well played.  I started looking them up on IMDB to see where I recognized them from.  In some ways it made me long for the days of FMV in the late 90's but I really loved the style and animation as it stood.  I read that in a potential sequel (not a direct sequel) to LA Noire, they may be working on doing full body motion capture with the MotionScan technology rather than just facial expressions.To further highlight how much I enjoyed this game, I even embarked upon completing the achievements and gophering around collecting all of the cars and film reels. Do yourself a favor, give this one a run.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												I remember an argument when this game came out that Cole Phelps was a weak character because his actions seemed unlikeable and his character was definately flawed. We see him throughout the game being torn down by his own past , we no longer see him cling to the ivory tower of hypocrisy we saw him in, in the beginning of the game. Playing as Jack Kelso at the end is supposed to make us feel like we made a mistake judging Phelps too early because Kelso is a character who is way too nice and lets others trample over him just so he can call himself an honorary man who lives for a higher purpose. But after the ending, you realize that Phelps was right to abandon his fortune for his passion, that there is no higher purpose but to live with what you want out of life and to chase what you want with reckless abandon. His mistake was joining the marines with this mentality and getting most of his men killed in battle and many more civilians killed. In the end, Elsa healed Cole but when let his guard down, he got the retribution he deserved not for commiting adultery but commiting an act of hubris that led to a long and winding path of death and misery. If you think about it this way, Cole was the suspect the whole time, becasue his warcrimes led to most of the game's murder cases.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Usually I try to finish the games I start as quickly as possible. I do the side quests, I try some achievements, but before playing any other game I try to finish what I started. That’s not the case with LA Noire: I avoid playing it. Why? Because it is in another league completely. The game is so good I’m taking my time to finish it. Literally MONTHS. I simply don’t want to end the story too quickly, I’m sipping it.The graphics are amazing, playing in 1080p with ‘quality’ settings and DX11 is an incredible experience. On the downside, there’s a 30fps lock, but that doesn’t compromise the gameplay because the action isn’t frantic. I find the game to be historically accurate as well. It definitely portrays the beginning of the American “Golden Age” (check the “Old Economy Steven” MEME for further references) in a clear-cut manner. There’s a “Bukowskian” atmosphere surrounding the setting and the characters (Bukowski was living in Los Angeles during the 40’s and both “Ham on Rye” and “Factotum” are accurate descriptions of that period). Coincidence or not, there’s a character in the game named “Bekowsky”...The characters are cynical, disillusioned, smoking drunkards, racist sexist♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the “noir femme fatales” shares many of the features of the male characters. LA is portrayed as a XX century Babylonian city packed with all sorts of lowlifes, degenerates, powerful and perverted directors and producers (L.A. didn't changed all that much, huh?). Due to its dedication to the Noir genre the game ends up rated Mature. This definitely isn’t a game for young gents. There’s plenty of nudity in some crime scenes, and the developers don’t hide anything, which is great, otherwise the game couldn’t qualify as a proper Noir-detective title.Since I have already established that this game is a marvelous piece of art, let’s see the cons:•	30 fps lock.•	Rockstar Social Club is required to play the game.•	The aforementioned Rockstar Social Club will eventually request your password, and you won’t remember it because the password needs to be 300 characters long, with 20 special characters, numbers and 125 capital letters. Why? Why??•	Every time you update the Rockstar Social Club, which is mandatory, otherwise the game won’t start… it’ll request your password again. And guess what: that 300 characters password you created 4 months ago won’t work because YOU WON’T REMEMBER IT. And when you request to reset it, all sorts of issues are going to popup. Seriously, you can count on it.•	Rockstar Social Club again. It’s useless. It’s dead weight and it’s sadistic towards the gamers. Steam offers everything a gamer needs, we don’t need extra-layers of crappy proprietary-software between us and the fun. It’s some sort of annoyance toll.•	Rockstar Social Club is worse than Uplay . There, I said it.Other than that the game is a 10/10.

Posted: February 9, 2014
												Just as advertised, playing this game feels like going through a serious of noir films full of action and drama.You have to hand it to the developers, the facial animations in this game is unlike everything you have ever seen, the characters in this game, regardless of how small his/her role is, are all done with the most top notce animation and voice acting that are just incredibly fun to watch. The gameplay itself, however, lacks the consistent quality in the animations. While at the beginning most of the cases are creative and fun, towards the end you start seeing more and more recurring themes and events that takes outo the freshness of the game. The city, while big, also felt a bit hollow as there aren't really much going on at any given time.Overall I'd give this game an 8/10, a truly refreshing entry in modern gaming

content:
Posted: January 25
												L.A. Noire is an openworld sandbox set in L.A., but it doesn't have to be. Between searching for clues and watching a suspect's face to see if they're lying, this game could support itself as a linear puzzle/shooter (although actually shooting most suspects is frowned upon). And it's not as if the open world actually adds much, the only missions other than story missions are "random encounters" over the police radio that let you actually shoot your gun and remind you this is a Rockstar title. But as I said, the mystery solving is superb! The amazing acting and mo-cap work shows through the small details in how a character reacts to certain lines of questioning. The game actually makes you think and put things together! The one thing I don't like about how the investigations are set up, is that it's impossible to fail. Other than the previously mentioned "shooting suspects", you'll always complete the level and catch the bad guy. You either figure it out yourself, or the game will spoon feed it to you, with supporting characters making constant comments about how "WE SHOULD MAYBE TAKE A LOOK IN THAT GARBAGE CAN I THINK". But if you're actually trying, they tend to shut up. It takes a while for an overarching plot to emerge as well, and I can't say I've completed it, but I definatley will.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Getting right into the end game now. Have actually really enjoyed LA Noire. The stories and characters are very believable - very maturely presented - and the facial animation is absolutely outstanding. There is a tendency for the formulaic which is fairly unavoidable with most games of this nature (drive here, find clues, interview her, next location, gun battle, etc). However I've been kept engaged both with interest in the story and the general challenge level of the game.Of particular note I've found the loving recreation of 1940's Los Angeles most intriguing. The sense of place and time is absolutely outstanding and well worth the investment. For achievement hunters, the achievements are reasonably constant and offer a good challenge with a handful that only the most dedicated will reach.Recommend it.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												LA Noire is a game that completely nails the gumshoe detective atmosphere but loses a bit on the overall narrative. Each case is about 1.5-2 hours long, and replayability is non-existant if only because by the time you finish the game you're tired of the simplistic mechanics. By "simplistic mechanics" I'm referring to the GTA style driving- and shooting-mechanics.Aside from that, the meat of the game is in detecting people's reactions to your pointed questions. The ability to see a doctor put his hands behind his back and suck on his lower lip as a telegraph that he isn't telling the truth is something that is very difficult to pick up at first but once you get the hang of it you start to really appreciate the development work that went into making it more about sussing out liars and cheaters than about reaction time and purchased upgrades. This game comes highly recommended also because of the way it draws you into post-WW2 Los Angeles: a city that is exploding with the popularity of movies and the pursuit of the american dream. The connecting narrative involving the eventual conspiracy scenario really didn't do too well to provide a driving force from case to case. The villains in the game seem very static and aren't fleshed out too well. As a result, actually finishing the game took some determination because you really don't care by the end.That being said, I highly recommend playing this game which is now super-cheap in 2014. There are quite a few memorable experiences in it and the concept and execution of the atmosphere is well-worth it.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Basically GTA for the faint of heartPros-Unique Gameplay-Cool Technology used to make it, Motion Scan Techonology-Some Replay Value-Dark and Twisted Story-Open World (-ish)-Over 30 hours of gameplay-Feels like a movie-Noir feel to the game-Game takes a long time to finish, so alot of gameplay delivered-Dark but sometimes funny writing-Collectables-Strong Voice Acting-Can get multiple people playing in this game since they can discuss about which choice to pick during an interrogation-Vehicles all drive differently-Made by Rockstar :)Cons-Not like GTA or Max Payne, you play as a good cop, you must obey the law-Game randomly throws twists at you mid-game which don't feel clever or shocking-During the Arson desk, it destorys everything it has done to build up to an conclusion-Some of the driving parts, i just gave it to my partner because some parts the place you go is the other side of town-Cars won't drive out of the war when your siren is activated-Ending, made me sad but still it is a rockstar game so what do you expect?Overall, L.A. noire is a must play, you'll probably never play a game like this for a while or until they release a sequel. The feel to the game is truly unique and makes me click launch L.A. Noire every time I go onto steam. Even though parts of the game are delivered weak, majority of it outshine the cons therefore making the cons not really not that big of a deal. Even though the ending for me was a let-down, overall I loved the game and wanna play it again.Rating: MUST BUY!Final Verdict: 10/10Yes,yes there are cons in this game, alot of em but this is one of the only games that I actually WANT to finish. Normal games I play for 10 mins then just never come back again but not this game. I actually WANT to play this game and I regret nothing paying money for this game. You may think I am over-rating it but if you look at my gamelist, tell me how many games have I actually finished?

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												This game tickled me in all of the right places.  I love the period setting (40's, post war), the motion capture (using MotionScan) of facial expressions, the cars, the story...it all worked for me. A brief mention of a technical detail is necessary however.  The game is capped at 30 FPS and this can result in some performance degradation.  You'll read numerous complaints about it being a console port and that it's unplayable.  True it is a port, but unplayable?  That is completely unfounded. Now that we've gotten that out of the way...If you're a fan of film noir and the crime thrillers of yore, you will enjoy this game.  It is not even necessary for you to be particularly good at gaming to complete a play through.  While there is action woven into the cases, most of the time you're putting the pieces together or interviewing suspects.  Some cases had me stumped at times, but I found that all the more encouraging to examine the evidence, make connections and solve it.  My recommendation to anyone considering playing this game, don't be tempted to find a walkthrough to breeze through the cases on auto-pilot.  Give them an honest try and use what's given to you. Games have boundaries so use that to your advantage to make your deductions.  You won't regret it and when you get that 5 star rating at the close of the case, you'll start believing you're ready to join local law enforcement (I jest). I have to emphasize the MotionScan technology used to capture facial expressions.  This was a necessary and very impressive component to the game.  While interviewing suspects you have to examine their facial expressions and behavior to determine if they are lying or telling the truth.  It is impressive...I don't think enough people give the studio credit for this achievement.Story wise, I was intrigued by the fact that the story emphasized the impact of WW2.  I don't want to talk about the story too much as to give anything away. The actors casted for the characters were believable and well played.  I started looking them up on IMDB to see where I recognized them from.  In some ways it made me long for the days of FMV in the late 90's but I really loved the style and animation as it stood.  I read that in a potential sequel (not a direct sequel) to LA Noire, they may be working on doing full body motion capture with the MotionScan technology rather than just facial expressions.To further highlight how much I enjoyed this game, I even embarked upon completing the achievements and gophering around collecting all of the cars and film reels. Do yourself a favor, give this one a run.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
PriceI bought the Complete Edition of this game for 5.99,- During a steam sale.Introduction L.A. noire is a Third person open world game developed by Team Bondi and published by Rockstar, even though there is a lot of instances where you need to use your gun, this is not a shooter game. You play as Cole phelps : An honest cop in a city full of corruption, murder and drugs. Later in the game you will play as Jack Kelso : a claims investigator for California Fire & Life, an Insurance Company. This game takes place a few years after WW2, Phelps was a marine during WW2 and is a little bit traumatized by some events during WW2. Graphics / Surroundings L.A. Noire’s map is based on LA just after WW2, with players given the chance to explore it next to solving crime. The Graphics are a little underwhelming for today's standard but they're still fine. The city looks amazing, with surprisingly much detail. The cars, clothing and people all feel very real, because of this unique feature called motion scan : They record people while voice acting with multiple cameras, this way you can make faces look more realistic and display emotions better. With this feature you can sometimes see if someone is guilty or is not.The people in the background all seem pretty real as well, talking to each other and talking about you (Cole phelps) For example : ‘Isn’t that the cop who solved that big murder case’.This makes the city feel a lot more realistic.AudioVoice acting in this game is great, especially Cole Phelps’s Character (Aaron staton, who you might know from Mad men) is performed very very well. Music in the car is just jazz music that was very popular around 1947 in LA, i personally don’t like this very much. You will hear News on the radio sometimes, This part is done pretty good.GameplayGeneralThe gameplay within the cases itself is very good, the rating system, the different characters, searching for evidence / clues, the shooting is very well done and the interactions between characters seem good / realistic.RanksYou play as an LAPD detective who will climb the ranks by solving crime : You start as a beat cop. You responds to radio calls, until you get your chance to prove yourself. when you've solved your first big crime as a beat cop you will get promoted to Traffic, mostly solving hit & runs, when you get to your last traffic case, you will come across your later to be partner roy earle, who is a dirty cop trying to protect an informant. Ones you have solved this case you will get promoted to Bunco (Fraud Division) and later Burglary (Robbery), unfortunately these 2 departments are left out of the final game. So in the final game you will get promoted from Traffic to Homicide, The five murders you will be working are kind of ‘connected’ : Based on the real life Black Dahlia killer. After you solved this case, you will be promoted to vice, where you will be partnered up with Roy earle, the guy who you had trouble with during a Traffic case. Cole doesn’t really trust him, and that seems right because of him Cole will be demoted after a scandal with Cole cheating on his wife. You’re going to get demoted to arson,where you will investigate a couple of connected house fires.CasesEvery day you will get a new case starting with you seeing the crime happening ( This doesn’t always happen). Then you will go to the crime scene to investigate it and interview possible witnesses. Then you will probably have some kind of a lead and from there on you will keep interviewing people, investigating houses of suspects or searching for cars on the street. After doing a lot of investigating you're going to arrest and charge a suspect, this sometimes ends in a shootout. Interviews / InterrogationsThe interrogation system works like this :You have 3 options to choose from.Truth : You think the suspect is speaking the truth or you have no evidence to prove otherwise.Doubt : You think the suspect is lying (Based on facial expression, or just on instinct) but you do not have the evidence to prove it)Lie : You have the evidence to prove your suspect is lying, you have to select this evidence.This does feel a little bit strange because if you doubt : Cole will sometimes get really mad for no apparent reason, This is because they changed this system during development.Searching for clues / evidenceWhen you’re at a crime scene, or a house of a suspect you can look around and you have to find clues, so you can continue your investigation. There are objects laying around everywhere; some important, some not. Ones you picked up something you have to look at the most important thing and focus on it, You will write the clues and P.O.I's all down in a little notebook.RatingOnes you have solved a case you will have a chat with your boss at that time, who is either happy or mad based on your result. Your result is influenced by the amount of clues you've found, amount of questions you've answered right, and the amount of damage you've done while driving around ( For example if you destroy multiple cars; your rating will be way lower).DrivingDriving is kind of  bad because of the 30FPS lock and general performance issues.But you could let your partner drive (Kind of fast travel), but when you are in a car chase it will still be annoying.CollectiblesThere are 3 collectibles : film reels, newspapers and cars.Film Reels : These lay across the entire map, finding all of them will get you an achievement.Newspapers : These give a little bit of background information about cole phelps and other returning characters.Cars : there are a lot of different cars, driving all of them will get you an achievement.StoryCole Phelps is an LAPD officer who was a marine during WW2, in flashbacks his history in the marine corps is explain, this part has a lot of influence at the last two missions. You will have a few different partners during his career, some he can trust, some not. The one thing that i found really annoying is that you have no influence at all on you  cheating on your wife. At the end when you’re investigating multiple arson’s you will find evidence of a conspiracy which includes your bosses, the DA, and other people, that are behind covering up a bunch of insurance frauds; houses that are being burnt down, for money.Performance / SettingsThe game is locked on 30FPS which is really annoying, apart from that the game ran just fine for me. A few lag spikes while driving is about it. Graphical bugs are there plenty, for example during a Traffic case you will get one big white thing in your screen. Verdict1. Must Play 2. Recommended 3. Recommended on sale4. Not recommended5. Don't Buy

content:
Posted: July 5, 2013
												L.A Noire delivers an exceptional story focusing on the exploits of a WWII officer turned detective in post-WWII L.A. The game efficiently blends story within story (past and present), via chapters that seamlessly blend together, efficiently creating a believable narration of one mans journey though a troubled time, and a troubled country. The game boasts amazing facial animation techniques, thus creating a greater range of viable facial contortions for the actors to express. The authenticity of the time is expressed in great detail as shown with the vehicle designs, the setting of the city, the music, and the people. The game boasts an extremely interactive environment in the form of interrogations, crime solving, clue searching (all being core aspects of gameplay), and in a most realistic way. Vehicular chases of any sort are exhilarating and finely executed (as well as the pedestrian chases), although general movement is a tad clunky, and unfortunately the combat mechanics are relatively mediocre, if fluent and stable. In conclusion: L.A Noire is well worth your time and your money, and is a must have for any fan of the mystery/thriller genre.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Many people think that L.A. Noire is something like Mafia but they are wrong. Those games have common only the age of story maybe. The biggest difference is in the adventure part of L.A. Noire, you'll have to find evidences and to speak with suspect people mostly in the gameplay. Though shootouts aren't frequent (just in optional missions and at the end of the game) and if you get to some they are boring, the investigations of cases are seriously funny and the system of dialogs is great. You have to decide, if suspect person says truth or lies at the moment. If you choose a lie, you must prove your contention by the appropriate evidence that you have found. You can make a pressure per person as well, if you are not sure. The storyline is higher than average and the surroudings of the City of Angels is very nice. I recommend to buy DLC's as well, there are the best cases in my opinion.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												This is one of those game that you must have played at least once. The technology used on the faces is almost in an uncanny valley kinda of thing, but it's still very enjoyable.As a detective in a 1947 L.A., that is pretty detailing and very accurate picture of the city in the past, you're suppose to discover the truth, see behind the lies of the all the suspects and find the one truth. And you gotta do that not just by using evidence, à la Ace Attorney, but also by reading the physiology of the person in front of you (well, it's more the face, and their expression but you get the point).Anyway, is a good game and with an awesome scenario and very interesting features. Definitely worth a try!

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												One of the best games I have ever played! LOVED IT9/10---------------------------------Simply brilliant piece of game art. There is not much talk around this gem but LA NOIRE sits up there with those Half lifes, GTAs, Mass Effects or whatever best game you know.It has such a great story, and great ... is GREAT. You are going to feel like you are part of a noire film from the 30's. I freakin loved that. It is so greatly written and it is quite deep so I experieced that feeling "I need to do something else but ♥♥♥♥in hell I need to know who killed that woman" and then spent like another 4 hours playing LA NOIRE.The reason why LA NOIRE is underappreciated is that it is quite a different game. It stands between Tomb Raider, GTA and Sherlock Holmes adventures. You are not gonna shoot everybody you meet and you are not gonna have an opportunity to do that. This game is not about shooting or car chasing... it so complex that you forget you are playing a GAME.Simply loved it. If you love detective style films.. you're gonna love LA NOIRE too. It just feel so real.AMAZING GAME!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Amazing Classic. Never played much detective games so story driven like L.A. Noire but this was my very first. Glad I played it.... But the frustrating optimization issues, lag, refusal to launch issues is really what degrades this masterpiece from receiving a good review. I ended up not finishing the game because it doesn't want to start anymore. Great.Pros:- Highly immersive- Very story driven with a 1950s theme- Enjoyable arcadic detective gameplay- Free Roaming L.A.- Dramatic cutscenes (movie-like)- Life-like facial animation & expressions- Diverse & influencial characters- 1080p support (for an old game this is a huge plus so thx for doing this)- Engaging casesCons:- Very poorly optimized (Newer OS struggle to run this game properly in its locked 29.97 fps)- Refuses to launch (for reasons unknown to this day I can no longer get the game to load)- Not made to be played in PC port (clearly designed for consoles)- Doesn't take advantage of multithreads/unable to run directx11 (stuck with directx9)- Have to spend too much time tweaking/finding fixes just to make the game work smoothly- Unrealistic driving - Forced to listen to copyrighted music (no option to turn off radio music or a way to separate game music from 3rd party music)- Interrogations limited to 3 options only. Feels dumbed down- Sometimes facial expression cues don't match with their previous statement, leading to a misunderstood decision during interrogations.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												First of all, at the time of writing, in order to get the game to work you need to download registry files from another copy of the game that DOES work... fortunately, there are very kind people in the community who figured this out and shared these files to everyone, so thanks very much!Second; this game as a whole was a bit disappointing. The unskippable cutscenes, indecipherable facial expressions and very linear progression are insufferable in a game that is designed to make you want to go over the cases again and correct what you did wrong the first time. If you get one question wrong, and it's the last question in the case, forget it... you have to do it all over as that was probably one of the most important questions (same goes for if you're at the end of a case and forgot to collect one piece of evidence at the beginning of the case). You can still complete the level with a good rating, with slight differences in how you get to the outcome, but ultimately the end result is still the same... Most of the time... It just depends if you're a perfectionist or not (which the game encourages, but why would you want to go through all that again?!)What did it for me was when you have to choose the wrong murder suspect on purpose in one case (yes, almost all evidence points towards the other guy, and it's not just my opinion, you are cryptically told to pick the wrong guy throughout the level and I only got the hint when I failed the mission). That is straight up unfair; all questions and evidence gathered and I get 2/5 stars for picking the "correct" answer?

content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												Rašysiu Lietuviškai ir Tikiuosi , kad kas nors atras ir bus įdomūs mano plepalai apie šį zaidimą.Taigi, studija Team Bondi po tėvo Rockstaro sparnu sugebejo pateikt tokį produktą, kuris privertė atsidaryti mano žandikauli ir su dideliu malonumu pereiti visą žaidimą.L.A. Noire tai rimtas ir labai stiprus reikaliukas.Mano nuomone tai kurinys kuris yra kaip geras dedektyvinis zaidimas /filmas, vertas aukšciausiu apdovanojimų.Pradzioje trumpai supažindinisiu su žaidimo istorija .Ji pasakoja apie dedektyvo Cole Phepls kelią link 1945 metų LAPD (Los Angelo policijos departamentas) aukštumų .Tikslingai kopdamas laipteliais link savo tikslo, jis patyria daug sukrecianciu įvykiu bei paragauja tikrojo kriminalisto gyvenimo.Gaudamas vis sudetingesniu bylų bei susidurdamas su ismanesniais ir gudresniais nusikalteliais, seklys supranta, kad kaina but geriausiu bus labai didelė.Mane suzavejo soundtrackas ir visas siuzetas kuris leidzia pasijust butent tikrojo seklio vaidmenyje.Žaidime turesime galimybe apklausti itariamuosius , ieskoti ikalciu bei vazinetis su senais gerais kadilakais.Taip pat netruks susisaudymu , mustyniu bei dar daugiau.Verdiktas 10/10

												This game is a blast, despite a few flaws. (Spoilers included)Pros:*40s/50s cheese*Phelps is an amusing jackass*Kelso is awesome and the ideal man*Dynamic with all 5 partners very hilarious/interesting*Nice facsimile of my hometown*WWII guns*Interrogation part extremely engaging and keeps me coming back*Extremely well done OST throughoutCons:*Game not designed for 60fps, so 30fps cap recommended to avoid game-breaking bugs*Draw distance kinda sucks*Can't really mod graphics*Why can't I free roam as Kelso on Arson*LA little barren for free roam outside of badge pursuit challenge and street crimes*Burglary would have been nice but noooooooooo they couldn't make it dlc*Slighty finnicky combat and cover mechanics*No ammo counter to track ammunition*Super abrupt ending

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												This game is the odd ball of Rockstar's games. Being a school bully, an ex-outlaw, a psychopath, or a gangster is pretty cool, but have you ever wanted to be a cop? Probably not. A detective? HELL YEAH! The game is pretty much based around crucial information you gather to reach a conclusion that normally ends in gun fire and a trip to the morgue. It has superb voice acting and story. I liked this game so much I spent months kicking down doors and shouting, "L.A.P.D.!" at the top of my lungs and scaring the crap out of everyone. So, point fingers (sometimes) and take names (literally) in this noir-ey detective game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Never do you play a game that has no clones, or at least not as good as it. That game is L.A. Noire.Lets look at the Pros, Mixed, and Cons.+ Very fun gameplay. I want to let you know that this game IS a puzzle game, but not as you might expect. You have to find certain clues, not doing any stupid pushing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. It's very fun and addictive, and wants me to have more of it. Also, there is some shooting and driving involved. However, if you wanted this to be a GTA in 1940, then you will be disappointed. However, you should love it, even if puzzles are not your thing.+ The Sound if FANTASTIC. If I had to rate this game on Sound, it would be a 10.5/10. It's that DAMN GOOD. The soundtrack is great and so 1940s! In fact, I noticed a lot of music from Fallout 3 in here, which also has awesome music. The voice acting is also perfect. It sounded like it could have been real detectives.+ The graphics are pretty dang sweet. The character models, especially their faces, are great. I never noticed bad lip-syncing, unlike most other games. I know there is one issue invloving graphics, but I will later address that in the review.+ A long story. It took me around 24 hours to beat L.A. Noire, and I was not rushing. It's fantastic well it lasts. However, well it lasts.+ Side Missions. They are not that good, but not bad either. It is nice that they added this, so this will not go against the review.Mixed:- 30 FPS capped. This would be a huge con IF it were not for a damn good explanation. So, this game was originally a console game, just like Red Dead Redemption (By the way rockstar, add it onto Steam. I don't care that it's almost 5 years old, I really want to play it) As we know, a lot of console games are locked at 30 FPS (Destiny, Fallout 4, etc.) However, Rockstar noticed there was a huge problem. The lip-syncing on PC was not good at all. They had a total of 4 choices: 1. Let there be bad lip-syncing, removing points from the PC review. 2. Redo THE ENTIRE GAME FOR PC, which could have taken a long time. 3. Make the gameplay 60 FPS, but the faces 30 FPS, possibly making bad lag, as well as confusing most people. 4. Keep it the same, but face there will be only be regular players who will outrage. I think 4 was the safest bet, plus it does not run that bad. At 30 FPS, it is fantastic. However, I still wish there was at least an option.Cons:- The gameplay gets boring a bit fast. After the 30th time of having a shoot out, it gets tiring. However, only the shooting. The interviews and car driving never get old.- This game has glitches, which might not seem bad, until I tell you. Screen-tearing, graphical glitches, and more are only uncommon, not rare.- Very little replay value. There is no second route, like GTA, Fallout, or Elder Scrolls. The next time you play it, it will be the same, which makes it boring. However, there is DLC if you can not get enough, which you would have to be crazy to not be.FINAL VERDICT9/10 L.A. Noire is a fantastic game.At full price it is worth it. On sale, you would have to be crazy not to buy it. I love this game and am praying that Rockstar will make a sequel, improving the games flaws.

												One of Rockstars best games.If you love films like LA Confidential you will adore this game.The game recreated 1940s cop drama so well and really brings you into the world.Gun play is solid and driving is like a go kart, which is fine.Interrogations are somewhat troubling as some of the 'correct' answers dont fit. Or a repair log stating the husband was out of the house getting his car fixed?Answer, the woman.Overall fantastic game and a great PC version7/10 : Pick up on sale-1 Interrogation sections-1 not being able to pick my hat back up-1 game only get good when you reach arson squad

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I've played some of this game. Not enough that I can give spoilers, but enough that I think I can make a decision. The decision is this: Wasted. Potential. In a summary, I'd say this was an elaborate point and click adventure. That's not a bad thing. If you enjoy your clicky adventures little on the easy side, then no-probs. It's awesome.Story is broken up into separate little "cases", investigating whatever crime of the day. This means even short sessions can be satisfying enough.The only problem is, it's a shoddy console port. Can't ever trust Rockstar in this respect. Look up. It was released Nov 2011. It even looks like Nov 2011. It's not eye-poppingly beautiful either. Maybe some complex (read "stupidly archaic and inefficient") shading, that's it. It runs horribly. Unless you've got a beast of a machine, you shouldn't be playing this game. Just don't. If you do, then go ahead. You won't get the top-notch graphics your machine might be usually chugging out, but you will get a completely unique experience.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Lie Detector: The Video GameStory: 23/25 Gameplay: 20/25 Graphics: 24/25 Sound: 21/25OVERALL: 88/100Well, you're a cop. That's new for this type of game. The story was pretty awesome with a lot of twists I didn't expect. It also shows pretty well how corrupt the police were at that time and how even the best men can do bad things. The gameplay was rather enjoyable. Running, gunning, following traffic laws until you get bored and decide to just drive on the sidewalk even though there's people there. Good stuff. The main thing that sets this title apart is the interrogations where you have to decide whether or nor people are lying. This is really, really, really awful at times. The graphics are amazing and everything appears to be from the proper time period. The sound is equally as good except I notice some reverberation or muffling with some of the voice acting. Awesome game, get it and its DLC.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Don't even think to compare this game to GTA-series. It's very different from some stpd thug-simulator like Watch_Dogs or GTA.Playing this game requires you to roleplay a detective of LAPD. Game is very immersive. City outside the buildings is vivid and alive. Graphics and sounds are very good.Act like a restless and proud detective. Drive retro cars carefully, stop at traffic lights if not in a hurry, embrace the atmosphere of 40's, listen to some flavor music while driving to settle your mind boiling with clues and suspects from current case. Interogate victims and suspects, look carefully and gather clues at crime scenes, don't get shot in firefights and get upperhand at HtH brawls.Take your part in ongoing plot.Interogation logic could'be weird at times, but doesn't break immersion or plot. Cases could be solved faster if you ask right questions and find important evidence upfront. This promotes replayability of the game.Verdict: This game is incredible if played right! Highly recommended.

												Pretty good.  I don't finish many single-player games as I am easily bored, but I finished this one.  The storey keeps you hooked. You can skip them afterwards (although you can find side-missions if you don't).  The city looks nice, but it is largely just for show (you can't interact with much).  The facial motion-capture and acting is the best I have ever seen in a game.  In fact, it's so good that it makes the rest of the character models and environmental graphics look stragely aweful (but they aren't really thad bad!).If you're reading this, I'd suggest you buy it.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												It's a quite interesting game with some unique gameplay mechanics and excellent facial animations, but...It is somewhat let down by horrible driving controls that are extremely over sensitive and the cars handle like tanks. All the movements in general have a really weighty, clunky feel to them, and there are many times when performing simple actions, such as climbing over a wall during a chase fail because you initiate it at slightly the wrong angle. Quite frustrating and difficult to get used to.The investigation mechanics are the only thing the game really has going for it, and they are great, but I can't help have the feeling that the game would have been a LOT stronger overall if it focused more on that side of things than on crappy gunplay and drawn out driving sequences.Probably the most irritating thing is that cut scenes are unskippable...So if you restart a case, you have to sit through all of the dialogue, then drive back to the crime scene etc....This is bad in any game, but in a game that relies heavily on story exposition it is pretty unforgivable.It does have an interesting story as well. Probably worth picking up in a sale if you are interested in the premise, but don't expect an action game, or rewarding gunplay, or enjoyable driving experiences.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Fantastic detective game with a very enjoyable story, characters that are interesting, some of the best facial animations yet, a wonderful creation of old school LA and the detective gameplay is a TON of fun. The game is not as open world as say GTA or Watch Dogs, but it goes for story alot more and also has the great detective work, looking for clues, interviewing people about crimes and trying to figure out if they are lying or telling the truth. If you want more story/character driven game pick this up, more linear than most open world games but the fantastic detecitve work, story, characters and animations are top notch. The game is capped at 30fps because of the facial animations they use, which might annoy some people, but once you play you will see it is not a big deal. Didn't have any crashes in the game and no big game breaking bugs. Not perfect but overall I had a blast on this game the two times I beat it. Not the best graphics ever but as I said the animations are fantastic and most everything else is well done.Looking for a fun detective game? Pick this up asap!

												This has got to be one of my favorite games of all time.  The story about Cole and his experiences really drew me into his life and made me care about his character. content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												This game is a must for anyone that likes crime drama or detective noir. This is not GTA. GTA is more like Saints Row which are both great games but not much like this game. LA Noire is more like Mafia or Hard Rain set in the post WW2 era but it plays more like a movie. So the equation: ((HR x 2) + M) may be a start.What the game lacks in action it makes up for in story. It will draw you in -I played it straight through which is unusual for me. While solving the main story mystery there are mini-games/crimes that will show up. Some of the mini crimes tie into the main storyline but are not essential. They are great if you feel the need for some action. There are also cars, badges and film reels scattered about that you can collect in a Free Roam Mode.The only issue I had was the 30FPS cap on the game which can make the game seem choppy at times but it doesn't ruin the game. This is a great game and I am looking foward to the next installment. I recommend buying all the DLC with this game before you play since it adds so much to the story.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I've only played through the first campaign and that's a story in itself.  It is a cinematic game akin to Mafia 2 which was an incredible experience.  The fault of this game is the confusing interrogation of the suspects and witnesses.  The whole lie/truth/neutral stance really makes no sense to me whatsoever because whatever I click, Cole's response is never what I expect him to say.  If I knew what he was going to say before I click it would feel so much better and probably give me more correct run throughs.  I also failed to pay attention to some of the characters from the larger story arc but that's my fault so the story campaign was a little confusing.On the bright side, the shooting and fight mechanics are awesome.  Driving around LA is great fun.  The world looks and sounds brilliant though it does run a little slow on my computer.  The dialogue and character interactions are top notch with excellent voice acting.  The facial expressions are a shining highlight and it makes those interrogations special even if I don't choose the correct option.  Don't get too wrapped up in the interrogations, maybe it's all my fault, but the rest of the game is good enough, especially for 5 bucks on sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I fully recommend this game, for those who like crime-solving games, games with mystery or suspense, or for those who enjoy the '50s noire detective/gangster theme. I myself enjoy all three of these elements, and so find this game incredibly addictive and enjoyable. The game is designed so that mistakes can be made during clue collecting (ie, you miss a clue) and interrogation (ie, you fail to call out a witness on a lie, or accept a lie as the truth) without a failure-state; it simply makes it more difficult to come to the correct conclusion at the end of the case, or it leads to a decreased score on the case. Each case has a very powerful film noire feel, and the cases are often based on historical cases from the 50s. You play Detective Phelps, an WW2 veteran who has turned to detective work for the LA police, and you interact with diverse, interesting characters, all with great voice acting and motion capture. To sum it up, there's not really any other game like this one, so if it appeals to you, get it! If you get it today, it's on sale for 4.99, but if you get the complete edition for an extra 10 cents, it comes with a couple extra cases and other DLC. What a steal!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I'm surprised at the relatively low scores here. I think this game is fantastic. It is what Mafia II was supposed to be on the storytelling/narration front. I'm normally very sensitive to shoddy ports, but this port doesn't seem to have consolitis at all in my opinion. I never played the console version so I can't compare. It certainly seems to control better than, say, Dead Space 1 or 2 did on the PC. The acting, story, and facial animations are world-class, and the facial animations really do raise the emotion of the scenes...you can see people's Adam's apples move when they gulp, for crying out loud! Doesn't sound very important except when you consider that much of what you're doing in the game is trying to find out if people are lying or not. I would say this is a GOTY contender if it weren't for the fact that Arkham City is about to come out, which I assume will dominate. My only gripe is that the cars handle way too well for cars of that era. They're very 'sticky'. It has worked perfectly 'out of the box' for me (purchased on Steam), no stability issues at all, except the game crashes whenever I quit. Obviously that is a non-issue, doesn't affect the experience at all because it only happens when I quit. I also don't have any of the frame-rate issues that some are reporting.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Now I haven't put much time into this game on Steam, because I mostly purchased it for the DLCs. But I have played this game thouroughly on Xbox. I have beaten the game 4 times, with 5 stars on every mission and have every acheivment. This game, in my opinion, is one of the best games of all time. Sure, this game definatly has it's flaws, but the story, characters, and world make up for it plenty.Pros:Team Bondi does a great job of creating atmosphere in this game. The storyline is somewhat complicated, but simple enough to follow. This game is often misconcieved as being developed by Rockstar, not published, so what a lot of people expect is action-packed gameplay with an outragous and funny story. This is NOT GTA, it has a very slow and methodical pace, which I personally am a fan of. The cases and investigation are extremely entertaining and will keep you guessing until the end. Granted, this is not a game that I could binge play. The story also takes some unexpected twists and turns. Ultimatly, this is a story-centered game.Cons:The gameplay outside of investigations is a bit bland, with nothing to really do in the world. Sure there are patrol side quests (and over 100 cars to collect which is pretty much impossible), but no other side quests or activities. It would have been cool to have something like a bowling or racing activity, or just something to make you more immersed in this world. The fighting mechanic is also a bit shallow, but then again it is not a game that revolves around melee or gun combat. The chase scenes are a bit pointless at times and become sort of tireing. Also, the "Truth, doubt, or lie" system as I like to call it can be painfully easy - With the characters you are interrogating making the most rediculous and uncomfortable-looking faces. Some may find the ending to be disappointing or unrewarding. WARNING: As with all Rockstar games, this is a pretty bad PC port, so beware of bugs and glitches.In the end, I may be biased because I am fasinated with the topics in this game. But it is something that left a lasting impact on me. A fan of old point-and-click mystery games or crime dramas would love this game. If you have the money to buy it, you should, because it is simply an experience that no gamer should miss out on.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												What an Incredible game! One of the deepest and richest storylines for any game I have every played. Not only do you feel good after solving a crime, but you actually feel like you are in the game with Cole Phelps and his partner. The searching of evidence is extremely easy with music and sound effects making almost impossible to miss a clue, but remember, not every clue is necesasary to the case! The driving is absolute perfection but I felt that at times, the car felt terrible for how far in the story you were (not a spoiler). I feel once you progress further, the car you drive should get better. The action mechanics are awesome, chasing down a baddy and tackling him to the ground is a satisfying thing. Though the shooting mechanics of the game take time to adjust to and some enemies take at least a full magazine of ammo to kill if it is not a headshot, it is easy to adjust to. The interview process of the game is extremely detailed, where a simple swallowing of saliva, could show the persons doubt. Make sure you look at your notebook and check every piece of evidence to make sure the accused isnt lying. This game has some small flaws, but are easily overlooked and one of the best police/detective games ever! 9/10

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												This game is freaking great. You take control of a paranoid schizophrenic patient who believes he's a detective in the 1950's. The entire game is a lie, and the people that you "kill" in-game are just hallucinations, as you actually are running around downtown L.A. like an absolute madman in "real life". I feel bad because there's this one part where you need to kill a little girl to obtain the secret information from the FBI overlords, and if you think that she's "lying" about her story, you kill her and take her papers. The reality in that is that you kill her in real life, and then take her kindergarten schoolwork. It's a twisted game that will leave your computer full of kum when you're done with it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
What it is aboutL.A. Noire is an action-adventure crime game played from a third-person perspective. There are cases to be completed, such as investigations for murder, to progress through the story. Inbetween all the cases, the player can roam in the 1940's Los Angeles to complete in optional activities, which appear through the police radio. Combined together, one can spend many hours to complete the game.The game is known for MotionScan, whereby the actors portraying the game's characters were recorded by 32 surrounding cameras to capture facial expressions from every angle. This technology is one of the important things in the game, as you have to guess if the witnesses you are interrogating are lying or telling the truth.L.A. Noire is capped to 30 frames per second (MotionScan is the reason for this), and the graphics, for a game being released in 2011, look kinda plastic and lifeless (applied to objects that are not alive). MotionScan does make the game feel a little alive, although nowaday's techniques let MotionScan stand in the corner for being the Ugly Betty.The available DLC expands the base game for a few more missions, giving it a little more time to survive the time you are playing it :-)In a nutshellL.A. Noire definitely set a new level for reality in 2011. Being beautiful, brutal, difficult and action-packed in one, this game is a must-play for every player that likes AAA-titles from previous years and for players searching for a temporary addiction!

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												This has got to be one of my favorite games of all time.  The story about Cole and his experiences really drew me into his life and made me care about his character.  The crime scenes are very fun to search around and look for clues, although when you're stumped it can be frustrating at times you can save up intuition to help you out.  The action sequences are very intense and can be challenging at times.  They do offer to allow you to skip them if you're having difficulty but where's the fun in that!  The interrogations are the hardest part of the game for me.  It takes a while to see how the different characters will react and lie to you.  The game is really long but I enjoyed every moment of it.  If you love crime/detective shows this game is a must buy.

content:
Posted: March 23
												L.A. Noire,A story written as an allegory, for the people who still enjoy games which aren't stuck on the level of mindless shooters, yet it delivers a fresh story sewn with love, sins of humankind, the filthy corruption of highly elected officials, and with great passion as well. If you want to have mindless fun with a game, L.A. Noire IS NOT for you. But, if you want to have a game which has a masterfully wroten storyline, with A grade characters, and with real life incidents, then this game is a must have for you.The game follows the rise and the fall of Cole Phelps, a "war hero" veteran who had been honorably discharged under mythical circumstances, who is quickly rising through the ranks of the LAPD, starting as a simple patrolman, but becoming a fearful member of the Administrative Vice squad later on.The game is based on the "Cases" which you would call missions. In these cases, Cole and his partner have to get to the crime scene after the briefing, search for clues, interrogate the locals or the witnesses, and occasionally phoning R&I for information regarding the case.These cases require sharp thinking and take a "certain animal cunning" for getting breakthroughs during interrogations, or simply just finding the right clue to lead you to the perpetrator. Your handy notebook will be helping you during the cases, neatly categorizing persons of interest, clues and locations.When interrogating a person, you have to choose a reply to their statements, those being Truth, Doubt (most of the time) or Lie, but in order to prove them to be lying, you have to choose an adequate evidence regarding the allegation. Facial capture being one of the game's key factors provides you hints of whether a person is telling the truth or is hiding something.The action sections of the game include on foot or car chases, shooting large groups of armed thugs, or simple fistfights.Besides the story cases, you can go for street crimes -  which are side missions -  such as armed robberies, "mental cases" or detaining people for being communists (laughed hard at this, but considering the year is 1947, it's understandable)If you're a bit bored, you can just go into free roam mode after completing cases on a given desk, and try to get all of the hidden Gold Film Reels, try to get all of the city landmarks in Los Angeles, or you can collect cars, and lost badges of the LAPD.The storyline is really well written and is sewn through several strings. The more you progress, the more of Cole's evil past, Courtney Sheldon's story, and the character development of Cole you will see. These strings will cross paths at the end of the game, and you will get the full picture (no spoilers intended). If you haven't tried this game out just yet, then you have to check it out right away! Wish you all a happy time detectives!10/10

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												At a time when narrative in gaming is constantly trying to find its own identity, L.A. Noire does a fine job of giving you the right amount of control amongst the very well acted cutscenes. The facial recognition tech hasn't been attempted since, and for good reason. L.A. Noire is constantly ranked amongst the most expensive games ever made - and it shows in the quality of the facial animations. I will say, though, that in large crowd shots, it is quite easy to tell which characters have the facial motion capture and which don't - and the ones that don't (i.e. equivalent of 'extras' in movies and television) do not look very good.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												L.A. Noire took me really long to complete with all the DLC, around 40 hours and it was hell of a run. This game was filled with amazing detective based mystery cases and a very distinct story line.The action was fun and amusing, chasing down people on foot and inside the vehicles. The gun action was also basic and easy to understand , from taking cover to blind firing your ememies or even just straight ramboing it.Taking the vehicles back to 1940's was a very neat idea, driving old cars was fun for a change wrather than the ones in the GTA series. They are over 90 vehicles and I only found half of them.The map is huge and there's just so much to explore.The main factor of the game is the motion capture of the face, the facial expressions were probably the most detailed and realistic I've ever seen in a game. When it comes to asking questions, i'm sure many people will get stumped or unsure on either choosing the "truth", "doubt" or a "lie"I will give this game 9/10 just because the ending wasn't how I wanted it to end.
