content:
Posted: January 3, 2013
												Pros:- Detective work and action scenes; good combo- Well laid out mysteries, things fit in- Very deep interaction with the events, even the slightest move can change it all- Dem faces and face tech- Atmosphere is engrossing and relievingCons:- Suffers from the controls of other Rockstar games; controller-specced- Choices you're given seem to "embelish" what they mean, 'doubt' means 'bluff'- Can feel a bit of a snore at times, you kinda wish the game would just get on with itOverall: 7.0This is like Pheonix Wright with a realistic edge on it, getting into the feel of a detective and working out all of the cases makes you feel accomplished and stunned with everything happening, but beyond that, there's nothing hidden behind the game, it's just that. The city and all of it's buildings, landmarks, inhabitants, criminals and suspects, all feel very appropiate and well designed. My personal peeve is that the story is too much "Harry Potter", why couldn't it just be about a detective, working with a bunch of different cases?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												L.A. Noire is built around giving players the ability to, as the name perfectly implies, unleash the Force. This is a version of the Force that really hasn't been seen anywhere before, with over-the-top uses of things like Force Push. When you go to push a stormtrooper away from you, he won't just fall over, he'll fly. You can Force Grip soldiers and toss them into oncoming TIE fighters, stab someone with a nicely tossed lightsaber that happens to be electrified for extra coolness, or use a good old bit of Force Repulse to shove a group of soldiers away from you and off the side of a suspended bridge (which will also result in the bridge buckling from the blast).When you first take control of Vader's secret apprentice, he's already pretty powerful with Force Push and Force Grip in his repertoire. But by the time you reach the end of the game, he's incredibly powerful. Stormtroopers that previously took a few swipes of a lightsaber to down now hit the floor in one swoop, and your Force powers will recharge quickly for repeated use. Being able to Force Push one guy off a ledge, electrify the guy next to him, slice down a third trooper and then Force Repulse all of their bodies off your standing within a couple seconds is flat-out awesome.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												The storytelling is OK, seems typical for the genre. The way they handled the graphics is very interesting and I'd like to see more of it in games. Searching for clues and trying to questions suspects seemed difficult in a way that wasn't intended. The gun fights were surprisingly ok, considering I usually absolutely loathe action sequences like that.However I think this game is a massive failure in one key aspect: I do not like the main character. I do not relate to them. I do not want to know more about them.You can have a successful game like that, but not with the way they told this story. The way the plot is handled, you are meant to think the main character is a Good Guy, wholesome and likeable. Then, as the story goes on, you discover - gasp! He might not be so good! A typical plotline that works just fine. But, from the very beginning, he is exactly the sort of person I hate.He doesn't interfere or hardly even comment when his coworkers mention despicable things. When someone is doing something immoral, his first response is to walk away and ignore it. Very "I'll have no part of this" - not a hero type, but an everyday type. Only this isn't a slice of life; we don't get to see the mundane aspects of his life, so we don't relate to him as an everyday type either. He's boring.Yeah. No.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
L.A. Noire: The Game That Should Have Been A MovieThis is the type of game that features excellent acting, story, writing, and dialogue, but is missing the most important element of any video game: good gameplay. Slogging through each and every case in L.A. Noire felt like an absolute chore, and the thing that kept me going was my desire to view the story. This is one of the few games where I was more interested in the cutscenes than the actual game itself.My primary issue with L.A. Noire was that everything felt very forced. I started playing under the impression that I would be filling the role of a detective and be forced to think and make choices with every seemingly minute detail possibly being important. That is simply not what happens. The game does not let you come to your own conclusions and it does not let you be the detective. Rather, everything has been decided in advance and you are simply shuffled along through the story. For every action you take, every choice you make, there is a right one and a wrong one. A good example of this would be accusing the wrong man. Let's say that, after reviewing the evidence, you come to the conclusion that person X is guilty. So you accuse person X. If person Y was the right choice, then your boss will give you a scolding about how you've destroyed the whole case. This makes little sense. It gives the impression that throughout the whole case, your boss already knows who is truly guilty.This becomes even more of a problem as cases start to get more and more complicated. In one instance during the game, I knew a certain character was guilty. Let's call him Bob. The evidence, combined with a gut-feeling, gave me the impression that Bob was my guy. Unfortunately, the game did not want me to pick Bob. The only 'right' choice I could make was to accuse the other guy (call him Steve). So I went against my own judgement and picked Steve. Later on, I learned that, lo and behold, Steve was innocent the whole time. Instead of letting me accuse the guilty man, the game forced me to accuse the innocent one just so that later on my 'mistake' could play a role in the plot.That is the biggest issue with L.A. Noire. The story is fantastic, but it is very force-fed and you are not allowed to deviate from it all. This raises the question of why L.A. Noire needed to be a video game to begin with. I would much rather have been allowed to simply press play and watch it, instead of having to work my way through its gameplay. I felt like an actor; like I was being made to follow a script.Another issue of concern I will speak to briefly is the control. Having to rotate pieces of evidence instead of simply picking them up is tedious and unnecessary. I found myself constantly frustrated by having to painstakingly rotate an object to the exact correct angle before the game counts it as being seen. The cover and fighting mechanics also could have benefited from some polishing. Many times I died simply because the player character downright refused to follow my commands.To conclude, L.A. Noire has an excellent story to tell, and characters with plenty of depth that are all uniquely interesting. Unfortunately, it is plagued by hand-holding and terrible gameplay. L.A. Noire is an excellent example of why games should be games, and movies should be movies.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Personal rating: 10/10Replayability: MediumBudget: Worth it. Lenght: At least a few days. L. A. Noire is one of the best police games out there. I'd love to see a modern game use some of the same ideas that were used for making this game a great "detective" game. The cases in L. A. Noire can be solved in slightly different ways, resulting in slightly different consequences through out the game, and the mechanics of the game function almost flawlessly. Combat, chases, interrogations, looking for evidence and just driving around in classic GTA 4 style (the game uses the same engine) is all entertaining enough on it's own to warrant a 5/10 rating. The game also has a great story, albeit very tragic (hence the title), and can at times feel like it's almost mocking how crazy Los Angeles is/was (no offense, it's just a very different city) in best GTA style, but it feels very serious. The characters in the game, and especially the motion capture that was used to get their facial expressions just right makes dialogues truly amazing.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Hesitant non-recommendation. More neutral if that was a thing on Steam.This game is pretty fun early on. Figuring out people's tells and searching for clues to use against them keeps cases moving in an organic direction. Each case is roughly 45-60 minutes long which is perfect for short stints. Unfortunately, the game starts to feel pretty tedious about midway through. You'll notice a cycle of find clues, talk to guy, find more clues, talk to next guy, talk to another guy, put bad guy away. Throw in some car chases and shootouts and I've described every LA Noire case progression. And that brings us to the biggest negative. You are a detective and yet there is VERY LITTLE DEDUCTION IN LA NOIRE. Seriously. You can't lose a case - you just get different ranks. But it's not because you as the player discovered anything. It's because you picked up clues that obviously lead to the next point in the case. And holy crap do you find a lot of matchboxes to lead you to the next point in the case.The overall story doesn't even really get going until halfway through. But by then the game has already worn out its welcome. This game needed to be 10 hours, not 20+ hours. Even though the individual cases in the DLC are solid, I'd avoid them because it makes an already too long game even longer. There is fun to be had in LA Noire, but don't buy this detective game expecting to deduce anything like Sherlock Holmes. You're really just a human lie detector that wins no matter what at the end of the day anyway.

content:
Posted: March 21
												I really wanted to like this game. Over the past few years I've tried to play it to completion but am just never able to. This is mostly due to the repetitive cycle of - drive to crime scene, find evidence, leave crime scene, interrogate loved ones of the victim (don't get it twisted some of the dialog choices have you screaming at them), make wild accusation (at one point during an interview with a suspect I outright called them a pedophile with no real evidence other than a book I found with some boy names in it), then accuse the wrong person and then move on to the next case and repeat the cycle all over. Don't get me wrong there are plenty of things to like about this game. The hat physics alone are pretty neat, and the face capturing is pretty cool, even though I dont think it works like they want to it. Its not a bad game, I just feel like it gets boring really quickly.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Tried my best, but couldn't bring myself to finish the game.Yes there are great qualities about this game that the majority have pointed out, and while I agree most of them, here are my reasons on why I gave up:1) Repetitive. There's a chase scene in nearly every case. And while I could tolerate vehicle chases, running after suspects on foot when they have like a 20 second tackle immunity (through subtle speed boosts) got really boring and I dreaded such scenes.2) Even with the innovative facial expresions that this game touts it was frustrating at times deciding between a doubt and a lie, a choice with 2 very different results.3) Long downtime. Call me impatient but I don't really want to have to listen to the conversation again and not being able to skip just because I backed out of an accusation, or having to drive from one end of the city to the other for a clue, only to realise that I have to essentially drive back again. In fact, the scene where I decided to throw in the towel was at a warehouse on the first case as Ad. Vice. I was operating a crane that took its sweet time lowering and lifting boxes and then moving them to a different position so as to not block the path of the objective.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												To be perfectly honest, this is one of the best games I have played in some time. The gameplay is fun, both the shootouts, the car chases, the clue finding and the interrogations, though a couple of the sequences drag out a bit. The story also is interesting, however it might not be the most unique or original out there. On the characters, not all of them are what you'd call completely three dimensional, but most of the central ones are very interesting and memorable.  But when it all comes together, it just works beautifully. The characters and how they interact as the story progresses, the cases you solve and the bad guys you gun down, the whole thing feels like playing through a really good crime novel or series or something. If that sounds even remotely interesting, I would highly recommend you to get your hands on this masterpiece.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												********** SETUP: ********** CPU: i5 3570k Ivy BridgeGPU: 650 Ti GTXRAM: 8 GBInput Preference: USB Xbox 360 Controller********** PROS: **********- Majority of the reviews I've seen on here bash the game for dirt poor performance, so I went in expecting the worst. Shocklingly enough, the game runs smoothly on my machine with absolutely no issues, whatsoever. Perhaps the people having problems have older machines or out of date drivers. I didn't need to mess with the command line or anything to get it to work. These issues could have been resolved through patches.- Game is fun to play, even though it gets a tad bit repetitive. - Facial features are AMAZING. Even better than today's games. This game has aged well.- Smooth animations and transitions; chases are seemless.- Has the best voice acting I've ever heard in a video game.- Excellent graphical fidelity and sound.- It has a black and white option where it applies a filter to make it look like you're watching an old movie. It's actually pretty cool, even though I'd never use it, so it's a wasted feature for me... but it's there.- Menu is intuitive and easy to use. All appropriate features are there, including the option of turning off mouse acceleration, which is always nice, as it puts off a lot of people.- Consumer-friendly price for content: I got this game for under $9 a while back including all of the DLC.- I'm not sure how historically accurate the controls for the cars are, but vehicle controls are decent and driving doesn't feel frustrating.- Character movement is authentic/realistic.- The game allows you to fast travel ANYWHERE via your partner.- There are 7 things to do in this game: 1) Do the main missions. 2) Do the short side missions that pop up when you're on your way to the main mission. 3) Collecting cars (95 total). 4) There are many landmarks scattered throughout the city that you can find. As you are driving through the city and pass by a landmark, it gives you the option of pressing a button to record it. That's it. 5) There are various newspapers (13 total) found throughout the city. You can only collect these during the main missions. It is not possible to collect them in free roam, which is kinda dumb. 6) Finding hidden badges. 7) Finding film reels.********** CONS: **********- No manual save. I'm used to games providing both or just manual. Having only auto saves makes it so you can't start the game where you'd normally like. I like to reload saves to do things I normally wouldn't do.- Cutscenes aren't skippable. Meaning if you mess up a few times, you need to rewatch them. - The game is fullscreen while cutscenes are widescreen. I get that the devs were trying to give the game a movie-like feel to it, but it ends up being distracting/annoying and odd.- Intros (starting up the game) are not skippable so you have to wait a minute or so for the game to load (game's file system is not standard so I couldn't find the intros to rename them to make them not appear. Google was not helpful). This might seem like a minor issue, but it is greatly annoying, especially including the time it takes for the game to unneccessarily check for DLC content, which it shouldn't check for in each session.- Even though it's an open world game, it does not feel like it because there aren't any reasons to explore the city. If you are driving towards a mission marker, you'll ocassionally get these "crime in progress" missions (can choose to accept/deny) where you stop what you're doing to drive over to apprehend/kill criminals. These are nice and varied, but they aren't enough to help carry the game (not that long, usually 2-3 minutes) outside of the primary missions.- This is more of an interactive movie than an actual detective game. I felt like I was just being led from point A to point B. A few cases require you to use your brain, but the game is pretty straightforward, otherwise.- The world doesn't feel alive. NPCs have the same facial and aesthetic quality as the main characters, but they don't do anything unique in the environment. If you bump into them, they'll say things, but their mouths don't move. The most interaction you'll get from them is if you run into another NPC's car. It's cool because they'll do the whole ragdoll animation and look injured.- You will encounter chase sequences of various kinds. I just wish that the chases on foot were better. For example, if I'm chasing someone with a gun, I would like to shoot them in the leg to incapacitate and arrest them. You can fire warning shots, but sometimes it doesn't work so you'd think it'd make sense to shoot their foot. But if you do this, the criminal dies, which is dumb.- This game needs a difficulty setting. You can tinker around in the settings to turn off hints and such, but certain aspects like the combat aren't challenging at all. You get infinite ammo, enemies can't aim, and your character can soak up an outrageous amount of bullets. Granted, the emphasis on a game like this shouldn't be on combat, but considering there are a lot of combat-type sequences, it gets frustrating to the point where these sequences become pointless.- Double DRM (Rockstar Social Club + Steam). Seriously? At least it's better than GTA IV's triple DRM. Rockstar claims that the game can run by turning Steam off, but the game wouldn't launch when I did that. Most of people's launch problems are from these DRM related issues. Just be glad you don't have to deal with GFWL, in addition. - For me, it's not fun to drive, which sucks because driving is an important aspect of this game. The novelty of driving through 1940s L.A. wears off fairly quickly. Luckily, Rockstar anticipated this and included a fast travel option for your partner to drive you to your location. But when you do that, there's not too much left in the game, as you'll be blazing through the campaign in no time.- The game is not challenging. You can completely fail every case and you'll still progress and get the same ending to the game. The lack of branching based on progression (like Mass Effect) is very disappointing and further diminishes replay value.- I didn't enjoy a lot of the side activites (street crimes were good). Most of these feel like padding, to be quite honest.- Lack of mission variety. Pretty much every case is solved the same way. The mission  where you are tracking down the serial killer is INCREDIBLE and had me hooked because it was something different and fresh. It's easily the best mission in the game. The game started getting good after the the 7-8 hour mark.- This is one of those games that I don't see myself ever replaying. What would be the point? You already know who's guilty and who isn't. It would be like retaking an exam when you already know all of the answers. When you replay the missions, you already know how characters/suspects are going to behave. You could try to get a better rating, but that's not something I'd want to do.********** SHOULD YOU BUY IT?: **********While production value and graphical quality are tremendous, they shouldn't decide whether a game is worth playing/owning or not, but there really isn't a lot to do to extend the life of this game. Yeah, you can argue that it has a lot of outside activities, but I would argue that collectibles don't count, as I consider them to be annoying padding. There's no multiplayer and, as far as I know, no plans for additional DLC. The campaign is fun, but not one I'd play again and the side missions aren't interesting, aside from a few street crimes you encounter, but those can be finished rather quickly. With everything that I said, I still would recommend buying the game with all the DLC on a sale, rather than the vanilla game, itself. Despite all the negative things I had to say, there's no denying the fun that I had. Go and get it!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
L.A. Noire: The Game That Should Have Been A MovieThis is the type of game that features excellent acting, story, writing, and dialogue, but is missing the most important element of any video game: good gameplay. Slogging through each and every case in L.A. Noire felt like an absolute chore, and the thing that kept me going was my desire to view the story. This is one of the few games where I was more interested in the cutscenes than the actual game itself.My primary issue with L.A. Noire was that everything felt very forced. I started playing under the impression that I would be filling the role of a detective and be forced to think and make choices with every seemingly minute detail possibly being important. That is simply not what happens. The game does not let you come to your own conclusions and it does not let you be the detective. Rather, everything has been decided in advance and you are simply shuffled along through the story. For every action you take, every choice you make, there is a right one and a wrong one. A good example of this would be accusing the wrong man. Let's say that, after reviewing the evidence, you come to the conclusion that person X is guilty. So you accuse person X. If person Y was the right choice, then your boss will give you a scolding about how you've destroyed the whole case. This makes little sense. It gives the impression that throughout the whole case, your boss already knows who is truly guilty.This becomes even more of a problem as cases start to get more and more complicated. In one instance during the game, I knew a certain character was guilty. Let's call him Bob. The evidence, combined with a gut-feeling, gave me the impression that Bob was my guy. Unfortunately, the game did not want me to pick Bob. The only 'right' choice I could make was to accuse the other guy (call him Steve). So I went against my own judgement and picked Steve. Later on, I learned that, lo and behold, Steve was innocent the whole time. Instead of letting me accuse the guilty man, the game forced me to accuse the innocent one just so that later on my 'mistake' could play a role in the plot.That is the biggest issue with L.A. Noire. The story is fantastic, but it is very force-fed and you are not allowed to deviate from it all. This raises the question of why L.A. Noire needed to be a video game to begin with. I would much rather have been allowed to simply press play and watch it, instead of having to work my way through its gameplay. I felt like an actor; like I was being made to follow a script.Another issue of concern I will speak to briefly is the control. Having to rotate pieces of evidence instead of simply picking them up is tedious and unnecessary. I found myself constantly frustrated by having to painstakingly rotate an object to the exact correct angle before the game counts it as being seen. The cover and fighting mechanics also could have benefited from some polishing. Many times I died simply because the player character downright refused to follow my commands.To conclude, L.A. Noire has an excellent story to tell, and characters with plenty of depth that are all uniquely interesting. Unfortunately, it is plagued by hand-holding and terrible gameplay. L.A. Noire is an excellent example of why games should be games, and movies should be movies.

Posted: March 16, 2012
												An ambitious game probably too ambitious for it's own good. There's no real rhyme or reason to the interogations at times. turning the game into a multiple choice test you didn't study for. The world, though it feels alive, is lackluster visually, the cars handle acceptable, and the gunplay can be fun at times but is usually boring. On the positive, the game has a great setting and is quite lengthy; adding in the DLC there is a lot of game to go around. The facial animation works wonderfully, but can leave the player baffled and frustrated without a "baseline" to go by.All in all, a severe disappointment that does have some enjoyment to be found. But, it's most definitely not worth more than $20.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												(Minor spoilers) This game is awful. Interrogations make no sense. People with no reason to lie regularly withhold information, all you really have to go on is facial expressions. And it's so stupidly easy to interpret them how the game wants, there is zero intrigue. Interviewee looks at the ground or eyes dart back and forth? Even if it happens only once and you believe the statement, doubt what he's saying.  Which leads to my next complaint - Half the time, the truth and doubt options are completely arbitrary, whatever you choose, your guy yells at and or calls the interviewee a liar, prompting the interviewee to complete the statement that you chose to believe or doubt before it was really even finished. And you would think that any and all information in a case would be available to present to suspects etc. But no. For example, while questioning a man about the last time he saw his wife, there is no way to pick at his statement about things getting "out of hand" before he left, despite the fact that a neighbor has told you that she saw a black eye on the wife after the fight. But at other times, you're expected to doubt a 15 year old girl who just found out her mother died, when she tells you she never really payed attention to the jewerely her mother wore. You have no reason at all to doubt this-you just met the girl and all you know is that the mother has had jewerly forcibly removed from her body and there's no trace of it in the home. And if you do choose the right answer, and doubt, she'll go on to tell you exactly what her mother wears in what is essentialy worded as the second half of her statement, as if your prodding jogged her memory. If you select truth, you suffer the wrong answer penalty and the girl doesn't tell you about her mom's jewerly. So often a characters tone will be totally out of context. You snap at just about anyone for anything. Half the time you select truth, you still call the person out for lying and or withholding something. The overarching story and my respect for Phelps as a character is ruined by moments like the one in a flashback to WWII in which he's shown defending the Japanese attack on pearl harbor: 'What would we do if another country cut off gas to run OUR cars?' Which is just stupid, considering the oil embargo was a result of Japan's imperialism. A game about solving mysteries face to face is devoid of logic and natural human reactions.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												L.A. Noire was one of the best games I have ever played, and that's why I am writing this review. Along with a tremendous and accruate representation of the 1940's Los Angeles, it has a wonderful and suspensful story. The graphics are on par for its time, and the gameplay is well done, although there is better. I would like to note, that I have not actually spent 100+ hours on this game, I just left it open (whoops) and it has about a 20 hour campaign, thats not including all of the street crimes and side "missions" to do in the game. It's a game I thoroughly enjoyed and I would recommend that everyone buy it with the DLC pack.8/10EDIT:I have returned to this game after about 1 year of not playing it, and something is really bothering me. I am just now realizing that this game is locked to 30 FPS. That is a shame. It drags performance down and really brings the game quality down. This disapointment has brought my rating down to an 8. This is still a great game, still worth buying, but the engine is a disapointment.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Ok, so L.A. Noire, you probably heard of it. It's that game with the best facial animations, it uses MotionScan technology. It's the game's most prominent feature. L.A.Noire will take you through career of Cole Phelps, ex marine, who now works at LAPD. This means there is driving in what was meant to be near perfect recreation of LA (I can't judge this since I was never to LA, not to mention LA of 1947), shooting and investigation, which is the main focus of the game, involved. During your investigations you will be searching for clues, which may or may not be of further use to you but they all add to your rating that is given to you at the end of each case, and interview suspects & witnesses. This is where MotionScan comes to play, you will have to read expressions of a interviewed person to figure out whether he/she is lying, telling the truth or simply withholding something.Storywise it is decent, there are some decisions which are odd and questionable. Some of the cases just feel wrong if you look on them on their own, but I don't want to potentionaly spoil anything so I won't go into details. The game is linear so even tho you may know from where the wind blows you are still forced to do thing you may not like in order to progress. Other than the main cases there are some street crimes, which mainly involves shooting, and few collectibles. Overall feel is good, I enjoyed my time I spent as LAPD investigator.Only problem I had with the game, other than plot of certain cases, was low FPS I experienced at first. According to forums Multi-threading and DX9 were to blame so I changed these options in launcher.And at last, don't expect GTA experience from this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												I remember when this game first came out, and it's been one of my favorite games ever since.  It's not for everyone, no doubt about that.  If you're a big Rockstar fan for the violence this game is probably not for you.  You wont be meeting up with hookers, shooting down choppers, or seeing how many pedestrians you can run over before your car explodes.  In LA Noire you play a cop in (you guessed it) LA during the 1940s.  Your primary goal is solving crimes through clues and interogations, then putting the peices together to figure out who the criminal is.  Sounds easy, it's not really (in my opinion).  You can easily miss a clue or get a question wrong that will ruin your case.  Finished cases can be replayed which is nice, giving this game a decent amount of replay value (but not a ton).Graphics - 7/10 - they are good but compared to new games they can't hold up obviously, no fault on the games side.Sound - 10/10 - personally I love the old timey music they play, it sets the tone perfectly, the game would be flawed without it.Controls - 7/10 - I highly recommend a controller.  Finding clues can be tough.  Hardest thing is driving in this game, other drivers just hate to get out of your way, and accidents hurt your overall score.Story - 9/10 - It's basically a big mystery game, with just enough twists and turns.  I'm sure the story is not 100% accurate history wise, but a fair amount of stuff comes from real life situations.  Old LA landmarks, the black dhalia murders, the spruce goose, and many more I'm sure.  It just helps tie the story together so well, you really feel like it's the 40's when you're playing this game.Overall - 8/10 - Decent replay factor as it's unlikely you'll beat more then a mission or two and get everything 100% correct.  The DLC also helps in regards to replay.  After playing this game for too long, I find myself so enthralled that I feel like a detective, sometimes figuring out where I last left my beer (usually I drank it)!I hope you find my review helpful!!!  At this time LA Noire w/ DLC sells for $30, a little high in my opinion, I waited for a sale, but I'm both cheap and patient.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												L.A. Noire was one of the best games I have ever played, and that's why I am writing this review. Along with a tremendous and accruate representation of the 1940's Los Angeles, it has a wonderful and suspensful story. The graphics are on par for its time, and the gameplay is well done, although there is better. I would like to note, that I have not actually spent 100+ hours on this game, I just left it open (whoops) and it has about a 20 hour campaign, thats not including all of the street crimes and side "missions" to do in the game. It's a game I thoroughly enjoyed and I would recommend that everyone buy it with the DLC pack.8/10EDIT:I have returned to this game after about 1 year of not playing it, and something is really bothering me. I am just now realizing that this game is locked to 30 FPS. That is a shame. It drags performance down and really brings the game quality down. This disapointment has brought my rating down to an 8. This is still a great game, still worth buying, but the engine is a disapointment.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												With all the slow burning ambiance of a point and click you'd be forgiven for thinking LA Noire wasnt a good game but you would be wrong. I wouldnt say this game would appeal to every gamer but those that like diversity will like LA noire.Set in the 1940s you play out the saga of a police officer rising through the ranks while busting chumps. You get a nice variety of crime to handle although the main theme and premise to the whole game is out and out deceit. These well scripted lies lend to the games points system and although not essential to completeing the game itself, certainly enriches the experience and feel of what the creator intended for us.As good as LA Noire maybe its not all sweetness and light though, like yet again we get a large playground with very little in it even with the DLCs, the car chases/driving feel early years GTA, Woody from toystory has nothing on our characters motor skills and the gun battles are no mafia 2 moment i can tell you. The good news is however, these arent bad enough to be deal breakers.So get out their officers, handle the crime and bag the perps ASAP, LAs counting on you son.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Great game, though it didn't port well to the PC.  A series of small glitches add up.  Frame rate lags, moments where Cole Phelps gets immobilized, unpredictable and imprecise driving controls (in a game where car damage brings down your score), poor menu controls (switching between mouse & keyboard), un-skippable cutscenes (for when you are re-trying a crime scene for the nth time).  It amounts to a bunch of issues that should have been resolved with a few decent beta-testers, but it seems the developers simply pushed it to get to the PC too fast.  The game is sometimes unclear on how to succeed: in interrogations, the subject gives a statement that cannot be true or false, so asking whether he's lying or not is aggravating.  Otherwise, though, the cases are well written and engaging.  The story moves well.  The environment is fantastically realized, especially the cars and the radio entertainment.  Some problems with uncanny valley effects, but I won't blame the developers for that.  I'd give it an 8.5 (higher but for glitches).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Ok, so L.A. Noire, you probably heard of it. It's that game with the best facial animations, it uses MotionScan technology. It's the game's most prominent feature. L.A.Noire will take you through career of Cole Phelps, ex marine, who now works at LAPD. This means there is driving in what was meant to be near perfect recreation of LA (I can't judge this since I was never to LA, not to mention LA of 1947), shooting and investigation, which is the main focus of the game, involved. During your investigations you will be searching for clues, which may or may not be of further use to you but they all add to your rating that is given to you at the end of each case, and interview suspects & witnesses. This is where MotionScan comes to play, you will have to read expressions of a interviewed person to figure out whether he/she is lying, telling the truth or simply withholding something.Storywise it is decent, there are some decisions which are odd and questionable. Some of the cases just feel wrong if you look on them on their own, but I don't want to potentionaly spoil anything so I won't go into details. The game is linear so even tho you may know from where the wind blows you are still forced to do thing you may not like in order to progress. Other than the main cases there are some street crimes, which mainly involves shooting, and few collectibles. Overall feel is good, I enjoyed my time I spent as LAPD investigator.Only problem I had with the game, other than plot of certain cases, was low FPS I experienced at first. According to forums Multi-threading and DX9 were to blame so I changed these options in launcher.And at last, don't expect GTA experience from this game.

content:
Posted: April 14
												A bit mixed. The setting and production are really good and my opinion is that it's worth it (at 2017 sale prices) for these aspects alone.However, a lot of the crime-solving gameplay feels a bit limiting and arbitrary. There's a few examples where missions become unwinnable (with a good score) depending on the order you look round the crime-scenes, since doing them in the wrong order means you don't have the evidence to ask the right questions. There's also no indication in the game of which is the right order. The interogation scenes also feel a bit arbitrary at times - it varies from interogation to interogation what counts a relevant evidence (as opposed to unsuccessful wild conjecture) and at times you need to present evidence that's quite different to the topic being discussed.After all that the cases tend to basically solve themselves, however well you do, and there's no freedom to do your own digging if you're beginning to have suspicions about the identify of a serial killer (say) that your character hasn't yet caught up with.After all that moan, I did basically enjoy it, but it's probably best done in smallish chunks so it doesn't become too easy to see the formula.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												I should start with the disclaimer that I'm a fan of open-world games in general and Rockstar games in particular. LA Noire was developed by a non-Rockstar studio, Team Bondi, and Rockstar entered relatively late in the development process. I presume they invested funds and technical support to keep the project afloat, but that's only speculation on my part. What isn't speculation is that it was a vast, ambitious project of the sort Rockstar likes, and the results were amazing.It's like playing two seasons of a period crime drama. Including the DLC there are over twenty missions (not including the four five-to-fifteen-minute training missions) and each is thirty to ninety (or more) minutes long, depending on how much rubbernecking you do. The overarching story is engrossing, and replaying it reveals nuances and foreshadowing that weren't obvious the first time around.Strengths: Well-researched recreation of 1947 Los Angeles (though only some, albeit large, sections of it), and 1947 cars, with some concessions made to the "print the legend" philosophy (e.g., the Intolerance movie set was actually struck decades before 1947). Cutting-edge facial capture technology and a top-drawer cast of hundreds -- I've actually recognized actors in live-action TV just from seeing their avatars in LA Noire. Dozens of intriguing cases that piece together a complex overarching story.Weaknesses: I like the overall story, but a lot of folks don't like it as much as I do, and you play as Cole Phelps (Badge 1247, as you will learn, and learn, and learn) who's a strait-laced kind of guy and not necessarily easy to warm up to. The open world is huge but somewhat underutilized; though there are a full forty action-packed side missions, replayable in free roam mode, and cool collectibles like concept/luxury cars and film reels named after classic noir movies, just walking around rarely feels as "alive" as GTA or Red Dead Redemption. As for interrogation: careful observation will serve you well, as the makers intended, but there will be times when you will mess up and won't know why. For some missions, replaying to get the best rating will probably require you to look up a walkthrough.LA Noire has a somewhat different feel and slower pace than Rockstar's other hits, especially GTA, but it evinces the same love of insanely detailed setting, memorable characters, and snappy dialogue. And if you've ever wanted to immerse yourself in the year 1947, there's really no other game in town.

There's a few examples where missions become unwinnable (with a good score) depending on the order you look round the crime-scenes, since doing them in the wrong order means you don't have the evidence to ask the right questions. There's also no indication in the game of which is the right order. The interogation scenes also feel a bit arbitrary at times - it varies from interogation to interogation what counts a relevant evidence (as opposed to unsuccessful wild conjecture) and at times you need to present evidence that's quite different to the topic being discussed.After all that the cases tend to basically solve themselves, however well you do, and there's no freedom to do your own digging if you're beginning to have suspicions about the identify of a serial killer (say) that your character hasn't yet caught up with.After all that moan, I did basically enjoy it, but it's probably best done in smallish chunks so it doesn't become too easy to see the formula.

												Excellent game, it isn't for the folk who play online shooters like cod and such. This game is something completely different. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2013
												Personally I play on Black and White mode with UI prompts disabled. Harder but more fun in my opinion.This is a game for people who play for the story and don't get put off by having to think seriously.While it is open world outside of objectives there doesn't seem to be much to do besides finding cars and doing side missions that randomly pop up. You mostly travel while in a police chase. Traveling to locations is entirely optional since you can get in the passenger seat and ask your partner to drive.Choices matter in this quite a lot from how you judge what people say in response to your questioning to what leads you pick up. Sometimes you will end up arresting someone without having checked all your leads because they appear to be guilty. Reading your report at the end of each case scores you on how you performed and even adds comments on how you could have done better. I've a feeling that my judgement has led a few innocent people behind bars.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												L.A. Noire is built around giving players the ability to, as the name perfectly implies, unleash the Force. This is a version of the Force that really hasn't been seen anywhere before, with over-the-top uses of things like Force Push. When you go to push a stormtrooper away from you, he won't just fall over, he'll fly. You can Force Grip soldiers and toss them into oncoming TIE fighters, stab someone with a nicely tossed lightsaber that happens to be electrified for extra coolness, or use a good old bit of Force Repulse to shove a group of soldiers away from you and off the side of a suspended bridge (which will also result in the bridge buckling from the blast).When you first take control of Vader's secret apprentice, he's already pretty powerful with Force Push and Force Grip in his repertoire. But by the time you reach the end of the game, he's incredibly powerful. Stormtroopers that previously took a few swipes of a lightsaber to down now hit the floor in one swoop, and your Force powers will recharge quickly for repeated use. Being able to Force Push one guy off a ledge, electrify the guy next to him, slice down a third trooper and then Force Repulse all of their bodies off your standing within a couple seconds is flat-out awesome.

There is little feedback for interogation though, so you get things wrong and never find out what the right answer was.  Some of the clues don't coorespond intuitively to the questioning, and you mostly feel lost even though you can clearly see someone is lying.  I'm not even sure questioning people successfully changed the outcome of the missions.  I got better at the game as time went along, but it felt repetitive and took a long time to beat. The story took some weird turns and the end was awkwardly abrupt.  I'm glad I played it but I wouldn't recommend it.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												LA Noire is extremely repetetive and has no replay value. It is interesting the first fiew missions but after a while you realise that every mission is basicly the same, the only difference is that the clues becomes more difficult to find and the face expressions becomes less and less obvious if they are lying or not. LA Noire is a game where you find clues and sit and judge people based on evidence. The driving in the game is nothing interesting because the city you are in contains nothing outside of your primary missions. There is no cloth shops, no random events on the streets, no nothing. The freedom is extremely limited. It may look like a GTA game but it is not. The city is staged with cutscenes and linear paths everywhere. A car chase leads the exact same path every time because of how staged it is.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2012
												Two things make this game suck.The first is that the game forces you to be an idiot. You have to go through something like 6-8 murder cases which are quite obviously the responsibility of a serial killer, but your thick jackass of a main character is too ♥♥♥♥ing stupid to figure this out no matter how much you yell at the back of his stupid head. The second problem is that (partially because Cole is such a ♥♥♥♥ing idiot) the game refuses to let you win. You gather evidence, find clues and search for the truth... only to have the bad guys rub their hands together, make a few backroom deals and ♥♥♥♥ you over. You would think this is building towards an ultimate confrontation, but instead at the end you just sort of die and lose. Yeah. ♥♥♥♥. A few cases are worthwhile, but the silly grimdark angle the story holds to coupled with  American patriotic nonsense sour it. Overall: I wish this game were a person so I could punch it in the ♥♥♥♥ing mouth.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Completed this game before on a console, and quite like the content, though typical Rockstar style missions often ended in frustration when the AI went wonky. In this case though, the worst part is the bugs. First half hour in, I've already had 3 game breaking bugs, and a number of other annoyances. I can't advise purchasing this, as it's essentially unplayable for any length of time. Examples: Scene music fails to fade out, leading me to believe there are more clues when there are not (verified by walkthrough); character constantly saying "You drive, I need to look at the case notes" and opening note book whilst attempting to walk to building across the road; character will not jump over a fence during the jumping over a fence tutorial (no joke), making this impassable. This is just a subset. It's a shame really, as I was looking forward to playing this on a decent machine where I could aim prooperly - the shoot outs were always the worst bits when using a controller...

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Just an incredible waste of money. The game does not work, no matter what I do. I tried various fixes, none of them worked, the game just runs at a smooth 15 FPS. My PC can display GTA V at 50 FPS, yet it seems too bad to make L.A. Noire an enjoyable experience. Which is quite understandable, since this game is known to be more greedy on the hardware than Crysis 3, Shadow of Mordor and Metro: Last Light together. Or it could be that Rockstar just ♥♥♥♥ed up again and made another poor port from the console peasants. With that being said, the game actually is great. I already played it on PS3 (say what!) and enjoyed the hell out of it. However, the only way to play it on PC is to have a GeForce Titan X coupled with an Intel i7 5960x processor, cooled by two giant ice blocks fit into a case the size of a boat motor. Or you just play it on consoles, because there it actually runs on 30 FPS. If you want to throw your money out the window, buy it, but if you are looking for a great (and playable) game, I suggest you save your 10€ and spend it on a game actually worth the money. Or, you get it for consoles. But who plays on them anyway?

You gather evidence, find clues and search for the truth... only to have the bad guys rub their hands together, make a few backroom deals and ♥♥♥♥ you over. You would think this is building towards an ultimate confrontation, but instead at the end you just sort of die and lose. Yeah. ♥♥♥♥. A few cases are worthwhile, but the silly grimdark angle the story holds to coupled with  American patriotic nonsense sour it. Overall: I wish this game were a person so I could punch it in the ♥♥♥♥ing mouth.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Do not play this game expecting a GTA+Mafia hybrid.Though it is closer to Mafia than it is to GTA, it still stands on its own.Now I wanted to recommend this game, I really did, but there are more things wrong than there are good, which tips my scale towards not recommended.@Pros:+Provides a great social commentary on 1940s Los Angeles, I believe it very well captures the good and the bad about people's mentality of that time.+Great map design, even the map captures 1940s very well.+Great attention to details, basically everything in this game describes 1940s very accurately, details like traffic lights, cigars, cars, news papers, music, clothes, guns and much more.+Facial expressions recorded from real actors, giving realistic expressions, making the "Lie", "Doubt" or "Truth" choice system be based on people's facial expressions, as much as it is based on facts you've collected.+The game does not hold back, they didn't cheap out for the PG rating, it is very dark in nature, and does not make an attempt in giving you false hope or flowery\holding-hands endings to the cases, from beginning to end it is very dark and realistic, just how you'd expect from a homicide investigation and chasing a serial killer, dead bodies, children burnt to a crisp and naked bodies of dead and r@ped women, kinda reminds me of the movie Se7en actually, it is SO dark in fact, it might be borderline depressing for some people.I find this quote from Chris Stuckmann's Sicario review describes the darkness of this game well: " https://youtu.be/DmnrlJifm3Y?t=2m45s " -->from 2:45 to 3:03@Cons:-The gameplay gets very repetitive very fast.-The story is too linear.-Disappointing ending.-You can't explore the map after finishing the game, you'll have to load the save before the final mission and play from there.-The game is god damn dark (see my Pros above)-The game feels like it was left in the middle of development, side tasks that lead to nowhere and subplots that don't take you anywhere.In short, if you think you can handle the dark story and imagery of this game, and you're looking for a story driven game rather than a GTA-like game, maybe grab L.A. Noire on a sale.Otherwise I generally do not recommend it.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												The idea of this game is fantastic, but the execution is terrible.  While Rockstar games did an excellent job of creating a beautiful historic setting, I often felt disengaged from what was going on aside from typical "go here and shoot this" mechanics.  Perhaps they felt intimidated by straying too far from their typical core audience and felt they had to make a hand-holding cop simulator.  I kept playing in hopes that it would get better, but after the novelty of the setting wore off it had the same mind-numbingly tedious gameplay that most MMORPG’s are notorious for.  Don’t waste your time on this.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												I tried to like this game, and it is somewhat intriguing at first, but its novelty wears off really fast.The often mentioned facial expressions aren't all that great, much less do they help in the interrogations. Which are kind of boring and seem random at times. The "acting" may be great "for a computer game" (and I wouldn't even agree to that), but it's still crappy overall and somewhat in uncanny valley.There is a certain open-world element to the game, but you have to wonder why exactly. You need to get from A to B and get to collect sightseeing places on the way, as well as some - again random - mini side missions. After a while, the driving around is just a waste of time; much less fun than I had in, say, Mafia.The cases themselves are somewhat nicely written, but they drag on and on because the on-site investigation is a point-and-click minigame at heart, which results in walking around every corner of houses and picking up the most irrelevant items to avoid missing any clue. Not to mention the often atrocious camera (hello console port) which often hinders you doing stuff you don't really want to be doing anyway.It's just boring overall.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												What is this game?Is an open world, detective game set in LA in the year 1947. You are an ex commander of the second World War who became a policeman, you get to start ranking up as you solve cases.The Pros:The game is fantastic, it got great atmosfere, great facial animation due to unique facial capture technology, a world that feels alive, great attention to detail, haves collectibles and unlockables, interesting stories, good character development, spot on controls and interesting mechanics.The Flaws:The game can be sometimes very slow and can get boring if played for long, also most of the choices you make dont really affect the outcome of the story, just the dialoge and your overral score in the mission, also awefully long loading times interrut the flow of the game.Port Especific Flaws:The port is terrible, there is a 30fps cap, the game runs slowly even in capable computers and this was never patched, the only way of fixing is adding some commands to the option menu on the launcher. THIS IS WHY I DONT RECOMEND BUYING THIS VERSION, GET THE PS3 VERSION FOR A BETTER EXPERIENCEConclusion:The game is a bit flawed but is definetly a unique and amaizng eexperience you should try.Score: 9/10 Amazing Game

												Look don't get me wrong there is a good and clever game in here, it's just not for everyone and I happen to be one of the minority who just didn't like it.  To be honest I found the interrogating mechanic to be just too hit and miss at times to really get me immersed in a rather tedious and disjointed story at times.  When the interrogations go wrong they degenerate into Cole Phelps starting to shout at the witness/suspect like a petulant child.  Maybe it gets better but after 13 hours I just couldn't be bothered anymore.  Just drags too much at times with some of the dialogue being rather painful.  Ultimately I just found it boring and depressing.  Probably should have stuck with it longer but lost interest.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2012
												An unfathomably miserable excuse for a game.  Let me set the picture for you.  You play hide n' seek to find random bits of evidence, but all the logical sense that you can put together never matters, because even though you're only put in a situation where you have to guess Truth, Doubt or Lie 600 times in a row, you get them invariably wrong no matter what evidence you collect or tells that the game's devs read SO POORLY that a professional poker player would be left scratching his head to a bloody pulp.Each and every developer responsible for this travesty of a game should take turns striking each other in the face for letting loose this jaw-droppingly pitiful game.  I guess, in the rare case, you're an individual who enjoys being told "Wrong, wrong, wrong, incorrect, incorrect, incorrect" a couple thousand times, then this game'll be right up your alley.One of the few games that dutifully earned a 0/100 from me; and that takes more than a modicum of effort at wanting to be one of the worst games in the history of gaming.  Rockstar should be ashamed of themselves for this trash.

You play hide n' seek to find random bits of evidence, but all the logical sense that you can put together never matters, because even though you're only put in a situation where you have to guess Truth, Doubt or Lie 600 times in a row, you get them invariably wrong no matter what evidence you collect or tells that the game's devs read SO POORLY that a professional poker player would be left scratching his head to a bloody pulp.Each and every developer responsible for this travesty of a game should take turns striking each other in the face for letting loose this jaw-droppingly pitiful game.  I guess, in the rare case, you're an individual who enjoys being told "Wrong, wrong, wrong, incorrect, incorrect, incorrect" a couple thousand times, then this game'll be right up your alley.One of the few games that dutifully earned a 0/100 from me; and that takes more than a modicum of effort at wanting to be one of the worst games in the history of gaming.  Rockstar should be ashamed of themselves for this trash.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												LA Noir, my first game on PC. I have never played a game like LA Noir before. It is unique unlike any other game i have yet come across. You play as Detective Cole Phelps for 90 percent of the game and Jack Kelso the other 10. You go around the streets of LA solving cases, asking people questions about information they may or may not know and getting into a little bit of combat here and there. Trust me this is a lot of fun and an enjoyable game for the first 10 hours, but a 22+ hour game not so much. What im trying to say is that the game is WAY too long. Rockstar the game developers of lA Noir have had a history of very long games such as GTA, Red Dead Redemption etc. I constantly said to my self 'when is this game going to end'? The combat in the game is great and a lot of fun, but the only problem is that there is hardly any and when there is it only last for like 2 minutes. A game like this should have beeeen of maximum of 12 hours andif they had added more cobat i would have given this game a higher score.      Overall LA Noir is a descent game in my opinion and I would recommend it to anyone into an open world game with solving cases, figuring out codes etc.      7.2/10      Pros -Good cobat (When there is some)     Cons -Too long       -Great voice acting                                    -Vehicle chases

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2012
												In my opinion, L.A. Noire is easily the best game that Rockstar has released on any platform. The story is absolutely amazing as it brings every detail to light and comes full circle by the end of the game. You play as a detective in Los Angeles after the close of World War II. As you attempt to solve murder, narcotics and various other cases, the game requires you to critically think as you progress through each case. Each investigation requires you to inverview possible suspects and decide whether they are telling the truth or lying. At the same time, there are numerous instances where gun play is an important part of the game as well.I highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the Grand Theft Auto series, or any previous sandbox game by Rockstar.

												Look don't get me wrong there is a good and clever game in here, it's just not for everyone and I happen to be one of the minority who just didn't like it.  To be honest I found the interrogating mechanic to be just too hit and miss at times to really get me immersed in a rather tedious and disjointed story at times.  When the interrogations go wrong they degenerate into Cole Phelps starting to shout at the witness/suspect like a petulant child.  Maybe it gets better but after 13 hours I just couldn't be bothered anymore.  Just drags too much at times with some of the dialogue being rather painful.  Ultimately I just found it boring and depressing.  Probably should have stuck with it longer but lost interest.

content:
Posted: January 25
												I was looking forward to playing this game. Being a detective, solving crimes in 40's L.A., but it turned out to be a very repetitive game, with no consequences at all if you drive like a madman, or hardly any when your interrogation goes wrong. The story is long winded, there's no logic involved in the story telling and the ending was abrupt. In my opinion they should have made it episodic, with shorter more interesting stories, no driving (you can skip the driving in this game) and a more interesting city. This is what goes wrong when you make things too big and set your aims too high.i liked some aspects of the game, very good voice acting, nice graphics, it's fun for a moment smashing your car into anything and get away with it (nobody cares). I also liked the partners and the moment you play as kelso. But overall, very disappointing for the price.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2012
												 Another masterpiece from Rockstar games, L.A Noire takes us back to 20th century where you play as Cole Phelps a former war hero who fought against Japan and now is a LAPD detective whose job to solve various crimes from murders to affairs and so on. The job of detective is hard as nail, you will need to be precise there when you search for clues and interview your suspects and finally if it needed accuse them in committing crime. Brawling, gunfights, tailing suspects everything is here.  Apart from solving 21 cases to complete main part of the game and enjoying great storyline, fear not there is much to do here.T here are a lot of side missions like finding film reels, completing other crimes, searching hidden vehicles and finally looking for places of interest. Not to mention that this complete edition has all dlcs and they are 4 new cases, and new outfits to wear. So don’t waste your time, go in store and buy this brilliant game and get on solving cases.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2012
												LA Noire is a masterpiece criminal thriller, developed by Rockstar in cooperation with Team Bondi. The story is played in Los Angeles after WW II, the player put ourselves into the skin of Cole Phelps, former war hero, now crime fighter. There are numerous cases to be solved. During them we must looking for clues, evidences;interwiev and interrogate witnesses and suspects. Some cases are real, but most of them are fictional. Mimicry and feelings on characters' face are incredibly realistic thanks to Motion Capture. Phelps is improving during the game by getting XP points. Many collectibles are hidden in LA. The complete edition contains each released DLC and the badge pursuit challenge. This game is UNIQUE:

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												I managed to grab this on some sale at steam or other, but it did actually shine out amongst the other games as you actually get to play as a detective, in what-seems to be a GTA game (from Rockstar, so what do you expect?)Starting out the game, its a standard GTA-like story driven game. The "sand-box", or "free" style of gameplay however, is very lacking in comparison however. The game follows the career of a Detective, some "bad♥♥♥♥♥quot; veteran from WW2 and his hijinx. It would be reasonable to say that this is a cross between an adventure game and a very small part action. - That said, there is also an "interrogation" mini-game to find clues or whatever.Whilst on the cover it seems to sound pretty damn cool, it is actually let-down by a number of issues. Firstly, them damn graphics. I mean, they'd be quite good... if it was released by the same time San Andreas came out. But by the release, them flickery shadows, and jaggy edges - you can see that they must have been cutting a few corners. Dated.Secondly- the "motto" of Rockstar, so far, (if you looked at GTA, or even Red Dead)- would be SAND BOX. This game is VERY linear. there are "street crime" events that happen in the city, but you'll be doing the same thing for each - Chase, shoot, suspect dead, repeat. To progress the story line, you had to go around interrogating people. you get 3 options "TRUE" , "FALSE", or "DOUBT". - there were many-a-time I had meant things in a certain way and the detective goes nuts for no reason-poopie! That said. > you could actually ask mostly wrong questions for all your suspects- then STILL manage to continue the story. - as punishment, solve street crimes- then carry on the story. pagnnhn!Conclusion > I actually had a good time for the first hour or two. I mean, the story isn't bad, but it's vastly inferior to anything that GTA gave out. Graphics? They're OK. Game-play? Not too good- not going to touch this for a LONG time. Instead of a detective game like I wanted, it was more like a Japanese style graphic novel where you just watch.As a Graphic novel, Im gonna give this a 7, but cos its in the "Games" section, ... 5? but... I did actually want to know what happened... so.. 6? yah...- I think its time I dug out that copy of "Blade Runner" again, now THAT was detective work!

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												I’m going to start this review out by saying that I was somewhat on the fence before my purchase of L.A. Noire.  I’m a fan of Rockstar and the majority of their games, but there was something about this game that had me a little anxious.  Now that I’ve played it, here’s what I think.This is, no doubt, a detective game.  There’s no ♥♥♥♥♥footing around that fact.  Most of your time will be spent doing one of three things.  Running down escaping felons, performing interrogations where you have to judge the honesty of the witness/accused, and searching for clues.  That pretty much sums up the game.  Oh, and there’s driving.I want to focus for a moment on the interrogations.  The faces of the characters in L.A. Noire have been very highly detailed.  It’s these details, as well as the way the individual sounds and acts, that give you clues if they’re telling you the truth when they answer your questions.  If you suspect they’re lying, it’s up to you to then link one of the clues to the lie.  You succeed, you catch them in the lie.  You fail, you lose the ability to use that question again.  This is probably the most difficult part of the game, and I failed miserably on my first 8 tries at the “tutorial” interrogation (which loops until you get it right).While I found the interrogation aspect of the game to be a rather successful way of immersion into the role of a detective it seemed the rest of the game somewhat broke that immersion.  It was almost like playing two games that really weren’t meant to be played together.  On one hand you had the GTA style game play that we all know, and on the other hand this extremely high level of story-based investigative detail.  I found myself wanting to “GTA” the hell out of this game whenever I was driving around or trying to stop an escaping felon, but this game punishes you for doing so.  Everything that was fun in GTA is basically prohibited from the “GTA” side of this game, thus making that entire portion of this game very boring.Talking about the GTA aspects of this game, I found the driving to be very awkward.  This game is supposed to be replicating cars from the 40’s but they certainly don’t act like cars from the 40’s.  The most unbelievable aspect of these cars is how tight they can turn.  I mean, you can be flying along and the dam things will almost turn on a dime.  The same can’t be said for stopping.  I know early cars were heavy, but these things stop worse than an overloaded big-rig.  I highly doubt any car, from any time period, would slide an entire block on pavement when you slam on the brakes.All in all this game felt like a rollercoaster.  Whenever you were talking to a witness or searching for clues you were almost on the edge of your seat with anticipation and enjoyment, but when you were playing “GTA” you were so restricted from having fun that you ended up bored to hell just waiting for it to be over.So what’s the verdict?  Do I regret my purchase?  Well… No, because I got it on sale for 80% off.  Would I buy it at full price?  Again, No.  The game has a lot of positives but some aspects of it are so boring that you have trouble staying interested in the game as a whole.  Sorry Rockstar, I just can’t recommend it.

												Normally, I love detective games. I love poking suspects for evidence, finding chinks in their lies, and exposing them. This game has that... sort of. I played through a little bit of first few missions- and from what I played... I didn't like this one at all. It has the things I like in a mystery game, but you are playing by  the game's preset of rules. What do I mean by this? If you don't do something in the exact certain order, you fail. If you don't ask question A before question B before question C, the game penalizes you for asking the question that it 'says' you have to do first. This is bullcrap! Don't penalize me for asking about the murder weapon before I ask about the scene! This restricts things too much, and I just don't have the patience to give this game when I have to restart over and over again because I'm not jumping through its hoops.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												L.A. Noire is a game developed by Team Bondi, an offshoot of Rockstar at the time it was made. People were up in arms about some of the conditions at the now shuttered studio in Australia. The head of development has responded to some of these claims. It doesn't seem that indifferent from much of the AAA landscape today. We'll  just review the product here. Overall, the questionable management and terrible working conditions still produced one hell of a game about the 1940s Los Angeles era.What you need to know is that on PC the game has been tremendously upgraded in the image quality department. 4K native is offered, but your best bet is 1080p with 4xSGSSAA through Nvidia Inspector, making this unique game a completely different experience compared to the PS3 version. This cannot be overstated.In other regards, we don't have the upgraded audio from PS3. The shadows are better than the Xbox 360, but not as precise as the PS3. That might be a good thing as shadows in that game tended to be too sharp. Texture filtering bests both consoles. Overall, the cleanliness of the image is by far the most important aspect to enjoying and being immersed in the city.As for controls: Going back to the PS3 version on the DS3 pad is exponentially worse than something like a DS4 and Input Mapper on PC. These two major changes make the PS3 version all but unplayable in retrospect. I actually went back to that version to compare, and the only thing I liked a tad more was the audio fidelity, though, it's not all that much better and most will not notice. The controls were abysmal in every way.For the game, of course, we have vintage L.A. modeled with exquisite outer detail. The indoor locations are lacking outside of the story mode, and there isn't a lot to do in the city overall, but with the DLC there are plenty of story missions to investigate, and the varied nature of the game puts you in plenty of different parts of old time Los Angeles. Travelling by car is pretty fairly smooth, and finding all the different makes and models is actually worthwhile now that the graphics have proper AA and detail.The action and movement is mediocre to okay. You won't be regarding this as the most fluid of shooting games, but what's there is serviceable if a little routine at times. Side missions are fairly bare bones. Collectibles are hard as hell to find in this sprawling map. The investigations to me are very fun, and I actually think they still hold up today. I know some people criticize the lack of knowing what to do in certain situations, but I still think this game comes closest to being one of the only immersive detective-style games out there.The Lie-Doubt-Truth mechanic works because it's honestly quit fun roaming for clues, and the art direction inside the various homes and building you enter is fairly top notch stuff even by modern standards. Being in 1940s L.A. is just kind of fun when it comes down to it. If this is not your type of setting, and you expect super high quality action, I would probably skip this game.The audio and voicework is quite good for the most part. Animations in the faces hold up because of the work they put into it, though, that does hamper the port at only 30FPS. There is a widescreen fixer for 60FPS, but I personally choose to have SGSSAA over the extra 30FPS, which can look a bit wonky at times. It is a lot smoother with that fix, so it is there if you need it.Most of what you get out of this game depends on if you like the setting. The stories and characters are for sure a cut above the average game, and some of them are very well done. But it comes back down to if you like this period and if you have the PC to play it right. An OC'd 970 and 2500K should do the job. I am currently using a 1070 and it runs perfectly at 30FPS with SGSSAA at 4x.So it's worth it just to see the detail of the city and the 1940s. The artists here pull it all off with great abandon. So much detail was drawn into this city, and yes it is a shame there is not more to do. Sometimes development hell gets the best of you. Still, the stories are interesting enough and the locations all now look so much more lovely than they ever did on the consoles. Travel around and chill out with L.A. Noire's gritty take on vintage crime and you'll have a fun experience for 30 hours or so.Posted January 26.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												This is a tough one. I'm sure when it was released in 2011 it was ground-breaking but it has not aged well. The story is the strong point, and while it's not the most suprising of endings, it is consistent and the way individual cases mesh with the main storyline is impressive. Having said that the rest of the game is a clunky mess. The driving is awkward and not fun, in fact you are penalised by doing it as having your partner drive removes the risk of crash-damage affecting your score. The shooting is unsatisfying, the clue hunting boring and the interviews, which are a key part of the game, are often ambiguous and just don't work very well. I enjoyed the story but the rest of the game was one big grind so unfortunately, even though I picked it up in  a sale, I can't recommend it. There are better places to spend your money.

I mean even when im lacking of admiration for the game this doesnt mean that I wouldnt appriciate it if they would care more about their older software. This game earned a better port - yes it does - not for me but for any other person that would enjoy this mb in its retrospectivish and very special way "master piece of its time". Cheers fellows - my final verdict4/10 by 2017 and its currenct price tag of 5 $Save your money and dont fool yourselfs by nostalgia and greed. Buy something new - you will have more fun in the long run.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2012
												L.A. Noire is a great example of how the industry's views on game design has changed over the last 10 years. Whilst before the emphasis would have been on  engaging gameplay, it's become a trend for developers to try and engage their players through flashy cinematics instead. The result is you have the player eating a sandwich of sorts with cinematics on either side and a bit of gameplay inbetween. Whilst this design can work with certain games, I think Team Bondi took it too far in the other direction. L.A. Noire feels as if it would more comfortable as a TV series than a game. I know many people joke about Heavy Rain being a movie, but Heavy Rain "solved" the problem of having an engaging storyline without interupting gametime by making the entire game into a cutscene. Conversely, L.A. Noire has you doing minor tasks in order to start the next cutscene, in which you have no control over whatsoever. The story is dull and drawn out and none of the gameplay is particularly engaging.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
												I would choose a mixed review if it was possible.Setting: nailedMusic: nailedFace Tech: creepy (especially on children), but nailedGameplay: awfulStory: ranged from good to mediocre to terribleStory's Achilles heel is the Homicide desk. A desk which one would think be the most engaging and interesting is the most boring and repetitive. It contributes literally nothing to the overarching plot and causes it to grind to a screeching halt. Removing the Homicide desk would significantly improve the overall pacing and quality of the game. Most people who leave the game unfinished will do so during Homicide or just after completing it. Also, don't forget the romance subplot later in the game which comes out of the left field.As for the gameplay. What they were going for was basically Phoenix Wright, but they couldn't pull it off - quite often forces you to jump to conclusions and focuses too much on facial animations instead of deduction. In addition, splitting the game up into cases just didn't help the story at all. What could have been a coherent and compelling film noir was made confusing and ultimately unsatisfying.
