content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												It's a PS3 port. Expect to have issue with resolution, frame rate, or it might not work at all.If you are expecting a GTA style world, turn away. It's a fairly simple map designed to provide some simple entertainment for getting you from point A to B, and to give some room for foot and car chases that are not at all as intense as they are in the GTA games. The shooting moments are so simple and short that they seem completely unnecessary.The main mechanic of the game is both it's strongest and weakest point. The itoregation process is innovative and interesting. At the same time it often leaves you feeling out of control. As your character often phrases things horribly and not at all as you expected, leaving you to deal with the outcome. In a way you don't just have to figure out what the suspect is thinking, but you have to figure out what your own character is thinking too. It can be tedious, for example (no spoilers): In the middle of the game you investigate several murders, one after another. From the very beginning your character suspects they are all committed by the same person. The victims all have a similar profile and died under similar circumstances. Which means you play through multiple scenarios that are very alike, it gets boring. Despite his suspicions you go through the motions of investigating and arresting other men, even though both your character and you suspect that these men are innocent. The game forces you to do it though, making it feel very guided and that your choices make no difference.

Rockstar is supposed to make games where you can do anything that you want with few limitations but in L.A. Noire you cant even do anything besides doing the missions and the missions were repititive! Clues, talk to a guy, talk to a guy, clues, talk to a guy, chase, shoot, clues, solve, solve end of mission then repeat. The cutscenes were also a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥because they're unskippable and they're very long! There are alot of things in this game that I didnt like and what I saw on the gameplay videos on Youtube were really it, they just showed the game intirely and it's my fault for expecting too much of this game. The graphics were really great though but the whole game in my opinion is not even good.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												First of all: what I wanted from this game was a good detective story, not a GTA-like game nor a shooter.The only real positive I can think of is the facial animation, which is really something to behold. As for the negatives:- The noire atmosphere is terribly hamfisted. It feels like they just watched a bunch of noire movies and took note of all the tropes they could use. The narration is really jarring and uninspired too.- This game is poinltessly open world, and as a result everything looks ugly.- Too many shootouts. You're a detective, not a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ SWAT.- The logic in the interrogations is all over the place. It constantly switches between demanding you to spot absolute truths (what the witness said is what happened) and relative truths (what the witness said is wrong, but he/she couldn't know), so you never know if the contradictions you just spotted are something you should point out or just irrelevant mistakes. At some points the game forces you to choose between two alternatives that you know are both wrong, and then you are even treated like an idiot because of the "mistake" you had to make.- Despite all of this the game still finds ways to push you forward even when you made blatant mistakes instead of having you fail and repeat. This makes the whole game feel completely pointless.Overall I can't find redeeming qualities in this game; I'd rather play most other adventure games.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												My rating: 6/10It's such a shame to see a game that does so many things right essentially ruined by getting so many things wrong.  I finally finished the game after starting it over 1 year ago - I started playing but quickly got so frustrated with its faults that I gave up on it and moved on to other things.  I really hate wasting money, though, so unless a game is abysmally bad (like, say, Assassin's Creed 1), I will generally force myself through to completion just to feel like I got my money's worth.  The thing about LA Noire is that it isn't abysmally bad, in fact there are a lot of things about the game that are outstanding, and I really wanted to like the game and finish it; it's just that the bad parts of the game are so bad that it took me a year before I could dredge it up again.  To clarify, let's first look at the things the game does right:Pros- Top-notch acting from every character, particularly the many well-known faces who populate the game- Amazingly impressive motion capture of the characters' faces- Great attention to detail regarding the world of 1940's LA - the look and feel were spot-on- Outstanding soundtrack- The devs realizing how horrible the "action" sequences were and providing the opportunity to skip themAll these things were done so well that it would normally be easy to overlook a few faults and love the game.  The graphics weren't exactly photorealistic, but the motion capture was so great that when coupled with the excellent camera work and soundtrack, the game felt more like an interactive movie than many other games I've played.  Unfortunately the game doesn't suffer from a few faults, and those faults are hardly minor:Cons- First and foremost, the "interrogation" system - it's horrible, it doesn't work, and it's incredibly frustrating.  This is obviously a problem because it's the primary point of the game - to gather evidence, then interrogate suspects and ferret out the guilty.  It's really the main reason why I quit the game the first time around, because half the time it's a complete guessing game.  You basically have a list of pre-generated questions, and based on the suspect's answer you have to determine whether they're telling the truth or lying, and if they're lying you have to decide if you doubt their answer - meaning you know they're lying but can't prove it - or whether they're actually lying - meaning you have evidence to prove their lie.  Seems simple enough, right?  If only.  There are supposed to be visual queues to when they're lying or not - if they stare straight at you confidently and calmly, they're supposed to be telling the truth.  If they fidget, smirk, blink excessively, or refuse to look you in the eye, then they're supposed to be lying.  This works great until the game devs decide to break their own rules, as happened to me several times when a suspect was staring straight ahead and not fidgeting at all, but it turned out they were lying.  It happened the other direction, as well - not very often, but just a few times was enough to constantly make me second-guess myself.  Then there were the times when a suspect was clearly lying and I had to pick out the precise piece of evidence the devs were looking for, which wasn't necessarily the most obvious piece of evidence I had.  A good case in point was the pregnant girlfriend of a car thief I was searching for.  I asked her if she knew what her boyfriend had been up to, and she clearly lied to me.  Now I had a piece of evidence - a diplomatic flag, taken from the stolen car, sticking out of a coffee mug that was sitting 5 feet away from the girlfriend, so I accused her of lying and pointed out the flag.  Nope! Despite evidence of the theft being mere feet away from her and her obvious lying, the devs had decided the correct answer should be "doubt", so that's what I had to choose in order to get it correct.  There are countless examples of this in the game, many being even more egregious than this, so that every interrogation question ended up making me feel like that college kid at the beginning of Ghostbusters sitting across from Bill Murray, who had his hand on the electric shock button, just waiting for the kid to answer wrong.  No interrogation in the game was a fun, sensible or even consistent experience.Even worse was how pointless the interrogations ended up being, given the sheer number of innocent people Cole put away.  Seriously, this guy really was the worst detective ever.- The driving - very few games get driving right, and this game isn't one of them.  It wouldn't have been a problem if the game didn't require so much of it, or at least didn't punish you for any damage you inflict while trying to get around.  Kudos, though, to the devs recognizing this and allowing you to skip most driving sequences and just fast travel to your destination.- The shooting - not the worst part of the game, but the cover system is terribly implemented, and the shooting itself is just boring and uninspired.  Unfortunately, there's a lot of it.- The story - it started out well enough, if a little too much like LA Confidential (which clearly inspired many of the game's elements and characters), but by the end made almost no sense at all, and ended with you gunning down innocent MPs and burning dozens of fellow LA police officers alive.  Though it was fun to watch the story unfold, it ultimately ended in a totally confusing and unsatisfying way.Overall, the game simply isn't nearly worth full price, or even a moderate discount.  It's probably good enough at 75% or 80%, if you're a big fan of James Ellroy or movies like LA Confidential, but if not then you'll probably do best to stay away.

Posted: September 20, 2014
												One of the worst games I've ever played. L.A. Noire requires a lot of guessing...A LOT. There's no fun in it because it requires no skill, it's basically you just keep trying and restarting the mission until you get it right. Perhaps if they didn't make it so there was so much guessing involved then I'd be ok with it, but that's not the case. This game is a waste of time and money, don't buy it even if it's on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												You can't stop with the car theft, can you Rockstar? This is almost as far opposite from Grand Theft Auto as a premise can possibly be, and you've still somehow managed to make it a game predominately about driving stolen cars.Why does the game constantly tell me to drive cars? I'm a detective in the 1940s! Shouldn't the achievements be 'Didn't objectify black people!', 'Managed not to beat your wife!'I actually felt pressured by the game every time I didn't stop to steal some swanky looking car. I get it game, I understand that in that area is one of fifteen 'special mystery cars' but I kinda wanted to be a detective and not feel like I was on some vintage version of Top Gear."Oh, you were gonna go investigate that triple-homicide, infanticide case? Well, that's nice and all, but did you NOT see that purple Nash Super in the garage? I guess it's YOUR choice which is more important."Good thing they also added in lots of fist fights, crazy shootouts, and over the top chases across giant Egyptian set pieces.If stealing cars that go fast and endless shootouts aren't common themes of Noir, then Rockstar doesn't know what Noir is - which is actually what I'm saying. That they have no idea what that is.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												I really wish I never bought LA Noire. At least I could have played some other game from my backlog... what can I say. It's even hard to call it a game. It's one of the worst case of interactive movie I've ever experienced: I wanted to give it a chance since I'm a big fan the LA's quartet... but this thing has nothing to do with the atmosphere and the setting of Ellroy's masterpieces. Most of all, the main story does not make any kind of sense. What about the "game"? It's so uninteresting I've even fallen asleep while playing. Investigation is boring and repetitive, Gunplay and driving are atrocious. You just pass from stupid cutscene to stupid cutscene waiting for the game to tell you what you are supposed to do, you are stripped of any kind of meaningful initiative and freedom, except during the interrogation when you are supposed to guess what the dev's wanted you to do while choosing between the "doubt" or "lie" option if the suspect start acting like he's going to make a big fart...Thanks god it's over. H(o)rgasm Rating (Holistic Review Gameplay Art Story Metrics):Gameplay: 8/25 (bad)Art: 10/25 (boring)Story: 5/25 (nonsensical)Holistic Rating: 6/25 (the game felt unpolished and disjointed)Total Rating: 29/100. Stay away.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												I am probably the only one that figured out, how to finally launch the game normally.  I will tell you how to fix this issue. I am running on Windows 10. Go To Your Steam Account, Right Click On L.A. Noire & Select Properties. Go To The Tab That Says Local Files, & Click On Verify Integrity of Game Cache. For Me, it found a file that was bad, so it replaced the file, after that, game runs perfectly fine. I hope this helps, because I don't think anyone has done this.

content:
Posted: February 13
												> Man says he has nothing to do with murder.> I say he's lying.> The game tells me to select a peice of evidence.> I select the gun that he owns that was found at the crime scene.> Wrong evidence, interrogation failed.> I want to try again, since I felt that was unfair so I hit the restart option.> I lose a half hour of progress.> ♥♥♥♥ it.Edit Feb 16: Kept playing through the first two cases. The interrogation system really does suck. Very frustrating. It tells you that you're wrong without giving you a way to fix it, which just feels bad. There doesn't seem to be any descernable difference between doubt and lie. Even when I figured out what was happening before the dtectives, I still couldn't piece together which arbitrary peice of evidence the game wanted me to pick.Also the acting in the interogations is baffling. From odd pursed lips that are supposed to indicate lying, to the uncomfortably unwavering eye contact that indicates truth. I feel bad for some of these actors, because the format and direction of this game forces them to turn in some really awful performances.Aaron Staton is good as Cole, despite Cole being insane. He jumps from boy scout to a screaming lunatic from line to line, and his partner isn't any better.The story of this game probably would be okay, I might go watch a let's play. The flash backs are interesting, and I assume that Kelso guy is going to pop back up in present day. Probably turned out to be a serial killer or something crazy like that. Joker to Cole's Batman.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Amid the post-war boom of Hollywood's Golden Age, Cole Phelps is an LAPD detective thrown headfirst into a city drowning in its own success. Corruption is rampant, the drug trade is exploding, and murder rates are at an all-time high. In his fight to climb the ranks and do what's right, Phelps must unravel the truth behind a string of arson attacks, racketeering conspiracies and brutal murders, battling the L.A. underworld and even members of his own department to uncover a secret that could shake the city to its rotten core. Using groundbreaking new animation technology that captures every nuance of an actor's facial performance in astonishing detail, L.A. Noire is a violent crime thriller that blends breathtaking action with true detective work to deliver an unprecedented interactive experience. Search for clues, chase down suspects and interrogate witnesses as you struggle to find the truth in a city where everyone has something to hide.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
												Story and characters are alright but there are quite a few things that make this game uplayable. The firs and by far most common that you will find is the fact that it is capped at 30 fps. Wich is bad but after a bit you will get used to it. Another annoyance is the characters faces of all things. They are extremly high definition and extremly expressive allowing the player to use the truth/lie system effectively. With that said however the rest of textures are decent resolution meaning that the faces do not fit with how the rest of the game looks. And the final thing this is the one that absolutly killed it - and the thing that made me request a refund - is pop in textures, not just pop in textures but sometimes textures and terrain meshes that will simply not show up. Meaning that you are just driving around in an empty abyss until about a minute later the game pops those textures and meshes back in and you are now stuck in a lamp post. This happens far far to frequently to be somthing that a reasonable person could overlook. And by the way my rig is no slouch it should have no problems what so ever of this kind. Like I said the game is fantastic (at least the bits I played) but on pc I cannot recomend it at all.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Runs pretty well. Good old Cluedo-cop PC Game with pretty fair graphics. But you have to sign into Rockstar Games to play; and if you have lost your old e-mail (as I have done previously), you lose the game (as I have done previously); probably.The Great thing about games like this is they are more advanced in Controls than games like Metal Gear Solid 5. Because MGS5 is incompetently coded, in that if you are disabled (have missing fingers on your left-hand and/or you are left-haned and use the Number-Keypad for all Shooter-type games), then you are bang out of luck, and KONAMI and Steam do not give a flying fk wether you can actually play the thing or not. The Forums order you to buy a Steam/controller but they refuse to ask KONAMI to cripple all Right-handed keyboard use: and are thus hypocrites.But Rockstar and the Assassin`s Creed series (and others) do allow you to re-map for such scanarios as great game companies have done for 20-years (but recent rat-coders fail to implement).So, a thumbs up for L.A. Noir.

number of helpful: 21 of 49 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												L.A. Noire...- punishes players with no save/load feature. I don't care if you want the story to flow and me to live with my mistakes, go to hell. Have saving and loading so I don't need to exit out of the game and reload it to access an auto-save.- is a big, open world in a linear game with nothing to do in the world outside of the intermittent, drive-out-of-the-way Street Crime segment- the music is good, but the horn is pretty much required if you want to get through the open world quickly (and you do, because there's nothing to do in it). Still, even then, pedestrians and drivers sometimes like to just stop instead of getting out of your way when you have the horn on. Sometimes I think I killed more people with the horn on than off.- the story driven dialogue is top notch, but all additional in-game voice acting for NPCs and such is so dull and typicalI'll give L.A. Noire credit, its story idea and music and setting are all great, but this did not need to be an open world game. I grew bored with it after about 10 hours. I got tired of driving through the town, got tired of getting punished for driving poorly in a game with a poor driving engine, and got tired of not being able to save and load. I would highly recommend this game if it were just a little less horrendously tedious.
